editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SATYR OF Titus Petronius Arbiter, A Roman Knight. With its Fragments, recover'd at BELGRADE.
Made Englih by Mr. BURNABY of the Middle-Temple, and another Hand.

q.p: Nihil hominum inepta peruaione falius nec ficta everitate ineptius.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Samuel Bricoe, at the Corner of Charles Street, in Ruel Street, Covent-Garden. 1694.

div.head: To the Right Honourable HENRY Earl of Rumney, Vicount Sidney, Mater-General of Their Majeties Ordinance, one of Their Majeties mot Honourable Privy-Council, Contable of Dover-Catle, and Lord Warder of the Cinque-Ports.
div.p:
GOod Men think the meanet Friend no more to be dipis'd, than the Politick the meanet Enemy; and the Generous
wou'd be as inquiitive to dicover an unknown Eteem for 'em, as the Cautious an unknown Hatred: This I ay to plead my elf into the number of thoe you know for your Admirers; and that the World may know it, give me leave to Preent you with a Tranlation of Petronius, and to abolve all my Offences againt him, by introducing him into o agreeable Company. You're happy, my Lord, in the mot Elegant part of his Character, in the Gallantry and Wit of a Polite Gentleman, mixt with the Obervation
and Conduct of a Man of Publick Employments; And ince all hare the benefit of you, 'tis the Duty of all to confes their ence of it, I had almot aid, to return, as they cou'd, the Favour, and like a true Author, made that my Gratitude which may prove your Trouble: But what flatters me mot out of the apprehenions of your Dilike, is the Gentlemanlike Pleaantry of the Work, where you meet with variety of Ridicule on the Subject of Nero's Court, an agreeable Air of Humour in a Ramble through Schools,
Bagnio's, Temples, and Markets; Wit and Gallantry in Amours, with Moral Reflections on almot every Accident of Humane Life. In hort, my Lord, I hall be very proud to Pleae a Sidney, an Houe Fertile, of extraordinary Genio's, whoe every Member deerves his own Sir Philip to Celebrate him; whoe Characters are Romances to the ret of Mankind, but real Life in his own Family.
div.closer: I am, my LORD, Your Lordhips mot devoted Humble Servant, W. BURNABY.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THe Moors ('tis aid) us'd to cat their newborn Children into the Sea, and only if they Swam would think 'em worth their Care; but mine, with more neglect, I turn into the World; for ink or wim, I have done all I deign'd for't. I have already, with as much atisfaction as Aeneas in a Cloud heard Dido praie him, heard the Beaux-Criticks condemn
this Tranlation before they aw it, and with as much Judgment as if they had: And after they had Prophetically dicover'd all the Flaws in the turns of Thought, the cadence of Periods, and had almot brought in Epick and Drama, they upt their Coffee, took Snuff, and charitably concluded to end Bricoe the Pye-Woman to help off with his Books. Well, I have nothing to ay, but that thee brisk Gentlemen that draw without occaion, mut put up without atisfaction.

After the Injury of 1700 Years or better, and the everal
Editions in Quarto, Octavo, Duodecimo, &c. with their repective Notes, to little purpoe; for thee Annotators upon matters of no difficulty, are o tedious, that you can't get rid of their enlargements without leeping, but at any real Knot are too Modet to interupt any Man's Curioity in the untying of it. After o many Years, I ay, it happen'd upon the taking of Belgrade this Author was made Entire; made o becaue the New is upected to be Illegitimate: But it has o many Features of the lawful Father, that he was at
leat thought of when 'twas got. Now the Story's made out, the Character of Lycas alter'd, and Petronius freed from the imputation of not making Divine or Humane Jutice purue an ill-pent Life.

As to the Tranlation, the other Hand, I believe, has been very careful; but if my part don't atisfie the World, I hould be glad to ee my elf reveng'd in a better Verion; and tho' it may prove no difficult Province to improve what I have done, I hall yet have the credit of the firt Attempt.

If any of the Fine Gentlemen hould be angry after they have read it, as ome, to ave that trouble, have before; and protet I've yet debaucht Petronius, and robb'd him of his Language, his only Purity, I hope we hall hortly be reconciled, for I have ome very prety new Songs ready for the Pres: If this atisfies them, I'll venture to tell others that I have dret the meaning of the Original as modetly as I could, but to have quite hid the obcaenity, I thought, were to Invent, not Tranlate.

As for the Ladies, if any too-dicerning antiquated Hypocrite
(for only uch I fear) hou'd be angry with the beatly Author; let the Work be my Advocate, where the little liberties I take, as modetly betray a broad Meaning, as bluhing when a Man tells the Story.

Thoe who object, that things of this nature ought not to be Tranlated, mut arraign the Verions of Juvenal, Suetonius, &c. but what Suetonius thought excuable in Hitory, any ober Man will think much more allowable in Satyr: Nor can this be offenive to Goodmanners, ince the gros part here is the diplaying of Vices of that Dye, that there's an abhorrence
even in Nature from 'em; nor is it poible that any ill Man can talk a good one into a new Frame or Compoition; nay, perhaps it may be applicable to a good ue, to ee our own happines, that we know that to be oppoite to Humanity it elf, which ome of the Ancients were deluded even to practie as Wit and Gallantry; thus I'm o far from being toucht in expreing thoe Crimes, that I think it makes the more for me, the more they're deteted.

If I have alter'd or added to the Author, it was either to render thoe Cutoms of the Romans
that were analogous to ours, by what was more familiar to us, or to prevent a Note by enlarging on others where I found 'em.
The Vere of both Parts are Mine, and I have taken a great liberty in 'em; and tho' I believe there I have not wrong'd the Original, yet all will not amount to call them Good.

The Money at firt I made Englih Coin, but not the exact worth, becaue it wou'd have been odd in ome places to have brought in pence and farthings; as when the thouand Seterces are offered to dicover Gito, it would not be conitent with
the hate they were in to offer o many Pounds, o many Shillings, and o many Pence: I therefore proportion'd a umm to the Story without cating up the Seterces; thus they went to the Pres: But advis'd either to give the jut value or the Roman Coin, I reolv'd on the latter for the Reaons I have given, and alter'd the Summs as the Proofs came to my hands; but truting the care of one Sheet to a Friend, the umm 2000 Crowns pat unalter'd.

div.head: THE SATYR OF Titus Petronius Arbiter, A Roman Knight. With its Fragments, recover'd at BUDA, 1688.
div.byline: Made Englih by Mr. BURNABY of the Middle-Temple, and another Hand.

p.q: I Promis'd you an Account of what befel me, and am now reolv'd to be as good as my Word, being o met to our Deires; not only to improve our Learning but to be Merry, and put Life in our Dicoure with pleaanter Tales.

div.p:
Fabricius Vejeuto has already, and that wittily handled the Juggle of Religion,
and withal dicover'd with what impudence and ignorance Priets pretend to be inpir'd: But are not our wrangling Pleaders poet with the ame Frenzy? who cant it; Thee Wounds I receiv'd in defence of your Liberty; this Eye was lot in your Service; lend me a Hand to hand me to my Children, for my faltering Hams are not able to upport me.

Yet even this might pas for tolerable, did it put young beginners in the leat way to well-peaking. Whereas now, what with the inordinate welling of Matter, and the empty ratling of Words, they only gain this, That when they come to appear in Publick, they think themelves in another World. And therefore I look upon the young fry of Collegiates as likely to make the mot hopeful Blockheads, becaue they neither hear nor ee any thing that is in ue among Men: But a company of Pirates with their Chains on the hoar; Tyrants iuing Proclamations to make Children kill their Fathers; the anwers of Oracles in a Plague-time, that three or more Virgins be acrific'd to appeae the Gods; dainty fine Honey-Pellets of Words, and every thing o aid and
done, as if it were all Spice and Garnih.

Thoe that are thus bred can no more undertand, than thoe that live in a Kitchin not tink of the Greae: Give me, with your favour, leave to ay, 'twas you firt lot the good grace of peaking; for with light idle gingles of Words to make port ye have brought it to this, That the ubtance of Oratory is become effeminate and unk.

Young Men were not kept to this way of declaiming when Sophocles and Euripides influenc'd the Age. Nor yet had any blind Alley-Profeor foil'd their Inclinations, when Pindar and the Nine Lyricks durt not attempt Homer's Numbers: And that I may not bring my Authority from Poets, 'tis certain, neither Plato nor Demothenes ever made it their Practice: A S • il • one would value, and as I may call it, a chat Oration, is not platchy nor woll'n, but ries with a natural Beauty.

This windy and irregular way of • abling came lat • ly out of Aia into Athens; and having, like ome ill Planet, blated the apiring Genius of their Youth, at once corrupted and put a period to all tr • e Eloquence.

After this, Who came up to the height of Thucydides? Who reach'd the Fame of Hyperedes? Nay, there was hardly a Vere of a right train: But all, as of the ame batch, di'd with their Author. Painting alo made no better an end, after the boldnes of the Egyptians ventur'd to bring o great an Art into a narrower compas.

At this and the like rate my elf once declaim'd, when one Agamemnon made up to us, and looking harply on him, whom the Mob with uch diligence oberv'd, he would not uffer me to declaim longer in the Portico, than he had weated in the School; But, young Man, aid he, becaue your Dicoure is beyond the common apprehenion, and, which is not often een, that you are a lover of Undertanding, I won't deceive you: The Maters of thee Schools are not to blame, who think it neceary to be mad with mad Men: For unles they teach what their Scholars approve, they might, as Cicero ays, keep School to themelves: like flattering mell-Feats, who when they come to great Mens Tables tudy nothing more than what they think may be mot agreeable to the Company (as well knowing they hall never obtain what they would,
unles they firt pread a Net for their Ears) o a Mater of Eloquence, unles, fiherman like, he bait his Hook with what he knows the Fih will bite at, may wait long enough on the Rock without hopes of catching any thing.

Where lies the Fault then? Parents ought to be harply reprehended, who will not have their Children come on by any trict Method; but in this, as in all things, are o fond of making a Noie in the World; and in uch hate to compas their Wihes, that they hurry them in publick e'er they have digeted what they have read, and put Children e'er they are well pat their Sucking-Bottle, upon the good grace of peaking, than which even themelves confes, nothing is greater: Whereas if they would uffer them to come up by degrees, that their Studies might be temper'd with grave Lectures; their Affections fahion'd by the Dictates of Widom; that they might work themelves into a Matery of Words; and for a long time hear, what they're inclined to imitate, nothing that pleas'd Children, wou'd be admir'd by them. But now Boys trifle in the Schools, young Men are laugh'd at in publick, and, which is wore than both, what every one foolihly takes up in his Youth, no one will
confes in his Age. But that I may not be thought to condemn Lucilius, as written in hate, I alo will give you my Thoughts in Vere.
div.l: Who ere wou'd with ambitious jut d • ire,
To Matery in o fine an Art apire,
Mut all Extreams firt diligently hun,
And in a ettled coure of V • rtue run.
Let him not Fortune with tiff Gr • at •• s climb,
Nor, Courtier-like, with Cringes undermine;
Nor all the Brother Blockheads of the Pot,
Ever peruade him to become a Sot;
Nor flatter Poets to acquire the Fame
Of, I protet, a pretty Gentleman.
But whether in the War be wou'd be great,
Or, ele his amorous Breat he wou'd improve
Well, to receive the youthful Cares of Love.
In his firt Years to Poetry inclin'd,
Let Homer's Spring bedew his fruitful Mind;
His manli • r Years to manlier Studies brought,
Philoophy mut next imply his Thought.
Then let his boundles Soul new Glories • ire,
And to the great Demothenes apire.
When round in throngs the lit'ning People come,
T' admire what prung in Greece o low at home.
Rais'd to this height, your leiure hours engage
In omething jut and worthy of the Stage;
Your choice of Words from Cicero derive;
And in your Poems you deign hou'd live,
The Joys of Feats, and Terrors of a War,
More pleaing thoe, and thee more frightful are,
When told by you, than in their acting were:
And thus, enrich'd with uch a golden • ore,
You're truly fit to be on Orator.
div.p:
While I was wholly taken up with Agamemnon, I did not oberve how Acyltos had given me the lip, and as I continu'd my diligence, a great crowd of Scholars fill'd the Portico, to hear, (as it appear'd afterwards) an extemporary Declamation, of I know not whom, that was dicanting on what Agamemnon had aid; while therefore they ridicul'd his Advice, and condemn'd the order of the whole, I took an o • portunity of getting from them, and ran in qu • t of Acyltos: But the hurry I was in, with my ignorance where our Inn lay, o ditracted me, that wha • way oever I went, I return'd by <>
••• e, till tir'd in the puruit, and all in a weat, I met an old Herb-Woman: An • , I be •• ech • e Mother, quoth I, do you know whereabouts I dw • ll? Pleas'd with the implicity of uch a home-bred J • t, W •• hould I not? anwer'd he; and <> on her Feet went on b •• ore me: I
thought her no les than a Witch: But, having led me into a bye Lane, he threw off her Pyebal'd Patch't-Mantle, and here, quoth he, you can't want a Lodging.

While I was denying I knew the Houe, I oberv'd a company of Beaux reading the Bills o'er the Cells, on which was incrib'd the Name of the Whore and her Price; and others of the ame Function naked, cuttling it here and there, as if they would not, yet would be een: When too late I found my elf in a Bawdy-Houe, curing the Jade that had trapan'd me thither, I cover'd my Head and was jut making off through the midt of them, when in the very Entry Acyltos met me, but as tir'd as my elf, and in a manner dead; you'd have worn the ame old Woman brought him. I could not forbear laughing, but having aluted each other, I ask'd him what buines he had in o candalous, a place? he wip'd his Face, And if you knew, aid he, what has happen'd to me—As what? quoth I.

He faintly reply'd; When I had rov'd the whole City without finding where I had left the Inn, the Mater of this Houe came up to me, and kindly profer'd to be my
Guide; o through many a cros Lane and blind turning, having brought me to this Houe, he drew his Weapon and pret for a cloer ingagement. In this Affliction the Whore of the Cell alo demanded Garnih-Money; and he laid uch Hands on me, that had I not been too trong for him, I had gone by the wort of it.

p.q: While Acyltos was telling his Tale, in come the ame Fellow, with a Woman, none of the leat agreeable, and looking upon Acyltos, entreated him to walk in and fear nothing, for if he would not be Paive he might be Active: The Woman on the other hand pres'd me to go in with her. We follow'd therefore, and being led among thoe Bills, we aw many of both Sexes at work in the Cells *, o much every of them eem'd to have taken a Provocative *.

Nor were we ooner dicover'd than they wou'd have been at us with the like Impudence, and in a trice one of them, his Coat tuck'd under his Girdle, laid hold on Acyltos, and having thrown him athwart a Couch, would have been bobbing at him: I preently ran to help the undermot, * and putting our trengths together, we made
nothing of the troubleom Fool *. Acyltos went off, and flying, left me expos'd to the Fury; but, thanks to my trength, I got off without hurt.

div.p: I had almot travert the City round, * when through the dusk I aw Gito on the Beggars-Bench of our Inn *; I made up to him, and going in, ask'd him, what Acyltos had got us for Dinner? the Boy itting down on the Bed, began to wipe the Tears that tood in his Eyes; I was much concern'd at it, and ask'd him the occaion; he was low in his anwer, and eem'd unwilling; but mixing Threats with my Int •• aties; 'Twas that Brother or Comrogue of yours, aid he, that coming ere while into our Lodging, wou' • have been at me, and put hard for it: When I cry'd out, he drew his Sword, and if thou art a Lucr •••• , aid he, thou hat met a Tarquin.
I heard him, and h • king my Fit at Acyltos, what ait thou, aid I, thou Catamite, whoe very Breath is tainted?

He diembled at firt a great trembling, but preently throwing my Arms aide, in a higher Voice cry'd out, Mut you be prating, thou ribauldrous Cutthroat *, whom, condemn'd for murdring
thine Hot *, nothing but the fall of the Stage could have av'd? You make a noie, thou Night-Pad, who when at thy bet hadt never to do with any Woman but a Baw'd? On what account, think ye, was I the ame to you in the Aviary, that the Boy here, now is?

And who but you, interrupted I, gave me that lip in the Portico? Why what, my Man of Gotham, continu'd he, mut I have done, when I was dying for hunger? Hear Sentence forooth, that is, the ratling of broken Glaes, and the expounding of Dreams? So help me Hercules, as thou art the greater Rogue of the two, who to get a meals Meat wert not aham'd to commend an inipid Rhimer. When at lat, having turn'd the humour from Scolding to Laughing, we began to talk oberly.

But the late Injury till ticking in my Stomach, Acyltos, aid I, I find we hall never agree together, therefore let's divide the common Stock, and each of us et up for himelf: Thou'rt a piece of a Scholar, and I'll be no himdrance to thee, but think of ome other way; for otherwie we hall run into a thouand michiefs, and become Towntalk.
Acyltos was not againt it; And ince we have promis'd, aid he, as Scholars, to up together, let's husband the Night too; and to morrow I'll get me a new Lodging, and ome Comerade or other.

Tis irkome, aid I, to defer what we like, (the itch of the Fleh occaion'd this ha • ty parting, tho' I had been a long time willing to hake off o troubleome an oberver of my Actions, that I might renew my old Intrigue with my Gito.)

Acyltos taking it as an Affront, without anwering, went off in a heat: I was too well acquainted with his ubtle Nature, and the violence of his Love, not to fear the effects of o uddain a breach, and therefore made after him, both to oberve his Deigns and prevent them; but loing ight of him, was a long time in puruit to no purpoe.

When I had earch'd the whole Town, I return'd to my Lodging, where, the Ceremony of Ki • es ended, I got my Boy to a cloer hug, and, enjoying my wihes, thought my elf happy even to Envy: Nor had I done when Acyltos tole to the Door, and pringing the Bolt, found us at leap-Frog; upon which, clapping his Hands, he fell a laughing, and turning
me out of the Saddle; What, aid he, mot reverend Gentleman, what were you doing, my Brother Sterling? Nor content with Words only, but untying the Thong that bound his Wallet, he gave me a warning, and with other reproaches, As you like this, o be for parting again.

p.q: The unexpectednes of the thing made me take no notice of it, but politickly turn it off with a laugh; for otherwie I mut have been at Loggarheads with my Rival: Whereas weetening him with a counterfeit Mirth, I brought him alo to laugh for company: And you, E • colpius, began he, are o wrapt in Pleaures, you little conider how hort our Money grows, and what we have left will turn to no account: There's nothing to be got in Town this Summer-time, • e hall have better l • ck in the Country; let's viit our Friends.

Neceity made me approve his Advice, as well as conceal the mart of his Lah; o loading Gito with our Baggage, we left the City, and went to the Houe of one Ly • urgus, a Roman Knight; who, becaue Acyltos had formerly been his Pathick, entertain'd us handomly •
and the Company, we met there, made our Diverions the pleaanter: For, firt there was Tryphaena, a very beautiful Woman, that had come with one
• ycas, the owner of a Ship, and of a mall Seat, that lay next the Sea.

The Delight we receiv'd in this place was more than can be expret, tho' Lycurgus's Table was thrifty enough: The • irt thing was every one to chue his Play-Mate: The fair Tryphaena pleas'd me, and readily inclin'd to me; but I had carce given her the Courte • e of the Houe, when Lycas torming to have his old Amour lock • from him, accu • 'd me at firt of underdealing; but oon from a Rival addreing himelf as a Lover, he pleaantly told me, I mut repair his Damag • s, and ply'd me hotly: But Tryphaena having my Heart, I could not lend him an Ear. The refual et him the harper; he follow'd me where-ever I went, and getting into my Chamber at night, when Entreaty did no good, he fell to downright Violence; but I rais'd uch an out-cry that I wak'd the whole Houe, and, by the help of Lycurgus •
got rid of him for that bo • t.

At length perc • iving Lycurgus's Houe was not for his purpoe, he would have peruaded me to his own; but I rejecting the • ro ••• r, he made ue of Tryphaena's Au • hority • and he the rather peru • ded me to yield to him, becaue he was in hopes of living more at liberty there. I follow'd therefore whither my Love led me; but Lycurgus having renew'd his old Concern with Acyltos, wou'd not uffer him to depart: At lat we agreed, that he hou'd tay with Lycurgus, and we go with Lycas: Over and beide which, it was concluded, that every of us, as opportunity offer'd, hould pilfer what he could for the common Stock.
Lyc • s was ove • joy'd at my Conent, and o ha • n •• our departure, that, taking l • ave of our Friends, we arriv'd at his • ou • the ame Day.

But in our Paage he o order'd the matter that • e •• te next me, and Tryphaena next Gito, which he purpoely contriv'd to how the noto • ious Lightnes of that Woman; nor was he mitaken in her, for he preently grew hot upon the Boy: I was quickly • ealous, and Lyc • s o exactly remark'd it to me, that he oon confirm'd my upicion
of her. On this I began to be eaier to him, which made him all Joy, as being aur'd the Unworthines of my new Mitres wou'd beget my Contempt of her, and reenting her light, I hou'd receive him with the better will.

So tood the matter while we were at Lycas's: Tryphaena was deperately in love with Gito; Gito again as wholly devoted to her; I car'd leat for the ight of either of them; and Lycas tudying to pleae me, found me every day ome new Diverion: In all which alo his Wife Doris, a fine Woman, trove to exceed him, and that o gayly, that he preently thrut Tryphaena from my Heart: I gave her the Wink, and he return'd her Conent by as wanton a Twinckle; o that this dumb Rhetorick going before the Tongue, ecretly convey'd each others Mind.

I knew Lycas was jealous, which kept me Tongue-ty'd o long, and the love he bore his Wife made him dicover to her, his inclination to me: But the firt opportunity we had of talking together, he related to me what he had learn'd from him; and I frankly confes'd it, but withal told her how abolutely avere I had ever been to't:
Well then, quoth the dicreet Woman, we mut try our Wits, according to his own Opinion, the permiion was one's and the poeion anothers.

By this time Gito had been worn off his Legs, and was gathering new trength, when Tryphaena came back to me, but diappointed of her expectation, her Love turn'd to a downright Fury; and, all on fire with following me to no purpoe, got into my Intrigue both with Lycas and his Wife: She made no account of his gameomnes with me, as well knowing it wou'd hinder no Grit to her Mill: But for Doris, he never left till he had found out our private Amours, and gave a hint of it to Lycas; whoe Jealouie having got the upper hand of his Love, ran all to revenge; but Doris, advertis'd by Tryph • ena's Woman, to divert the Storm, forbore any more uch meetings.

As oon as I perceiv'd it, having curs'd the Treachery of Tryphaena, and the Ingratitude of Lycas, I began to make off, and Fortune favour'd me: For a Ship conecrated to the Goddes Iis, laden with rich Spoils, had the day before run upon the • ocks.

Gito and I laid our Heads together, and he was as willing as my elf to be gone; for Tryphaena having drawn him dry, began now not to be o fond of him. Early the next morning therefore we march'd to Sea-ward, where with the les difficulty we got on board the Ship, becaue we were no trangers to Lycas's Servants then in wait upon her: They till honouring us with their company, it was not a time to filch any thing; but, leaving Gito with them, I took an opportunity of getting into the Stern, where the Image of Iis tood, and trip'd her of a rich Mantle, and Silver Taber, lifting other good Booty out of the Mater's Cabin, I tole down by a Rope, uneen of any but Gito; who alo gave them the lip and culk'd after me.

div.p:
As oon as I aw him I hew'd him the Purchae, and both of us reolv'd to make what hate we could to Acyltos, but Lycurgus's Houe was not to be reach'd the ame day: When we came to Acyltos we hew'd him the Prize, and told him in hort the manner of getting it, and how we were made a meer may-game of Love: He advis'd us to prepoes Lycurgus with our Cae,
and make him our Friend • re the others could ee him; and withal boldly aert it, That the trick Lycas would have erved them, was the only caue why they tole away o hatily; which when Lycurgus came to undertand, he wore he would at all times protect us againt our Enemies.

Our flight was unknown till Tryphaena and Doris were got out of bed; for we daily attended their levy, and waited on them while they were dreing; but, when contrary to cutom they found us miing, Lycas ent after us, and epecially to the Sea-ide, for he had heard we made that way, but not a word of the Pillage, for the Ship lay omewhat to Sea-ward, and the Mater had not yet return'd on board.

But at lat it being taken for granted, we were run away, and Lycas becoming uneaie for want of us, fell deperately foul on his Wife, whom he uppos'd to be the caue of our departure: I'll take no notice of what Words and Blows pat between them; I know not every particular: I'll only ay, Tryphaena, the Mother of Michief, had put Lycas in the head, that it might o be, we had taken anctuary at Lycurgus's, where he peruaded
him to go in quet of the Runnagates, and promis'd to bear him company, that he might confound our Impudence with jut Reproaches.

The next day they accordingly et forward, and came to his Houe; but we were out of the way: For Lycurgus was gone to a Fetival in honour of Hercules, held at a neighbouring Village, and had taken us with him, of which when the others were inform'd, they made what hate they could to us, and met us in the Portico of the Temple. The ight of them very much diordered us: Lycas eagerly complained of our flight to Lycurgus, but was received with uch a bended Brow, and o haughty a Look, that I grew valiant upon't, and with an open Throat charg'd him with his beatly attempts upon me, as well at Lycurgus's as in his own Houe; and Tryphaena endeavouring to top my Mouth, had her hare with him, for I et out her Harlotry to the Mob, who were got about us to hear the colding: And as a proof of what I aid, I hew'd them poor aples Giton, and my elf alo, whom that itch of the Whore had even brought to our Graves.

The hout of the Mob put our Enemies o out of Countenance that they went off heavily, but contriving a revenge; and therefore oberving how we had put upon Lycurgus, they went back to expect him at his Houe, and et him right again. The Solemnity ending later than was expected, we could not reach Lycurgus's that Night, and therefore he brought us to a half-way Houe, but left us aleep next Morning, and went home to dipatch ome buines, where he found Lycas and Tryphaena waiting for him, who o ordered the matter with him, that they brought him to ecure us. Lycurgus naturally barbarous and faithles, began to contrive which way to betray us, and ent Lycas to get ome help, whilt he ecured us in the Village.

Thither he came, and at his firt entry, treated us as Lycas had done: After which wringing his Hands together, he upbraided us with the Lye we had made of Lycas, and taking Acyltos from us, lock'd us up in the Room where we were, without o much as hearing him peak in our defence; but carrying him to his Houe, et a Guard upon us, till himelf hould return.

On the Road Acyltos did what he could to mollifie Lycurgus; but neither Entreaties, nor Love, nor Tears doing any good on him, it came into our Comerades head to et us at liberty, and being all on fire at Lycurgus's retines, refus'd to bed with him that Night, and by that means the more eaily put in execution what he had been thinking on.

The Family was in their dead leep when Acyltos took our Fardels on his Shoulders, and getting through a breach in the Wall, which he had formerly taken notice of, came to the Village by break of Day, and meeting no one to top him, boldly enter'd it and came up to our Chamber; which the Guard that was upon us, took care to ecure; but the Bar being of Wood, he eaily wrenched it with an Iron Crow, and waken'd us; for we nor'd, in pight of Fortune.

Our Guard had o over-watched themelves, that they were fall'n into a dead leep, and we only wak'd at the Crack. To be hort, Acyltos came in and briefly told us what he had done for our akes: On this we got up; and as we were rigging our elves, it came into
my Head to kill the Guard, and rifle the Village; I told Acyltos my Mind: He liked the rifling well enough, but gave us a wih'd delivery without Blood, for being acquainted with every corner of the Houe, he pick'd the Lock of an Inner-Room where the Movables lay, and bringing us into it, we lifted what was of mot value, and got off while it was yet early in the Morning; avoiding the common Road, and not reting till we thought our elves out of danger.

Then Acyltos having gotten heart again, began to ampli • ie the Delight he took in having pillag'd Lycurgus; of whoe mierablenes he, nor without caue, complain'd; for he neither paid him for his Nights ervice, nor kept a Table that had either Meat, or Drink on't, being uch a ordid pintch-peny; that, notwithtanding his infinite Wealth, he deny'd himelf the common Necearies of Life.
div.l: Unhappy Tantalus, amidt the Flood,
Where floating Appl • on the urface roll'd,
Ever puru'd them with a longing Eye,
Yet could no • Thurt nor Hunger atisfie.
Such is the Mier's fate; who midt his tore,
Fearing to ue, is mierably poor.
div.p:
Acyltos would have been for Naples the ame day, had I not told him how imprudent it was to take up there, where, foramuch as could be conjectur'd, we were mot likely to be ought after: And therefore, aid I, let's keep out of the way for the preent, and, ince we have enough to keep us from want, troul it about till the Heat be over. The Advice was approv'd, and we et forward for a pleaant Country-Town, where we were ure to m • et ome of our Acquaintance that were taking the benefit of the Seaon: But we were carce got half way, when a hower of Rain emptying it elf upon us like Buckets, forc'd us into the next Village; w • ere entring the Inn, we aw a great many others that had alo truck in, to avoid the Storm. The throng kept us from being taken notice of, and gave us the opportunity of prying here and there, what we might • ilch in a Crowd, when Acyltos, unheeded of any one, took a Pure from the Ground, in which he found everal pieces of Gold; we leap'd for Joy at o fortunate a beginning;
but fearing, let ome or other might eek after it, we lunk out at a Back-door, where we aw a Groom Sadling his Hores; but, as having forgotten omewhat, he run into the Houe, leaving behind him an Embroider'd Mantle, mail'd to one of the Saddles: In his abence I cut the Straps, and under the covert of ome Out-heds, we made off with it to a neighbouring Foret.

Being more out of danger among the Thickets, we cat about where we hould hide the Gold, that we might not be either charg'd with the Felony, or robb'd of it our elves: At lat we concluded to ow it in the Lining of an old patcht Coat which I threw over my Shoulders, and entruted the care of the Mantle to Acyltos, in deign to get to the City by Cros-ways: But as we were going out, we heard omewhat on our left hand, to this purpoe: They hall not ecape us; they came into the Wood; let's eparate our elves and beat about, that we may the better dicover and take them. This put us into uch a fright, that Acyltos and Giton fled through Briars and Brambles to the City-ward; but I turn'd back again in uch a hurry, that without
perceiving it, the precious Coat drop'd from my Shoulders: At lat being quite tir'd, and not able to go any further, I laid me down under the helter of a Tree, where I firt mis'd the Coat: Then grief retor'd my trength, and up I got again to try if I could recover the Treaure; I ran hither and thither, and every where, but to no purpoe; but pent and wated between toil and heavines, I got into a Thicket, where having tarried four hours, and half dead with the horror of the place, I ought the way out; but going forward, a Country-man came in ight of me: Then I had need of all my Confidence, nor did it fail me: I went up roundly to him, and making my moan how I had lot my elf in the Wood, deir'd him tell me the way to the City: He pittying my Figure (for I was as pale as Death, and all bemir'd) ask'd me if I had een any one in the Wood? I anwered, not a Soul—on which he courteouly brought me into the Highway, where he met two of his Friends, who told him, they had travers'd the Wood thro' and thro', but had light upon nothing but a Coat, which they hew'd him.

It may eaily be believed I had not the courage to challenge it, tho' I knew well enough what the value of it was: This truck me more than all the ret; however, bewailing my Treaure, the Country-man not heeding me, and feeblenes growing upon me, I lacken'd my pace, and jogg'd on • lower than ordinarily.

It was longer e're I reach'd the City than I thought of; but coming to the Inn, I found Acyltos half dead, and tretcht on a Straw Pallet, and fell on another my • lf, not able to utter a word: He miing the Coat was in a great diorder, and ha • ily demanded of me, what was become of it: I on the other hand, carce able to draw my breath, reolv'd him by my languihing Eyes, what my To • g • e would not give me leave to peak: At length recovering by little and little, I plainly told him the ill luck I had met with: But he thought I jeted, and tho' the tears in my Eyes might have been as full Evidence to him as an Oath, he yet quetioned the truth of what I aid, and would not believe but I had a mind to cheat him. During this, Giton tood as troubled as my elf, and the Boy's
adnes increaed mine: But the freh Suit that was after us, ditracted me mot. I opened the whole to Acyltos, who eem'd little concern'd at it, as having luckily got off for the preent, and withal aur'd himelf, that we were pat danger, in that we were neither known, nor een by any one: However, it was thou • ht fit to pretend a Sicknes, that we might have the better pretext to keep where we were: But our Monies falling horter than we thought of, and Neceity enforcing us, we found it high time to ell ome of our Pillage.

It was almot dark, when going into the Brokers Market, we aw abundance of things to be bought and old: of no extraordinary value, 'tis true; yet uch whoe Night-walking Trade, the dusk of the Evening might eaily conceal. We alo had the Mantle with us, and taking the opportunity of a blind Corner, fell a haking the Skirt of it, to try if o glittering a Shew would bring us a Purchaer; nor had we been long there, e're a certain Country-man, whom I thought I had een before, came up to us with a Huye that follow'd him, and began to conider the Mantle more
narrowly, as on the other ide did Acyltos our Country Chapman's Shoulders, which preently tartled him, and truck him Dumb, nor could my elf behold • em without being concern'd at it, for he eemed to me to be the ame Fellow that had found the Coat in the Wood, as in truth he was: But Acyltos doubting whether he might trut his Eyes or not, and that he might not do any thing rahly, firt came nearer to him as a Buyer, and taking the Coat from his Shoulders, began to cheapen, and turn it more carefully. O the wonderful vagaries of Fortune! for the Country-man had not o much as examined a Seam of it, but carelely expoed it as Beggars-booty.

p.U: eeing the Coat unript, and the Peron of the Seller contemptible, took me aide from the Crowd: And don't you ee Brother, aid he, the treaure I made uch moan about is returned? That's the Coat with the Gold in't, all afe and untoucht: What therefore do we do, or what coure hall we take to get our own again?

div.p:
I now comforted, not o much that I had een the Booty, but had clear'd my elf of the Supicion that lay upon me,
was by no means for going about the Buh, but down right bringing an Action againt him, That if the Fellow would not give up the Coat to the right owner, we might recover it by Law;
div.l: The Caue is bad when e'er the Client's Poor:
Thoe trickt liv'd Men that eem above our World
Are oft too modet to reit our Gold.
So Judgment, like our other Wares, is old;
And the grave Knight that nods upon the Laws,
Wak'd by a Fee, Hems, and approves the Caue.
div.p: Acyltos on the other ide afraid of the Law, who, aid he, knows us in this place, or will give any credit to what we ay? I am clear for buying it, tho' we know it to be our own, and rather recover the Treaure with a little Money, than embroil our elves in an uncertain Suit; but we had not above a couple of Groats ready Money, and that we deign'd hould buy us omewhat to eat. Leat therefore the Coat hould be gone in the mean time, we agreed, rather than fail, to ell the Mantle at a lower price, that the Advantage we got by the one, might make what we lot by the other more eaie.

Aoon therefore as we had pread open the Mantle, the Woman that tood muffled by the Countryman, having pryingly taken notice of ome tokens about it, forceably laid both hands on't, and etting up her Throat, cryed out, Thieves, Thieves!

We on t'other part being diordered at it, let yet he might eem to do nothing, got hold of the totter'd Coat, and as pitefully roar'd, they had robb'd us of it: But our cae was in no wie like theirs, and the Rabble that came in to the out-cry, ridicul'd, as they were wont, the weaker ide, in that the others made claim to o rich a Mantle, and we to a ragged Coat, carce worth a good Patch. At this Acyltos could hardly keep his Countenance; but the noie being over, We ee, aid he, how every one likes his own bet, Give us our Coat, and let them take the Mantle.

The Countryman and the Woman lik'd the exchange well enough, but a ort of Petty-Foggers, mot of whoe buines was uch Night Practice, having a mind to get the Mantle themelves, as importunately required, that both Mantle and Co • t hould be left
in their hands, and the Judge would hear their complaints on the Morrow: For it was not the things alone that eem'd to be in dipute, but quite another matter to be enquir'd into, to wit, a trong upicion of Robbery on both ides.

At lat it was agreed to put both into ome indifferent hand, till the right were determined; when preently one, I know not who, with a bald Pate, and a Face full of Pimples, he had been formerly a kind of Solicitor, teps out of the Rout, and laying hold on the Mantle, aid he'd be Security it hould be forth-coming the next day: when in truth he intended nothing more, but that having gotten it into Huckters hands, it might be mugled among them, as believing we would never come to own it, for fear of being taken up for it; for our part we were as willing as he; and an Accident befriended both of us: For the Country-man thinking corn of it, that we demanded to have the patcht Coat given us, threw it at Acyltos's Head, and dicharging us of every thing but the Mantle, required that to be ecur'd as the only caue of the Dipute. Having
therefore recovered, as we thought, our Treaure, we made all the hate we could to the Inn, and having hut the Door upon us, made our elves Merry, as well with the judgment of the Rabble as of our Detracters, who with o much circumpection had retor'd us our Money.

While we were ripping the Coat and taking out the Gold, we overheard omebody asking mine Hot, what kind of People thoe were that had jut now come in, and being tartled at it, I went down to ee what was the matter, and undertood that a City Serjeant, who according to the duty of his Office, took an account of all Strangers, and had een a couple come into the Inn, whoe Names he had not yet Regitred, and therefore inquired of what Country they were, and what way of living they had.

But mine Hot gave me uch a blind Account of it, that I began to • pect we were not afe there; whereupon for fear of being taken up, we thought fit to go off for the preent, and not come back again till it was more in the Night, but leave the care of our Supper to Gito.

We had reolv'd to keep out of the Broad Streets, and accordingly took our Walk thro' that quarter of the City where we were likely to meet leat Company; when in a narrow winding Lane that had not Paage thro', we aw omewhat before us, two comely Matron-like Women, and followed them at a ditance to a Chappel, which they entred, whence we heard an odd humming kind of Noie, as if it came from the hollow of a Cave: Curioity alo made us go in after them, where we aw a number of Women, as mad as they had been, Sacrificing to Bacchus, and each of them an Amulet (the Enign of Priapus) in her Hand. More than that, we could not get to ee; for they no ooner perceived us, than they et up uch a Shout, that the Roof of the Temple hook agen, and witha • endeavoured to lay Hands on us; but we camper'd and made what hate we could to the Inn.

Nor had we ooner tuff'd our elves with the Supper Gito had got for us, when a more than ordinary Bounce at the Door, put us into another fright; and when we, pale as Death, ask'd who who was there, 'twas anwer'd, Open
the Door and you'll ee: While we were yet talking, the Bolt drop'd off, and the Door flew open, on which, a Woman with her Head muffl'd came in upon us, but the ame who a little before had tood by the Country-man in the Market: And what, aid he, do you think to put a Trick upon me? I am Quartilla's Maid, whoe Sacred reces you o lately diturb'd: She is at the Inngate, and deires to peak with ye: not that he either taxes your Inadvertency, or has a mind to o reent it, but rather wonders, what God brought uch Civil Gentlemen into her Quarters.

We were ilent as yet, and gave her the hearing, but inclin'd to neither part of what he had aid, when in came Quartilla her elf, attended with a young Girl, and itting down by me, fell a weeping: nor here alo did we offer a word, but tood expecting what thoe Tears at command meant. At lat when the Showre had emptied it elf, he didainfully turn'd up her Hood, and clinching her Fingers together, till the Joints were ready to crack, what Impudence, aid he, is this? or where learnt ye thoe Shamms, and that light of Hand ye have o lately been beholding
to? By my Faith, Young-men, I am •• rry for ye; for no one beheld wha • was unlawful for him to ee, and went off unpuniht: and verily our part of the Town has o many Deities, you'l ooner find a God than a Man in't: And that you may not think I came hither to be revenged on ye, I am more conce • n'd for your Youth, than the Injury ye have done me: for unawares, as I yet think, ye have committed an inexpiable abomination.

For my part it troubled me all Night, and threw me into uch a haking, that I was afraid I had gotten a Tertian, on which I took omewhat to have made me leep; but the God appeared to me, and commanded me to rie and find ye out, as the likeliet way to take off the violence of the Fit. But I am not o much in pain for a remedy, as that a greater anguih trikes me to the heart, and will undoubtedly make an end of me, for fear in one of your Youthful Frolicks, you hould dicloe what you aw in Priapus's Chappel, and utter the Counels of the Gods among the People. Low as your Knees, I therefore lift my Hands t'ye, that ye neither make Sport of our Night-worhip, nor
dihonour the Myteries of o many Years, which, 'tis not every one, even among our elves, that knows.

After this he fell a crying again, and with many a pittiful groan, fell flat on my Bed: when I at the ame time, between pity and fear, bid her take courage and aure her elf of both; for that we would neither divulge thoe holy Myteries; nor if the God had precrib'd her any other remedy for her Ague, be wanting our elves to ait Providence, even with our own hazard.

At this Promie of mine, becoming more chearful, he fell a kiing me thick and threefold, and turning the humour of Tears into Laughing, he comb'd up ome Hair that hung over my Face with her Fingers, and I come to a Truce with ye, aid he, and dicharge ye of the Proces I intended againt you: but if ye hou'd refue me the Medicine I intreat of ye for the Ague, I have Fellows enough will be ready by to Morrow, that hall both vindicate my Reputation, and revenge the Affront ye put upon me.
div.l: Contempt's dihono'rable, and the Giver rude,
T' advie the Doctor, peaks the patient proud:
But I am Mitres of my elf o far,
I can pay corn with corn without a War:
The wie revenge is to neglect the ill,
They're not the only Conquerours that Kill.
div.p: Then clapping her Hands together, he turn'd off to o violent a Laughter, that made us apprehenive of ome deigns againt us; the ame alo did the Woman that came in firt, and the Girl that came with her; but o mimically, that eeing no reaon for o udden a change, we one while tar'd on one another, and otherwhile on the Woman.
At length, quoth Quartilla, I have commanded, That no fleh alive be uffered to come into this Inn to day; that I may receive from you the Medicine for the Ague without interruption.

At what time A • yltos was a little amaz'd, and I o chill'd, that I had not power to utter a word: But the Company gave me heart not to expect wore, for they were but three Women • and if they had any deign, mut yet be too weak to effect it againt us, who if we had nothing more of Man about us, had yet that Figure to befriend us:
We were all girt up for the purpoe, and I had o contriv'd the Couples, that if it mut come to a Rancounter, I was to make my part good with Quartilla, Acyltos with her Woman, and Gito the Girl.

While I was thus cating the matter in my Head, Quartilla came up to me, to cure her of her Ague, but finding her elf diappointed, flew off in a rage, and returning in a little while, told us, there were certain Perons unknown, had a deign upon us, and therefore commanded to remove us into a Noble Palace.
Here all our Courage fail'd us, and nothing but certain Death eem'd to appear before us.

When I began, If, Madam, you deign to be more evere with us, be yet o kind as to dipatch it quickly; for whatever our offence be, it is not o hainous that we ought to be rack'd to death for it: Upon which her Woman, whoe Name was Pyche, pread a Coverlet on the Floor, and fell examining the Linings of my Breeches, but her labour was lot, all was cold and dead. Acyltos muffled his Head in his Coat, as having had a hint given him, how dangerous it was to take notice of what
did not concern him: In the mean time Pyche took off her Garters, and with the one of them bound my Feet, and with the other my Hands.

Thus fetter'd as I lay, This, Madam, aid I, is not the way to rid you of your Ague: I grant it, anwer'd Pyche, but I have a Doe at hand will infallibly do it; and therewith brought me a luty Bowl of Satyrion. (a Love-Potion) and o merrily ran over the wonderful effects of it, that I had well-nigh uck'd it all off: But becaue Acyltos had lighted her Courthip, he finding his Back towards her, threw the bottom of it on him.

Acyltos perceiving the Chat was at an end, Am not I worthy, aid he, to get a Sup? And Pyche fearing my Laughter might dicover her, clapped her Hands, and told him, Young-man I made you an offer of it, but your Friend here has drunk it all out.

Is it o, quoth Quartilla, miling very agreeably, and has Encolpius gugg'd it all down? At lat alo even Gito laught for Company, at what time the young Wench flung her Arms about his Neck, and meeting no reitance, half mother'd him with Kies.

We would have cry'd out, but there was no one near to help us; and as I was offering to bid 'em keep the Peace, Pyche fell a nipping and pricking me with her Bodkin: On the other ide • alo, the young Wench half tifled Acyltos with a Dih-clout he had rubb'd in the Bowl.

Latly came leaping upon us a Burdah, in a rough Mantle tuck with Myrtle, girt about him; and one while almot ground our Hipps to Powder with his bobbing at us, and other-while lobber'd us with his naty Kies; till Quartilla, holding her Staff of Office in her Hand, dicharg'd us of the Service; but not without having firt taken an Oath of us, that o dreadful a Secret hould go no further than our elves. Then came in a company of Wretlers, and rubb'd us over with the Yelk of an Egg beaten to Oil: When being omewhat refreh'd, we put on our Night Gowns, and were led into the next Room, that had three Beds in it, all well appointed, and the ret of the entertainment as plendidly et out. The word was given, and we ate down, when having whet our appetites with an excellent Antipat, we will'd our
elves with the choicet of Wine; nor was it long e'er we fell a nodding. It is o, quoth Quartilla; can ye leep when ye know it is the Vigil to Priapus? at what time Acyltos nor'd o oundly, that Pyche, not y • t forgeting the diapointment, he gave her, all beooted his Face, and cor'd down his Shoulders with a burnt Sticks end.

Plagu'd with thee michiefs, I hardly got the leat wink of Sleep, nor was the whole Family, whether within doors or without, in a much better condition; ome lay up and down at our Feet, others had run their Heads againt the Walls, and others lay dead aleep cros the Threhold: The Lamps alo having drunk up their Oil, gave a thin and lat blaze. At this intant got in a couple of pilfering Rogues to have tollen our Wine; but while they fell a cuffling among ome Silver Veels that tood upon the Table, they broke the Earthen Pot that held the Wine, and overthrew the Table, with the Plate on it, and at the ame time alo, a Cup falling off the Shelf on Pyche's Bed, broke her Head as he lay fat aleep; on which he cry'd out, and therewith dicovered the Thieves,
and wak'd ome of the Drunkards: The Thieves on the other hand finding themelves in a Pound, threw themelves on one of the Beds, as ome of the Guets, and fell a noring like the ret. The Uher of the Hall being by this time got awake, put more Oil in the dying Lamps; and the Boys, having rubb'd their Eyes, return'd to their charge, when in came a Woman that play'd on the Harp, and ratling its Strings, rous'd all the ret: On which the Banquet was renew'd, and Quartilla gave the Word, to go on where we left (that is, Drinking:) The She Harper alo added not a little to our Midnight Revel.

At lat bolted in a hameles Racal, one of no Grace either in Words or Geture, and truly worthy of the Houe where he was; he alo et up his noice, 'till apihly compoing himelf, as if he intended omewhat to the Company, he mouth'd out thee Veres;
div.l: O Yes! Now Tumblers with your wanton Tricks,
Make hat, move your Legs quick, make the Ground drum;
With wanton Arms, oft Thighs, and active Hips,
The Old, the Tender, and the weetly Young.
div.p: Having done with his Poetry, he mear'd my Lips with a naty Kis; then getting on our Bed, tugg'd toutly to have turn'd up our Night-Gowns: Long and hard he kept goring at me, but all to no purpoe. Great drops of Paint hung like Gum on his Forehead, and came trickling down the wrinkles of his Cheeks like Rain on a naked Wall. Nor could I forbear Tears any longer, but being brought to the lat extremity, I beeech you Madam, quoth I, ure you have commanded to have us tifled with Kies.

When gently clapping her Hands together, O Man of Wit, aid he, and very original of pleaant Railery! what, don't you know a Pathick is ever a drivelling Kier? And therefore that my Companion might not cape better than my elf, By your Integrity, Madam, quoth I, does Acyltos alone keep Holy-day among us.

Is it o, aid he, even let him have his hare too: And therewith the Racal chang'd his Hore, and turning off to Acyltos, almot bray'd him to pieces with kiing and bobbing him. Gito
tood laughing all the while, 'till he had well-nigh plit himelf; which Quartilla perceiving, diligently enquired whoe Boy he was, and I telling her he was my Comrade, why then, aid he, has he not kit me? and o calling him to her, fell at it roundly; and making a flourih with his Quarter-Pike, this, quoth he, may do well enough for a Fore-Skirmih, and get me an appetite to morrow; but having made o full a Meal already, it is not my way to put a Churle upon a Gentleman. With that Pyche came tittering to her, and having whipered I know not what in her Ear, Thou art in the right, quoth Quartilla, 'twas well thought on; and ince we have o fine an opportunity, why hould not our Pannychis loe her Maidenhead? And forthwith was brought in a pretty young Girl, that eem'd not to be above Seven Years of Age, and was the ame that firt came into our Room with Quartilla: All approv'd it with a general Clap, and next deiring it, a Wedding was truck up between the Boy and her. For my part I tood amaz'd, and aur'd them, That neither Gito, a bahful Lad, was able for the
drudgery, nor the Girl of years to receive it. Is that all, quoth Quartilla? Is he les than I was when I firt entred on't? A Pox on my Nanny if I remember I ever was a Maid; for when I was yet a little one, I went to CreepMoue with little Boys; and as I grew in Years, I put forwards to bigger, 'till I came to the age you ee; and truly I think hence came the Proverb:
She'll bare him a Bull that bore him a Calf.
Leat therefore my Comrade might run a greater hazard, I got up to the Wedding.

And now Pyche put a flame-colour Veil on the Girles Head; the Pathick led before with a Flambo • , and a long Train of drunken Women, fell a houting, and dret up the Bride-Chamber; Quartilla all a-gog as the ret, took hold of Gito, and dragg'd him in with her: But truly the Boy made no reitance; nor eem'd the Girl frighted at the name of Matrimony. When therefore they were lockt up, we at without, before the Threhold of the Chamber; and Quartilla having waggihly lit a Chink thro' the Door, as wantonly laid
an Ape's Eye to it; nor content with that, pluck't me alo to ee that Childs play, and when we were not peeping, would turn her Lips to me, and teal a Kis.

The Jade's fulomnes had o tir'd me that I began to devie which way to get off. I told Acyltos my mind, and he was well pleaed with it, for he was as willing to get rid of his torment, Pyche: Nor was it hard to be done, if Gito had not been lockt up in the Chamber; for we were reolved to take him with us, and not leave him to the mercy of a Bawdy-houe. While we were contriving how to effect it, it o happened that Pannychis fell out of Bed, and drew Gito after her, without any hurt, though the Girl got a mall Knock in the fall, and therewith made uch a Cry, that Quartilla, all in a fright, ran headlong in, and gave us the opportunity of getting off, and taking the Boy with us; when without more ado, we flew to our Inn, and getting to Bed, pat the ret of the Night without fear.

But going out the next day, whom hould we meet but two of thoe Fellows that robb'd us of the Mantle, which Acyltos
perceiving, he briskly attack'd one of them, and having diarm'd and deparat • ly wounded him, came in to my relief; who was preing hard upon the other, but he behav'd himelf o well, that he wounded us both, altho' but lightly, and got off himelf without o much as a Scratch.

And now came the third day, that is the expectation of an Entertainment at Trimalchio's, where every one might peak what he would: But having received ome Wounds, we thought flight might be of more ue to us than itting till: We got to our Inn therefore, as fat as we could, and our Wounds not being great, cured them as we lay in Bed, with Wine and Oyl.

But the Rogue whom Acyltos had hewn down, lay in the Street, and we were in fear of being dicovered, while therefore we were penively conidering which way to avoid the impending Storm, a Servant of Agamemnon's interrupted our fears: And do not ye know, aid he, with whom we eat to day? Trimalchio, a trim finical Humorit has a Clock in his Dining-Room, and one on purpoe to let him know how many Minutes of his Life he had
lot. We therefore dret our elves carefully, and Gito willingly taking upon him the part of a Servant, as he had hither to done, we bad him put our things together, and follow us to the Bath.

Being in the mean time got ready, we walk'd we knew not where, or rather having a mind to divert us, truck into a Tennis-Court, where we aw an old Bald-pated Fellow in a Carnationcolour'd Coat, playing at Ball with a company of Boys; nor was it o much the Boys, tho' it was worth our while, that engaged us to be lookers on as the Mater of the Houe himelf in Pumps, who altogether toed the Ball, and never truck it after it once came to the Ground, but had a Servant by him with a Bag full of them, and enough for all that play'd.

We oberved alo everal new things; for in the Gallery tood two Eunuchs, one of whom held a Silver Chamber-pot, the other counted the Balls, not thoe they kept toing • but uch as fell to the Ground. While we admir'd the Humour, one Menelaus came up to us, and told us we were come where we mut et up for the Night, and that we had
een the beginning of our Entertainment. As he was yet talking, Trimalchio napp'd his Fingers, at which ign the Eunuch held the Chamber-pot to him as he was playing; then calling for Water, be dipped the tips of his Fingers in it, and dry'd them on the Boys Head. 'Twould be too long to recount every thing: We went into the Hot-houe, and having weated a little, into the Cold Bath; and while Trimalchio was anointed from Head to Foot with a liquid Perfume, and rubb'd clean again, not with Linnen but the finet Flannen, his Three Chyrurgeons ply'd the Mucadine, but brawling over their Cups; Trimalchio aid it was his turn to drink; then wrapt in a Scarlet Mantle, he was laid on a Litter born by Six Servants, with Four Lacqueys in rich Liveries running before him, and by his ide a Sedan, in which was carried his Darling, a tale bleer eyed Catamite, more Illfavoured than his Mater Tremalchio; who as they went on, kept cloe to his Ear with a Flagellet, as if he had whipered him, and made him muick all the way. Wondering, we followed, and, with Agamemnon, came to the Gate, on which hung a Tablet with this this Incription:
WHAT EVER SERVANT GOES FORTH WITHOUT HIS MASTER'S COMMAND, HE SHALL RECEIVE AN HUNDRED STRIPES.

In the Porch tood the Porter in a Green Livery, girt about with a Cherry-coloured Girdle, garbling of Peae in a Silver Charger; and over head hung a Golden Cage with a Magpye in it, which gave us an All Hail as we entred: But while I was gaping at thee things, I had like to have b • oken my Neck backward, for on the left hand, not far from the Porter's Lodge, there was a great Dog in a Chain painted on the Wall, and over him written in Capital Letters, BEWARE THE DOG. My Companions could not forbear laughing; but I recollecting my Spirits, purued my deign of going to the end of the Wall; it was the draught of a Market-place where Slaves were bought and old with Bills over them: There was alo Trimalchio with a white Staff in his Hand, and Min • rva with a Train after her entring Rome: Then having learnt how to cat Accompt, he was made Auditor; all exquiitely painted with their
proper Titles; and at the end of the Gallery Mercury lifting him by the Chin, and placing him on a Judgment-Sea • . Fortune tood by him with a Cornucopia, and the Three fatal Siters winding a Golden Thread.

I oberved alo in the ame place a Troop of Light • horemen, with their Commander Exerciing them; as alo a large Armory, in one of the Angles of which tood a Shrine with the Gods of the Houe in Silver, a Marble Statue of Venus, and a large Golden Box, in which it was aid he kept the firt Shavings of his Beard. Then asking the Servant that had the charge of thee things, What Pictures thoe were in the middle? The Iliads and the Odyes, aid he, and on the left hand two pectacles of Swordplaying. We could not betow much time on i • , for by this time we were come to the Dining • Room, in the entry of which ate his Steward, taking every ones Account: But what I mot admir'd, were thoe bundles of Rods, with their Axes, that were fatned to the ides of the Door, and tood, as it were, on the Brazen Prow of a Ship, on which was written,
TO CAIUS POMPEIUS TRIMALCHIO OF PRAETORIAN DIGNITY; CINNAMUS THE STEWARD.
Under the ame Title alo, hung a Lamp of two Lights from the Roof of the Room, and two Tablets on either ide of the Door; of which one, if I well remember, had this Incription,
THE THIRD AND SECOND OF THE KALENDS OF JANUARY, OUR PATRON CAIUS EATS ABROAD.
On the other was repreented the Coure of the Moon, and the even Stars; and what Days were Lucky, what Unlucky, with an Embos'd Studd to ditinguih the one from the other.

Full of this Senuality we were now entring the Room, where one of his Boys, et there for that purpoe, call'd aloud to us, ADVANCE ORDERLY. Nor is it to be doubted, but we were omewhat concern'd for fear of breaking the Orders of the place. But while we were footing it accordingly, a Servant
tript off his Livery, fell at our Feet, and beought us to ave him a Whipping; for he aid his Fault was no great matter, but that ome Cloaths of the Stewards had been toln from him in the Bath, and all of them not worth Eighteen-pence.

We returned therefore in good Order, and finding the Steward in the Counting-Houe telling ome Gold, beought him to remit the Servant's punihment: When putting on an haughty Face, It is not, aid he, the los of the thing troubles me, but the Negligence of a car • l • s Ra • al. He has lot me the Garments I ••• at Table in • and which a Cli • nt of • ine preent • d me on my Birth-day; no Man can deny them to be right Purple, tho' not double Dye; yet wha • ev • r it be, I grant your Requet.

Having receiv'd o great a Favour, as we were entring the Dining • Room, the Servant for whom we had been Suitors, met us, and kiing us, who tood wondring what the Humour meant, over and over gave us thanks for our Civility; and in hort, told us we hould know by and by, whom it was we had oblig'd: The Wine which our Mater keeps for his own drinking, is the Waiters kindnes.

At length we ate down, when a bigger and prucer ort of Boys coming about us, ome of them poured Snowwater on our Heads, and others par • d the Nails of our Feet, with a mighty dexterity, and that not ilently, but Singing as it were by the bye: I reolved to try if the whole Family Sang; and therefore called for Drink, which one of the Boys as readily brought me with an odd kind of Tune; and the ame did every one as you asked for any thing: You'd have taken it for a Morris dancers Hall, not the Table of a Peron of Quality.

Then came in a umptuo • s Antepat; for we were all eated, but only Trimalchio, for whom, after a new fahion, the chief Place was reerv'd. Beides that, as a part of the Entertainment, there was • t by us a large Veel of Metheglin, with a Pannier, in the one part of which were whit • Olives, in the other black; two broad Platters covered the Veel, on the brims of which were Engraven Trimalchio's Name, and the weight of the Silver, with little Bridges oldered together, and on them Dormice, trew'd over with Honey and Poppy: There were
alo piping-hot Sauages on a Silver Gridiron, and under that large Damons, with the Kernels of Pomegranats.

In this Condition were we when Trimalchio himelf was waddled into the Conort; and being cloe bolter'd with Neck-cloaths and Pillows to keep off the Air, we could not forbear laughing unawares: For his bald Pate peep'd out of a Scarlet Mantle, and over the load of Cloaths he lay under, there hung an Embroidered Towel, with Purple Taels and Fringes dingle dangle about it: He had alo on the little Finger of his left Hand, a large Gilt Ring, and on the outmot Joint of the Finger next it, one leer, which I took for all Gold; but at lat it appeared to be Jointed together with a kind of Stars of Steel: And that we might ee thee were not all his Bravery, he tripp'd his right Arm, on which he wore a Golden Bracelet, and an Ivory Circle, bound together with a glittering Locket, and a Meddal at the end of it: Then picking his Teeth with a Silver Pin, I had not, my Friends, aid he, any inclination to have come among you o oon, but fearing my abence might make you wait too long, I deny'd my elf my
own atisfaction; however uffer me to make an end of my Game: There followed him a Boy with an Inlaid Table and Chrital Dice; and I took notice of one thing more pleaant than the ret; for intead of black and white Counters, his were all Silver and Gold pieces of Money.

In the mean time while he was quandring his Heap at Play, and we were yet picking a Relih here and there, a Cupboard was brought in with a Basket, in which was a Hen Carved in Wood, her Wings lying round and hollow, as itting on Brood; when preently the Conort truck up, and two Servants fell a earching the Straw under her, and taking out ome Peahens Eggs, ditributed them among the Company: At this Trimalchio changing Countenance, I commanded my Friends, aid he, the Hen to be et with Peahens Eggs; and o help me Hercules, am affraid they may be half Hatcht: however we'll try if they are yet Suppable.

The thing we received was a kind of Shell of at leat Six Pound weight, made of Pate, and moulded into the Figure of an Egg, which we eaily broke; and for my part, I was like to have thrown away
my hare; for it eemed to me to have a Chick in it; till hearing an old Guet of the Tables aying, It was ome good Bit or other, I earched further into it, and found a delicate fat Wheatear in the middle of a well-pepper'd Yolk: On this Trimalchio topped his Play for a while, and requiring the like for himelf, proclaim'd, If any of us would have any more Metheglin, he was at liberty to take it; when of a udden the Muick gave the Sign, and the firt Coure was crabled away by a Company of Singers and Dancers; but in the Rutle it happening that a Dih fell on the Floor, a Boy took it up, and Trimalchio taking notice of it, pluck'd him by the Ears, and commanded him to throw it down again; on which the Groom of the Chamber came with a Broom and wept away the Silver Dih, with whatever ele had fallen from the Table.

When preently came in two longhair'd Blacks, with mall Leather Bottles, uch as with which they trew Sand on the Stage, and gave us Wine to wah our Hands, but no one offered us Water. We all admiring the Finicalnes of the Entertainment, Mars, aid he, is a
lover of Jutice, and therefore let every one have a Table to himelf, for having more Elbow-room, thee naty tinking Boys will be les troubleome to us; and thereupon large double-Ear'd Veels of Glas cloe Plaitered over, were brought up with Labels about their Necks, upon which was this Incription:
OPIMIAN MUSCADINE OF AN HUNDRED YEARS OLD.

While we were reading the Titles, Trimalchio clapped his Hands, and Alas, alas, aid he, that Wine hould live longer than Man! Wine is Life, and we'll try if it has held good ever ince the Conulhip of Lucius Opimius, or not: 'Tis right Opimian, and therefore make ready; I brought not out o good Yeterday, yet there were Perons of better Quality Sup'd with me.

We drank and admired every thing, when in came a Servant with a Silver Puppet, o Jointed and put together, that it turned every way; and being more than once thrown upon the Table, cat it elf into everal Figures; on which Trimalchio came out with his Poetry:
div.l: Unhappy Mortals, on how fine a Thread
Our Lives depend! How like this Puppet Man,
Shall we, alas! b • all when we are dead!
Therefore let's live Merrily while we can.
div.p:
The Applaue we gave him, was followed with a Service, but repecting the place not o coniderable as might have been expected: However, the Novelty of the thing drew every Man's Eye, upon it; it was a large Charger, with the twelve Signs round it; upon every one of which the Mater Cook had laid omewhat or other uitable to the Sign: Upon Aries, ChickPeae, (a Pule not unlike a Rams-head) upon Taurus a piece of Beef; upon Gemini a pair of Pendulums and Kidneys: upon Cancer a Coronet; upon Leo an African Figg; upon Virgo a well-grown Boy; upon Libra a pair of Scales, in one of which was a Tart, in the other a Cutard: upon Scorpio a Pilchard; upon Sagittary a Grey-hound; upon Capricorn a Lobter; upon Aquarius a Gooe; upon Pices two Mullets, and in the middle a Plat of Herbs, cut out like a green Turf, and over them an Honey-comb. During this, a leer
Black carry'd about Bread in a Silver Oven, and with a hideous Voice, forced a Bawdy Song from a Buffoon that tunk like Aa Faetida.
When Trimalchio perceived we look'd omewhat awkardly on uch coure Fare, Come, come, aid he, fall to and Eat, this is the Cutom of the place.

Nor had he ooner aid it, then the fourth Conort truck up; at which the Waiters fell a Dancing, and took off the upper part of the Charger, under which was a Dih of cramm'd Fowl, and the hinder Paps of a Sow that had Farrowed but a day before, well Powdered, and in the middle a Hare, tuck in with Finns of Fih in his ide, that he look'd like a Flying Hore; and on the ides of the Fih four little Images, that pouted a relihing Sauce on ome Fih that lay near them, all of them brought from the River Euripus.

We alo econded the Shout begun by the Family, and fell merrily aboard this; and Trimalchio no les pleas'd than our elves, cryed Cut; at which the Muick ounding again, the Carver humour'd it, and cut up the Meat with uch Antick Potures, you'd have thought him a Car-man fighting to an Organ.

Nevertheles Trimalchio in a lower Note, cryed out again Cut: I hearing the word o often repeated, upecting there might be ome Joke in it, was not ahamed to ask him that at next above me, what it meant? And he that had been often preent at the like, You ee, aid he, him that Carves about, his Name is Cutter; and as often as he ays Cut, he both Calls and Commands.

The Humour poiled my Stomach for eating; but turning to him that I might learn more, I made ome pleaant Dicoure to him at a ditance; and at lat asked him what that Woman was that o often culted up and down the Room.

It is, aid he, Trimalchio's Wife, her Name Fortunata, he meaures Money by the Buhel; but what was he not long ince? Pardon me Sir, you would not have touch'd her with a pair of Tongs, but now, no one knows how or wherefore, he's got into Heaven; and is Trimalchio's all in all: In hort, if he ays it is Mid-night at Mid-day, he'll believe her. He's o very Wealthy, he knows not what he has; but he has an Eye every where; and when you
leat think to meet her, you'll have her: She's void of all Good Counel, and withal of an ill Tongue; a very Pye at his Bolter; whom he Loves he Loves; and whom he does not Love, he does not Love.

Then for Trimalchio, he has more Lands than a Crow can • ly over; Monies upon Monies: There lies more Silver in his Porters Lodge, than any one Man's whole Etate. And for his Family, Hey-day, hey-day, there is not (o help me Hercules) one tenth of them that know their Mater. In brief, there is not one of thoe Fools about him, but he can turn him into a Cabbage-talk: Nor is there any occaion to Buy any thing, he has all at his own Door; Wooll, Marte • P • pper, nay Hens Milk; do but beat about and you'll find it. In a word, time was, his Wooll was none of the bet, and therefore he bought Rams at Tarentum to mend this Breed; as in like manner he did by his Honey, by bringing his Bees from Athens. It is not long ince but he ent to the Indies for Muhroom-Seed: Nor has he o mu • h as a Mule that did not come of a Wild As. S • e you all thee Quilts? there is not one of them whoe
Wadding is not the finet Comb'd Wooll of Violet or Scarlet Colour, Dy'd in Grain. O happy Man! but have a care how you put a light on thoe Freed Men, they are Rich Rogues: See you him that its at the lower-end of the Table, he has now the Lord knows what; and 'tis not long ince he was not worth a Groat, and carried Billets and Faggots at his Back: It is aid, but I know nothing of it my elf, but as I have heard, either he got in with an old Hog-grubbler, or had to do with an Incubus, and found a Treaure: For my part, I envy no Man, (if God gives any thing it is a Bit and a Blow, and wills no Evil to himelf) he lately et up this Proclamation:
C. POMPEIUS DIOGENES HAS SOME LODGINGS TO LET, FOR HE HATH BOUGHT A HOUSE.

But what think you of him who its in the place of a late Slave? how well was he once? I do not upbraid him: He was once worth a Hundred Thouand Setertias, but has not now a Hair of his Head that is not Engaged; nor,
o help me Hercules, is it his own fault: There is not a better humour'd Man than himelf; but thoe Racally Freedmen have cheated him of all: For know, when the Pot boyls, and a Man's Etate declines, farewel Friends. And what Trade do you think he drove? He had the etting forth of Grave Men's Funerals; and with that Eat like a Prince: He had his Wild Boars erved up covered; Patry • Meats, Fowl-Cooks, Bakers: More Wine was thrown under his Table, than mot Men have in their Cellars; a meer Phantam: And when his Etate was going, and he fear'd his Creditors might fall upon him, he made an Auction under this Title:
JULIUS PROCULUS WILL MAKE AN AUCTION OF SEVERAL GOODS HE HAS NO USE OF.

The Dih was by this time taken away, and the Guets grown merry with Wine, began to talk of what was done abroad, when Trimalchio broke the Dicoure; and leaning on his Elbow, this Wine, aid he, is worth drinking, and Fih mut wim; but do you think I
am atisfied with that part of your Supper you aw in the Charger? Is Vlyes no better known? what then; we ought to exercie our Brains as well as our Chaps; and hew, that we are not only lovers of Learning, but undertand it: Peace ret my old Tutor's Bones who made me a Man amongt Men: No Man can tell me any thing that is New to me; for, like him, I am Mater of the Practicks.

This Heaven that's inhabited by twelve Gods, turns it elf into as many Figures; and now 'tis Aries: He that's born under that Sign has much Cattle, much Wooll, and to that a Jolt-head, a Brazen-face, and will be certainly a Cuckold: There are many Scholars, Advocates, and Horned Beats, come into the World under this Sign. We praied our Nativity-cater's pleaantnes, and he went on then again: The whole Heaven is Taurus, and wonder it e'er bore Football-Players, Herds-men, and uch as can hift for themelves. Under Gemini are foaled Coach-Hores, Oxen calved, great Baubles, and uch as can claw both ides, are born. I was born my elf under Cancer, and therefore tand on many Feet, as having large Poeions
both by Sea and Land. For Cancer, uits one as well as the other, and therefore I put nothing upon him, that I might not pres my own G • niture. Under Leo, Spend • hrifts and Bullies: under Virgo, Wom • n, Runagates, and uch as wear Iron Garters: under Libra, Butchers, Slip-lop-makers, and Men of Buines: under Scorpio, Empoioners and Cut-throats: under Sagittary, uch as are Goggle-ey'd, Herb-women, and Bacon-tealers: under Capricorn, poor helples Racals, to whom yet Nature intended Horns to defend themelves: under Aquarius, Cooks and Paunch-bellies: under Pi • es, Caterers and Orators: And o the World goes round like a Mill, and is never without its Michief; that Men be either born or perih. But for that tu • t of Herbs in the middle, and the Honey-comb upon it, I do nothing without jut reaon for it: Our Mother the Earth is in the middle, made round like an Egg, and has all good things in her elf, like a Honey-comb.
