Mot Learnedly, we all cry'd; and lifting our hands, wore, neither Hipparchus nor Aratus were to be compared to him; till at lat other Servants
came in and pread Coverlets on the Beds, on which were Painted Nets, Men in Ambuh with Hunting-Poles, and whatever appertained to Hunting: Nor could we yet tell what to make of it; when we heard a great cry without, and a pack of Beagles came and ran round the Table, and after them a large Trey, on which was a Boar of the firt Magnitude, with a Cap on his Head, (uch as Slaves at their making Free, had et on theirs in token of Liberties) on his Tusks hung two Wicker Baskets, the one full of Dates, the other of Almonds; and about him lay little Pigs of Marchpane, as if they were ucking: They ignified a Sow had Farrowed, and hang there as Preents for the Guets to carry away with them.

To the cutting up this Boar, here came not he that had carried about the Fowl as before, but a winging Fellow with a two-handed Beard, Buskins on his Leggs, and a hort Embroidered Coat; who drawing his Wood-Knife, made a large hole in the Boar's Side, out of which flew a company of Blackbirds: Th • n Fowlers tood ready with their Engines and caught them in a trice as they • luttered about the Room:
On which, Trimalchio ordering to every Man his Bird, See, aid he, what kind of Acorns this Wild Boar • ed on: When preently the Boys took off the Baskets and ditributed the Dates and Almonds among the Cuets.

In the mean time, I, who had private thoughts of my own, was much concerned, to know why the B • ar was brought in with a Cap upon his Head; and therefore having run out my Tittle-tattle, I told my Interpreter what troubled me: To which he anwered, Your Boy can even tell ye what it means, for there's no Riddle in it, but all as clear as Day. This Boar tood the lat of Yeter-nights Supper, and dimis'd by the Guets, returns now as a Free-man among us. I curt my dulnes, and asked him no more Quetions, that I might not be thought to have never eaten before with Men of Sene.

While we were yet talking, in came a handome Boy with a Wreath of Vine Leaves and Ivy about his Head; declaring himelf one while Bromius, another while Ly •• us, and another Euhyus, (everal Names of Bacchus) he carried about a Server of Grapes, and wi • h a clear Voice, repeated ome of his Mater's
Poetry, at which Trimalchio turning to him, Dionyius, aid he, be thou Liber, (i. e.) Free, (two other Names of Bacchus) whereupon the Boy took the Cap from off the Boar's Head, and putting it on his own, Trimalchio added, you will not deny me but I have a Father, Liber. We all praied the conceit, and • oundly kied the Boy as he went round us.
From this up roe Trimalchio, and went to the Cloe-Stool; we alo being at liberty, without a Tyrant over us, fell to ome Table-talk.

When preently one calling for a Bumper, the Day, aid he, is nothing, 'tis night e'er the Scene turn, and therefore nothing is better than to go treight from Bed to Board. We have had a great deal of Frot, the Bagnio has • arce heated me; but a warm drinking is my Wardrobe-keeper: For my part, I have pun this days Thread; the Wine is got into my Noddle, and I am down-right—

Selucus w • nt on with the ret, and I, aid he, do not ba • he every day, for he where I ue to bathe is a Fuller: Cold Water has Teeth in it, and my Head grows every day more wahy than other; but when I have got my Doe in my
Guts, I bid de • iance to Cold: Nor could I well do it to day, for I was at a Funeral, a jolly Companion, and a good Man was he, Cryanthus has breathed his lat: 'Tis not long ince we were together, and methinks I talk with him now. Alas, alas! we are but blown Bladders, les than Flies, yet they have omewhat in them: But we are meer Bubbles. You'll ay he would not be rul'd; not a drop of Water, or Crumb of Bread went down his Throat in five Days: And yet he's gone, or that he died of the Doctor. But I am of opinion his time was come; for a Phyitian is a great Comfort. However, he was well carried out of his Houe upon a rich Bed, and mightily lamented, he made ome of his Servants Free; but his Wi • e eem'd not much concerned for him. You'l ay again he was not kind to her; but Women are a kind of Kites; whatever good is done them, 'tis the ame as if it were thrown in a Well; and old Love is as bad as a Goal.

At this Philaos grew troubleome, and cryed out, Let us remember the Living: He had what was due to him; as he liv'd o he dy'd; and what has he now that any Man moans the want
of? He came from nothing, and to his dying-day would have taken a Farthing from a Dunghil with his Teeth; therefore as he grew up, he grew like a Honey-comb. He dy'd worth the Lord knows what, all ready Money. But to the Matter; I have eaten a Dog's Tongue and dare peak truth: He had a foul Mouth, was all Babble; a very Makebate, not a Man. His Brother was a brave Fellow, a Friend to his Friends, of an open hand, and kept a full Table: He did not order his Affairs o w • ll at firt as he might have done; but the firt Vintage made him up again; for he old what Wine he would; and what kept up his Chin was the expectation of a Reverion; the Credit of which brought him more than was left him; for his Brother taking a Pett at him, devied the Etate to I know not whoe Batard: He flies far that • lies his Rela • ion • . Beides, this Brother of h • s had Whiperers about him, that were back-friends to the other: but he hall never do right that is quick of belief, •
•• cially in matter of buines; and y • t ' • i • tru • , he'll be counted wi • e while he lives, to whom the thing what • v • r it b • is given, not he that
ought to have had it. He was without doubt, one of Fortune's Sons; Lead in his hand would turn to Gold, and without trouble too, where there are not Rubbs in the way. And how many Years think ye he liv'd? Seventy-odd: but he was as hard as Horn, bore his Age well, and as black as a Crow.

I knew him ome Years ago an Oilman, and to his lat a good Womans Man; but withal uch a Mier, that (o help me Hercules) I think he left not a Dogg in his Houe. He was alo a great Whore-mater, and a Jack of all Trades; nor do I condemn him for't, for this was the only ecret he kept to himelf and carry'd with him.

Thus Phileros and Gammedes, as followeth: Ye talk of what concerns neither Heaven nor Earth, when in the mean time no Man regards what makes all Victuals o earce: I could not (o help me Hercules) get a mouthful of Bread to day: and how? The drought continues: For my part, I have not fill'd my Belly this Twelvemonth: A plague on thee Clerks of the Market, the Baker and they juggle together; Take no notice of me, I'll take no notice of thee; which make the poorer
ort labour for nothing, while thoe greater Jaw-bones make Fetival every day. Oh that we had thoe Lyons I now find here, when I came firt out of Aia, that had been to live: The inner part of Sicily had the like of them, but they o handled the Goblins, even Jupiter bore them no Good-will. I remember Sa • nius, when I was a Boy, he liv'd by the Old Arch; you'd have taken him for Pepper-corn rather than a Man; where-ever he went the Earth parched under him; yet he was honet at bottom; one might depend on him; a Friend to his Friend, and whom you might boldly trut in the dark. But how did he behave himelf on the Bench? He toed every one like a Ball; made no Starch'd Speeches, but downright, as he were, doing himelf what he would peruade others: But in the Market his noie was like a Trumpet, without Sweating or Spu • ing. I fancy he had omewhat, I know not what, of the Aian humour: then o ready to return a Salute, and call every one by his Name, as if he had been one of us. In his time Corn was as common as Loam; you might have bought more Bread for half a Farthing, than any
two could eat; but now the Eye of an Ox will cot you twice as much: Ala • ! alas! we are every day wore and wore, and grow like a Cows Tail, downward: And why all this? We have a Clerk of the Market not worth three • iggs, and values more the getting of a Doit himelf, than any of our Lives: ' • sis this makes him laugh in his leeve; for he gets more Money in a day than many an honet Man's whole Etate: I know now how he got the Etate he has; but if we had any thing of Men about us, he would not hug himelf as he does; but now the People are grown to this pas, that they are Lyons at home, and Foxes abroad: For my part, I have eaten up my Cloaths already, and if Corn holds at the rate it does, I hall be for • 'd to ell Houe and all: For what will become of us, if neither Gods nor Men pity us? Let me never enjoy my Friends more, than I believe all this comes from Heaven; for no one thinks there is any uch thing; no one keeps a Fat, or value Jupiter a hair, but huts his Eyes and reckons what he is worth. Time was, when Matrons went bar •
foot with dihevel'd Hair, pure Minds, and pray'd him to end Rain, and
forthwith it rained Pitcher-fulls, or then or never, and every one was pleaed: Now the Gods are no better than Mice; as they tread, their Feet are wrapt in Wooll; and becaue we are not Supetitious your Lands yield nothing.

More Civilly, I beeech ye, aid Echion the Hundred-Contable; it is one while this way, and another while that, aid the Country • man when he lot his peckled Hogg: What is not to day may be to morrow; and thus is Life hurried about, o help me Hercules, a Country is aid not to be the better that it has many People in it, tho' ours at preent labours under that difficulty, but it is no fault of hers: We mut not be o Nice, Heaven is equally ditant every where; were you in another place you'd ay • oggs walked here ready dres'd: And now I think on' • , we hall have an exc • ll • nt Show thee Holy-days, a •• n • ing-Prize exhibit • d to the P • opl • ; not of Slav • s bought for that purpo • , but mot of them Freemen. Our Patron T •• us has a large Soul, but a very Devil in his Drink, and cares not a traw which ide gets the better: I think I hould know him, for I belong to him; he's of a right
breed both by Father and Mother, no Mungril. They are well provided with Weapons, and will fight it out to the lat: the Theatre will look like a Butchers Shambles, and he has wherewithal to do it; his Father left him a vat Sum, and let him make Ducks and Drakes with it never o much, the Etate will bear it, and he always carries the reputation of it. He has his Waggon Hores, a Woman-Carter, and Glyco's Steward, who was taken a-bed with his Mitres; what a bule's here between Cuckolds and Cuckold-makers! But this Glyco a Money-Broker, condemned his Steward to • ight with Beats; and what was that but to expoe himelf for another? where lay the Servant's Crime, who perhaps was oblig'd to do what he did: She rather deerv'd to be brain'd, than the Bull that toed her; but he that cannot come at the Are, Thrahes at the Pack-Saddle: yet how could Glyco expect Hermogine's Daughter hould make a good End? he'd have pared the Claws of a flying Kite; A Snake does not bring forth a Halter: Glyco might do what he would with his own; but it will be a Brand on him as long as he lives; nor can any thing but Hell
blot it out; however, every Man's faults are his own. I perceive now what Entertainment Mammea is like to give us; he'll be at Twopence Charges for me and my Company; which if he does, he will pull Narbanus clean out of favour; for you mut know, he'll live at the full height; yet in truth what good has he done us? He gave us a company of pittiful Sword-players, but o old and decrepid, that had you blown on them, they'd have fallen of themelves: I have een many a better at a Funeral Pile; he would not be at the Charge of Lamps for them; you'd have taken them for Dunghil Cocks fighting in the dark; one was a downright Fool, and withal Gouty; another Crumpfooted, and a third half dead, and Hamtrung: There was one of them a Thracian, that made a Figure, and kept up to the Rule of Fighting; but upon the whole matter, all of them were parted, and nothing came of this great block-headed Rabble, but a downright running away: And yet, aid he, I made ye a Show, and I clap my hands for Company; but cat up the Account, I gave more than I received; one Hand rubs another. You Agamemnon eem
to tell me what would that troubleome Fellow be at; becaue you that can peak, and do not, you are not of our Form, and therefore ridicule what poor Men ay; tho', aving the repute of a Scholar, we know you are but a meer Fool. Where lies the matter then? let me perwade you to take a walk in the Country, and ee our Cottage, you'll find omewhat to eat; a Chicken, ome Eggs, or the like: The Tempet • ous Seaon had like to have broke us all, yet we'll get enough to fill the Belly. Your Scholar, my Boy Cicero, is mightily improved, and if he lives, you •• l have a Servant of him; he is prety forward already, and whatever pare time he has, never off a Bock: H • 's a witty Lad • well-featur'd, takes a thing without much tudy, tho' y • t he be ickly: I killed three of his Linnets the other day, and told him the W • a •• ls had • aten them; yet he found other things to play with, and has a pritty knack at Painting: He has a perf • ct a verion to Greek, but eems better inclined to Latin; tho' the Mater he h •• now humours him in the other; nor can he be kept to one thing, but is • ill c • aving more, and will not take •• ins with
any. There is alo another of this ort, not much troubled with Learning, but very diligent, and teaches more than he • knows himelf: He comes to our Houe on Holidays, and whatever you give him he's contented; I therefore bought the Boy ome Ruled Books, becaue I will have him get a mattering in Accounts and the Law; it will be his own another day: He has Learning enough already, but if he takes back to it again, I deign him for a Trade, a Barber, a Paron, or a Lawyer, which nothing but the Devil can take from him: How oft have I told him, Thou art (Sirrah) my • irt begotten, and believe thy Father, whatever thou learnet 'tis all thy own: See there Philero the Lawyer, if he had not been a Scholar he might have tarved; but now ee what Trinkums he has about his N •• k, and dares No •
Narbanus. Letters are a Treaure, and a Trade never dies.

Thus, or the lik • , we were bandying it about, when T • imalchio return'd, and having wip'd th • Slops from his Face, wah'd his Hand • , and in a very little time, Pardon me, my • riend • , aid he, I have been co • tive for • v • ral days, and my Phyicians were to •• k about
it, when a Suppoitory of Pomegranate Wine, with the Liquor of a Pine-tree and Vinegar relieved me; and now I hope my Belly may be ahamed if it keep no better Order; for otherwie I have u • h a rumbling in my Guts, you'd think an Ox bellowed; and therefore if any of you has a mind, he need not bluh for the matter; ther • 's not one of us born without ome defect or other, and I think no torment greater than wanting the benefit of going to tool, which is the only thing even Jupiter himelf cannot prevent: And do you laugh, Fortunata, you that break me o o • ten of my leep by Nights; I never denyed any Man to do that in my Room might pleaure himelf, and Phyicians will not allow us to keep any thing in our Bodies longer than we needs mut; or if ye have any farther occaion, every thing is ready in the next Room: Water, Chamber-pots, Cloe-tools, or whatever ele ye may need; believe me, this being hard-bound, if it get into the Head, diturbs the whole Body; I have known many a Man lot by it, when they have been o modet to themelves as not to tell what they ailed.

We thank'd him for his freenes, and the Liberty he gave us, when yet to uppres our Laughter, we et the Glaes about again; nor did we yet know that in the midt of uch dainties we were, as they ay, to clamber another Hill; for the Cloth being again taken away, upon the next Muick were brought in Three fat Hogs with Collars and Bells about their Necks; and he that had the charge of them told us, the one was Two Years old, the other Three, and the third full grown. I took it at firt to have been a Company of Tumblers, and that the Hogs, as the manner is, were to have hewn us ome Tricks in a Ring, 'till Trimalchio breaking my expectation, Which of them, aid he, will ye have for Supper? for Cocks, Pheaants, and the like Tri • les are but Country fare, but my Cooks have Coppers will boil a Calf whole; and therewith commanding a Cook to be called for, he prevented our Choice by ordering him to kill the larget, and with a loud Voice, asked him, Of what rank of Servants in that Houe he was? to which he anwering, Of the forti • th: Were you bought, aid the other, or born in my Houe? Neither,
aid the Cook, but left you by Paua's Tetament. See then, aid Trimalchio, that you dres it as it hould be, or I'll end you to the Galleys. On which the Cook, advertied of his power, went into the Kitchin to mind his charge.

But Trimalchio turning to us with a pleaanter look, asked us if the Wine pleaed us, if not, aid he, I'll have it changed, and if it does, let me ee it by your drinking: I thank the Gods I do not buy it, but have every thing that may get an Appetite growing on my own Grounds without the City, which no Man that I know but my elf has; and yet it has been taken for Tarracino and Taranto. I have a Project to joyn Sicily to my Lands on the Continent, that when I have a mind to go into Africa, I may ail by my own Coats. But prithee Agamemnon tell me what moot-point was it you argued to day; for tho' I plead no Caues my elf, yet I have had a Share of Letters in my time; and that you may not think me ick of them now, have three Libraries, the one Greek, the other two Latin; therefore as you love me tell me what was the State of the Quetion: The Poor and the Rich are Enemies,
aid Agamemnon: And what is Poor, anwered Trimalchio? Spoke like a Gentleman, replyed Agamemnon. But making nothing of the matter, If it be o, aid Trimalchio, where lies the Dipute? and if it be not o, 'tis nothing.

While we all humm'd this and the like tuff, I be • ech ye, aid he, my dear Agamemnon, do you remember the Twelve Labours of Hercules, or the Story of Ulyes, how a Cyclop put his Thumb out of Joint with a Mawkin? I read uch things in Homer when I was a Boy; nay, aw my elf the Sybil of Cuma hanging in a Glas Bottle: And when the Boys asked her, Sybil, what wouldt thou? She anwered, I would Die.

He had not yet run to the end of the Rope, when an over-grown Hog was brought to the Table. We all wondered at the quicknes of the thing, and wore a Capon could not be dres'd in the time; and that the more, becaue this Hog eemed larger than was the Boar we had a little before: When Trimalchio looking more intent upon him, What, what, aid he, are not his Guts taken out? No, (o help me Hercules) they are not! Bring hither, bring hither this Rogue of a Cook. And when he tood
hanging his Head before us, and aid, he was o much in hate he forgot it. How, forgot it, cry'd out Trimalchio! Do ye think he has given it no Seaoning of Pepper and Cummin? Strip him: When in a trice 'twas done, and himelf et between two Tormentors: However, we all interceeded for him, as a fault that might now and then happen, and therefore beg'd his pardon; but if he ever did the like, there was no one would peak for him; tho' for my part, I think he deerved what he got: And o turning to Agamemnon's Ear, This Fellow, ai • I, mut be a naughty Knave; could any one forget to Bowel a Hog? I would not (o help me Hercules) have forgiven him, if he had erved me o with a ingle Fih. But Trimalchio it eems, had omewhat • l • in his Head; for falling a laughing, You, aid he, that have o hort a Memory, let's ee if you can do it now. On which, the Cook having gotten his Coa • again, took up a Knife, and with a • eigned trembling, ripp'd up the Hogs Belly long and thwart, when immediately its own weight tumbled out a heap of • ogs-Puddings and Sauag • s.

After this, as it had been done of it elf, the Family gave a Shout, and cry'd out, Health and Properity to Caius! The Cook alo was preented with Wine, a Silver Coronet, and a drinking Goblet, on a broad Corinthian Plate: which Agamemnon more narrowly viewing; I am, aid Trimalchio, the only Peron that has the true Corinthian Veels.

There was a Copper-Smith that made Glas Veels of that pliant hardnes, that they were no more to be broken than Gold and Silver ones: It o happened, that having made a Drinking-pot, with a wide Mouth of that kind, but the finet Glas, • it for no Man, as he thought, les than Caear himelf; he went with his Preent to Caear, and had admittance: The kind of the Gift was praied, the hand of the Workman commended, and the d • ign of the Giver accepted. He again, that he might turn the admiration of the beholders into atonihment, and work himelf the more into the Emperor's favour, pray'd the Glas out of the Emperor's hand; and having received it, threw it with uch a force againt the Paved Floor, that the mot olid and firmet Metal could not but have received ome hurt thereby. Caear alo was no les amazed
at it, than concerned for it; but the other took up the Pot from the Ground, not broken but bulg'd a little; as i • the ubtance of Metal had put on the likenes of a Glas; and therewith taking a Hammer out of his Pocket, he hammer'd it as it had been a Bras Kettle, and beat out the Bruie: And now the Fellow thought himelf in Heaven, in having, as he fanied, gotten the acquaintance of Cae • ar, and the admiration of all: But it fell out quite contrary: Caear asking him if any one knew how to make this Malleable Glas but himelf? And he anwering, there was not; the Emperor commanded his Head to be truck off: For, aid he, if this Art were once known, Gold and Silver will be of no more eteem than Dirt.

And for Silver, I more than ordinarily affect it: I have everal Water-pots more or les, whereon is the Story how Caandra killed her Sons, and the dead Boys are o well Emboed, you'd think them real. I have alo a drinking Cup left me by an Advocate of mine, where Daedalus puts Niobe into the Trojan Hore, as alo that other of Hermerotes; that they may tand as a Tetimony, there's truth in Cups, and all this
Ma •• y; nor will I part with what I undertand of them at any rate.

While he was thus talking, a Cup dropt out of a Boy's hand; on which, Trimalchio looking over his Shoulder at him, bad him begone, and kill h • melf immediately; for, aid he, thou art careles and mind't not what thou art about. The Boy hung his Lip, and beought him; but he aid, What! dot thou beeech me, as if I required ome difficult matter of thee? I only bid thee obtain this of thy elf, that thou be not careles again: But at lat he dicharged him upon our entreaty. On this the Boy run round the Table and cry'd, Water without doors, and Wine within. We all took the Jet, but more epecially Agamemnon, who knew on what account himelf had been brought thither.

Trimalchio in the mean time hearing himelf commended, drank on the merrier; and being within an Ace of quite out, Will none of you, aid he, invite my Fortunata to Dance? Believe me, there's no one leads a Country Dance better: And with that, toing his Hands round his Head, fell to act a Jack-Pudding; the Family all the while Singing,
Youth it elf, mot exactly Youth it elf; and he had gotten into the middle of the Room, but that Fortunata whipered him, and I believe told him, uch Gambols did not become his Gravity: Nor was there any thing more uneven to it elf; for one while he turned to his Fortunata, and another while to his natural inclination: But what diturbed the pleaure of her Dancing, was his Notaries coming in; who, as they had been the Acts of a Common-Council, read aloud.

VII. of the Calends of Augut born in Trimalchio's manner of Cumanum, Thirty Boys and Forty Girls, brought from the Threhing-floor into the Granay, Five hundred thouand Buhels of Wheat. The ame day broke out a Fire in a Pleaure-Garden that was Pompey's, firt began in one of his Bayliffs Houes.
How's this, aid Trimalchio! when were thoe Gardens bought for me? The Year before, anwered his Notary, and therefore not yet brought to Account.

At this Trimalchio fell into a Fume; And whatever Lands, aid he, hall be • ought me hereafter, if I h • ar nothing of it in ix Months, let them never, I
charge ye, be brought to any Account of mine. Then alo were read the Orders of the Clerks of the Markets, and the Tetaments of his Woodwards, Rangers, and Park-keepers, by which they diinherited their Relations, and with ample praie of him, declare Trimalchio their Heir. Next that, the Names of his Bayliffs; and how one of them that made his Circuits in the Country, turned off his Wife for having taken her in Bed with a Barber; the Door-keeper of his Baths turn'd out of his Place; the Auditor found hort in his Accounts, and the Dipute between the Grooms of his Chamber ended.

At lat came in the Dancers on the Rope; and a gorbelly'd Blockhead tanding out with a Ladder, commanded his Boy to hopp every Round inging, and dance a Jigg on the top of it, and then tumble through burning Hoops of Iron, with a Glas in his Mouth. Trimalchio was the only Peron that admir'd it, but withal aid, he did not like it; but there were two things he could willingly behold, and they were the Flyers on the high Rope, and Quails; and that all other Creatures and Shows were meer Gewgaws: For, aid he • I
bought once a Sett of Stroulers, and choe rather to make them Merry • Andrews than Comedians; and commanded my Bag-piper to Sing in Latin to them.

While he was Chattering all at this rate, a Boy chanced to tumble upon him, on which th • Family gave a Shriek, the ame alo did the Guets; not for uch a Beat of a Man, whoe Neck they could willingly have een broken, but for fear the Supper hould break up ill, and they be forc'd to wail the death of the Boy.

Whatever it were, Trimalchio gave a deep Groan; and leaning upon his Arm as if it had been hurt, the Phyicians ran thick about him, and with the firt, Fortunata, her Hair about her Ears, a Bottle of Wine in her Hand, till howling, mierable unfortunate Woman that he was! Undone, undone.

The Boy on the other hand, ran under our Feet, and bee • ched us to procure him a Dicharge: But I was much concern'd, let our Interpoition might make an ill end of the matter; for the Cook that had forgotten to Bowel the Hog was till in my thoughts. I began therefore to look about the Room, for fear omewhat or other might
drop through the Cieling; while the Servant that had bound up his Arm in white, not Scarlet-colour Flannen, was oundly beaten: Nor was I much out, for intead of another Coure, came in an order of Trimalchio's, by which he gave the Boy his Freedom; that it might not be aid • o Honourable a Peron had been hurt by his Slave. We all commended the Action, but chatted among our elves with what little Conideration the things of this World were done. You're in the right, aid Trimalchio; nor ought this Accident to pas without Booking; and o calling for the Journal, commanded it to be Entred; and with, as little thought, tumbled out thee Veres:
div.l: What's leat expected falls into our Dih,
And Fortune's more indulgent than our Wih:
Therefore, Boy, fill the generous Wine about.
div.p:
This Epigram gave occaion to talk of the Poets, and Marus the Trachian carry'd the Bays a long while: till Trimalchio (turning to ome Wit amongt them) I beeech ye, Mater of mine, aid he, tell me what difference take ye between Cicero the Orator, and Publius the
Poet? for my part I think one was more Eloquent, the other the honeter Man; for what could be aid better than this?
div.l: Now inking Rome grows weak with Luxury,
To pleae her appetite cram'd Peacocks die:
Their gaudy Plumes a modih Dres upply.
For her the Guinnea Hen and Capon's dret:
The Stork it elf for Rome's luxurious Tate,
Mut in a Caldron build its humbl'd Net.
That foreign, friendly, pious, long-leg'd thing,
Grateful, that with hrill • ounding notes does ing
All Winter's gone; yet uhers in the Spring.
Why in one Ring mut three rich Pearls be worn,
But that your Wives th' exhauted Seas adorn,
Abroad t'increae their Lut, at home their Scorn?
Why is the cotly Emrald o deir'd,
Or richer glittering Carbuncle admir'd,
Beca • e they parkle, is't with that you're fir'd?
Well, Honety's a Jew • l. Now none knows
A modet Bride from a kept Whore by'er Cloaths •
For Cobweb Lawns both Spoue & Wench expoe.
div.p:
But, now we talk after the rate of the Learned, which, aid he, are the mot difficult Trades? I think a Phyician and a Banker: A Phyitian, becaue he knows a Man's very heart, and when
the Fits of an Ague will return; tho' by the way, I hate them mortally; for by their good will I hould have nothing but Slubber-lops: And a Banker, becaue he'll find out a piece of Bras Money, tho' plated with Silver.

There are alo brute Beats, Sheep and Oxen, laborious in their kind: Oxen, to whom we are beholding for the Bread we eat: and Sheep, for the Wooll, that makes us o fine. But O horrid! we both eat the Mutton, and make us warm with the Fleece. I take the Bees for Divine Creatures; they give us Honey, tho • 'tis aid they tole it from Jupiter, and that's the reaon why they Sting: For where-ever ye meet any thing that's weet, you'll ever find a Sting at the end of it.

He alo excluded Philoophers from buines, while the Memoirs of the Family were carrying round the Table, and a Boy, et for that purpoe, read aloud the Names of the Preents, appointed for the Guets, to carry home with them. Wicked Silver, what can it not! Then a Gammon of Bacon was et on the Table, and above that everal harp Sauces, a Night-Cap for himelf, Pudding-Pies, and I know not
what kind of Birds: There was alo brought in a Rundlet of Wine, boiled off a third part, and kept under Ground to preerve its trength: There were alo everal other things I can give no account of; beides Apples, Scallions, Peaches, a Whip, a Knife, and what had been ent him; as Sparrows, a Flyeflap, Raions, Attick Honey, NightGowns, Judges Robes, dry'd Pate, Table-Books, with a Pipe and a Foot-tool: After which came in an Hare and a SoleFih: And there was further ent him a Lamprey, a Water-Rat, with a Frog at his Tail, and a bundle of Beets.

Long time we miled at thee, and five hundred the like, that have now lipt my Memory: But now when Acyltos, who could not moderate himelf, held up his hands and laught at every thing; nay o downright, that he was ready to cry: A Free-man of Trimalchio's that ate next above me, grew hot upon't; And what, aid he, thou Sheep, what dot thou laugh at? does not this Sumptuounes of my Mater pleae you? you're richer (forooth) and eat better every day; o may the Guardian of the place favour me, as had I ate near him, I'd hit him a Box
on the Ear ere this: A hopeful Cullion, that mocks others; ome pitiful Night-walker, not worth the very Urine he makes; and hould I throw mine on him, knows not where to dry himelf. I am not (o help me Hercules) quickly angry, yet Worms are bred even in tender Fleh. He laughs! what has he to laugh at? what Wooll did his Father give for the Bantling? Is he a Roman Knight? I am the Son of a King. How came I then, you'll ay, to erve another? I did it of my elf, and had rather be a Citizen of Rome, than a Tributary King, and now hope to live o, as to be no Man's Jeat. I walk like other Men, with an open Face, and can hew my Head among the bet, for I owe no Man a Groat: I never had an Action brought againt me, or aid to me on the Exchange, Pay me what thou owet me. I bought ome Acres in the Country, and have every thing uitable to it: I feed twenty mouths, beides Dogs: I ranomed my Bond-Woman, let another hould wipe his Hands on her Smock; and between our elves, he cot me more than I'll tell ye at preent. I was made a Captain of Hore gratis, and hope o to die, that I hall have no occaion
to bluh in my Grave: But art thou o prying into others, that thou never conideret thy elf? Cant thou py a Loue on another Man's Coat, and not ee the Tyck on thy own? Your Mater then is ancienter than your elf, and't pleae him; but yet thou, whoe Milk is not yet out of thy Noe; that can't not ay Boh to a Gooe; mut you be making Obervations? Are you the wealthier Man? If you are, Dine twice, and Sup twice; for my part I value my Credit more than Treaures: Upon the whole matter, where's the Man that ever dunn'd me twice? Thou Pipkin of a Man, more limber, but nothing better than a Strap of wet Leather, I have erved forty Years in this Houe, came into it with my Hair full grown; this Palace was not then built, yet I made it my buines to pleae my Mater, a Peron of Honour, the parings of whoe Nails are more worth than thy whole Body. I met everal rubs in my way, but by the help of my good Angel, I broke through them all: This is truth; it is as eaie to make a Hunting-Horn of a Sow's Tail, as to get into this Company. What makes ye in a Dump now, like a Goat at a heap of Stones?

On this Gi • on, who tood behind him, burt out a laughing; which the other taking notice of, fell upon the Boy; and, Do you, aid he, laugh too, you curlpated chattering Magpye? O the Saturnals! why how now, Sirrah! is it the Month of December? When were you Twenty, I pray? What would this Collop dropt from the Gibbe • , this Crowsmeat, be at? I • ll find ome or other way for Jupiter to plague th • e, and him that br • d thee no better, or never let me • at a good Meals-meat again: I could, Sirrah, but for the Companies ake, I pare thee; tho' either we undertand not aright, or they are Sots themelves, that carry no better a hand over thee; for without doubt it is true, Like Mater like Man. I am hot by nature, and can • arce contain my elf; give me but a mes of Peae-Porridge, and I care not two-pence for my Mother. Very well, I hall meet thee abroad, thou Moue; nay, rather Mole • Hill. May I never thrive mor • , but I'll drive that Mater of thine into a blade of Rue; nor halt thou (o help me Hercules) 'cape me, tho' thou couldt call in Jupiter to thy aid: I hall off with thoe Locks, and take thee when that tri •• ing
Mater of thine hall be o • t of the way; thou wilt certainly fall into my hands, and either I know not my elf, or I'll make thee leave that Buffoonry: Tho' thy Beard were of Gold, I'll have thee bruied in a Mortar, and him that firt taught thee: I never • udied Geometry, Criticim, and meer words without ene, but I undertand the itting of Stones for Buildings; can run you over a hundred things, as to Metal, Weight, Coin, and that to a tittle; if you have a mind you and I will try it between us: I'll lay thee a Wager, thou Wizard, and tho' I am wholly ignorant of Rhetorick, thou'lt pr • ently ee thou hat lot: Let no one run about the Buh to me; I come up to him: Reolve me, I ay, which of us runs, yet • irs not out of his place: which of us grows bigger, and yet is les. Do you camper? can't you tell what to make of it, that you look o like a Moue in a Trap? Therefore either hold thy tongu • , or don't provoke a better Man than thy elf, who does not think thee fram'd of Nature, unles thou faniet me taken with thoe yellow curl'd Locks, which thou hat already vowed to ome Whore or other. O lucky Opportunity! come, let's walk
the Exchange, and ee which of us can take up Money: You'll be atisfied then, this Iron has Credit upon't • a pretty thing, is it not! a drunken Fox. So may I gain while I live, and die well; but the People will brain me if I follow not that Coat on thy back, which is not for thy wearing, where ever thou goet: He's a precious tool too, whoever he were, that taught thee; a piece of green Cheee, no Mater. I have learn'd as well as another Man, and my Mater aid it would be my own another day. Save your Worhip! get home as fat as you can, but look well about you, and have a care how you peak irreverently of your betters, or vi • Etates with them; he that does it, his Pure hall feel it: For my elf, that you ee me as I am, I thank my Stars for the Art I have.

Acyltos was making anwer to his Railing; when Trimalchio, pleaed with that good Grace of peaking, Go to, aid he, no more of this wild talk, let us rather be pleaant: And you Hermeros, bear with the Young-man, his Blood boils; be thou the oberer Man; he that is overcome in this matter, goes off Conqueror: Even thy elf, when
thou wert uch another Capon, hadt nothing but Coco, Coco, and no heart at all. Let us therefore, which is the better of the two, be heartily Merry, and expect ome admirers of Homer, that will be here preently.

Nor were the words carc • out of his mo • th, when in came a band of Men, and made a ru • ling with th • ir Spears and Targets. Trimalchio l • aned on his Pillow, the Homerits ratled out Greek Veres, as, arrogantly enough, they were wont to do, and he read a Latin Book with a lo • d voice: whereupon Silence being made, Know ye, aid he, what Fable they were upon?

Diomedes and Ganymede were two Brothers, and Helen was their Siter; Agam • mnon tole him away, and hamm'd Diana with a Hind in his room, as ays Homer in this place; and how the Tro
• ans and the Parentines fought among themelves; but at lat he got the better of it, and married his Daughter Iphigenia to Achilles; on which Ajax run Mad. And there's an end of the Tal • .

On this the Homerits et up a Sho • t, and a young boiled Heifer with an Helm • t on her Head, was handed in upon
a mighty Charger: Ajax followed, and with a drawn Sword, as if he were mad, made at it, now in one place, then in another, till acting a Morrisdancer; till having cut it into Joints, he took them upon the point of his Sword, and ditribu • ed them. Nor had we much time to admire the Conceit; for of a udden the Roof gave a crack, and the whole Room hook: For my part, I got on my feet, but all in confuion, for fear ome T • mbler might drop on my head; the ame alo were the ret of the Guets; till gaping and expecting what new thing hould come from the Clouds: when traight the main Beams opened, and a vat Circle was let down, all round which hung Golden Garlands, and Alabater Pots of weet Ointments.

While we were required to take up thee Preents, I chanced to cat an eye upon the Table, where there lay a freh Service of Cheee-cakes and Tarts, and in the midt of them a l • ty Rundlet, tuck round with all orts of Apples and Grapes, as they commonly draw that Figure.

We greedily reached our Hands towards it, when of a udden, a new Diverion gave us freh Mirth; for all the
Cheee-cakes, Apples and Tarts, upon the leat touch, threw out a delicious liquid Perfume, which fell upon us.

We judging the Mes to be Sacred, that was o gorgeouly et out, tood up and began a Health to the Augut Founder, the Father of his Country: After which Reverence, falling to catch that catch could, we filled our Napkin • , and I chiefly, who thought nothing too good for my Boy Gito.

During this, in came three Boys in White, their Coats tuck'd about them; of whom, two et on the Table three Houhold Gods with Broaches about their Necks, and the other bearing round us a Goblet of Wine, cry'd aloud, Be the Gods Favourable! The Name of this, aid he, is Cobl • r, that other's Goodluck, and the third's Spend-all: And as the Image of Trimal • hio was carryed round, and every one kis'd it, we thought it a hame not to do as the ret of the Company.

After this, when all of us • had wihed him Health and Happines, Trimalchio turning to Ni •• ros, You were wont, aid he, to be a good Companion, but what's the matter we get not a word from ye •• w? Let me entreat ye, as you would
ee me Happy, do not break an old Cutom.

Niceros, pleaed with the franknes of his Friend: Let me never thrive, aid he, if I am not ready to caper out of my Skin, to ee you in o good a Humour; therefore what I ay hall be all Mirth; tho' I am afraid thoe Grave Fopps may laugh: but let them look to't, I'll go on nevertheles; for what am I the wore for any ones Swearing? I had rather they laugh at what I ay, than at my elf.
Thus when he pake—he began this Tale—

While I was yet a Servant we liv'd in a narrow Lane, now the Houe of Gavilla: There, as the Gods would have it, I fell in Love with Tarentius's Wife; he kept an Eating-houe. Ye all knew Melia Tarentina, a pretty little Punching-block, and withal Beautiful; but (o help me Hercules) I minded her not o much for the matter of the point of that, as that he was good-humour'd; if I asked her any thing, he never deny'd me; and what Money I had, I truted her with it; nor did he ever fail me when I'd occaion. It o happened, that a She-companion of hers
had dy'd in the Country, and he was gone thither; how to come at her I could not tell; but a Friend is een at a dead lift; it alo happened my Mater was gone to Capua to dipatch omewhat or other: I laid hold of the opportunity, and peruaded mine Hot to take an Evenings Walk of four or five Miles out of Town, for he was a tout Fellow, and as bold as the Devil: The Moon hone as bright as Day, and about Cock-crowing we fell in with a Burying-place, and certain Monuments of the Dead: my Man loitered behind me a Star-gazing, and I itting expecting him, fell a Singing and numbring them; when looking round me, what hould I ee but mine Hot tript tark-naked, and his Cloat • s lying by the High-way-ide. The ight truck me every where, and I tood as if I had been dead; but he Pis'd round his Cloaths, and of a udden was turned to a Wolf: Don't think I Jet; I value no Man's Etate at that rate, as to tell a Lye. But as I was aying, after he was turned to a Wolf, he et up a Howl, and fled to the Woods. At firt I knew not where I was, till going to take up his Cloaths, I found them alo turn'd to Stone. Another
Man would have dy'd for fear, but I drew my Sword, and laying all the Ghots that came in my way, lighted at lat on the place where my Mitres was: I entred the firt Door; my Eyes were unk in my Head, the Sweat ran off me by more treams than one, and I was jut breathing my lat, without thought of recovery; when my Melia coming up to me, began to wonder why I'd be walking o late; and if, aid he, you had come a little ooner, you might have done us a kindnes; for a Wolf came into the Farm, and has made Butchers work enough among the Cattle; but tho' he got off, he has no reaon to laugh, for a Servant of ours ran him through the Neck with a Pitch-fork. As oon as I had heard her, I could not • old open my Eyes any longer, and ran home by Daylight, like a Vintner whoe Houe had been robb'd: But coming by the place where the Cloaths were turned to Stone, I aw nothing but a Puddle of Blood; and when I got home, found mine Hot lying a • bed like an Oxe in his Stall, and a Chirurgeon • reing his Neck. I undertood af ••• wards he was a Fellow that could change his Skin; but from
that day forward, could never eat a bit of Bread with him, no, if you'd have kill'd me. Let them that don't believe me, examine the truth of it; may your good Angels plague me as I tell ye a Lye.

The Company were all wondring, when, Saving what you have aid, quoth Trimalchio, if there be faith in Man, my Hair tands on end, becaue I know Niceros is no Trifler; he's ure of what he ays, and not given to talking: Nay, I'll tell ye as horrible a thing my elf; but ee there, what's that behind the Hangings?

When I was yet a long-hair'd Boy, for even then I liv'd a pleaant Life, I had a Minion, and he dy'd: He was (o help me Hercules) a Pearl, a Paragon, nay Perfection it elf: But when the poor Mother lamented him, and we alo were doing the ame, ome Witches got round the Houe on a udden, you'd have taken them for Hounds hunting a Hare. We had then in the Houe a Cappadocian, a tall Fellow, tout and hardy, that would not have tept an inch out of his way for Jupiter. He boldly drew his Sword, and wrapping his Coat about his left Arm, leaped out of the
Houe, and as it might be here, (no hurt to the thing I touch) ran a Woman clean through. We heard a pittiful Groan, but not to Lye, aw none of them. Our Champion came in and threw himelf on a Bed, but all black and blue, as he had been thrah'd with Flails; for it eems ome ill Hand had touched him. We hut the Door, and went on with our Mourning; but the Mother taking her Son in her Arms, and troaking him, found nothing but a Bolter of Straw; it had neither Heart, Entrals, nor any thing, for the Fairies belike had tollen him out of his Cradle, and left that of Straw intead of him. Give me Credit, I beeech ye, Women are craftier than we are, play their Tricks by Night, and turn every thing Topy-turvy. After this our tall Fellow never came to his Colour again, but in a few days died Raving-mad.
We all wondred, as not doubting what he aid, and kiing the Table in reverence to him, pray'd the privilege of the Night, and that our Places might be kept till we returned.

And now we thought the Lamps look'd double, and the whole Room eem'd quite another thing; when Trimalchio
again, I peak to you Plorimus, won't you come in for a hare? Will ye entertain us with nothing? thou uedt to be a pleaant Companion, couldt ing a Song and tell a Tale with the bet; but Alas! alas! the Sweetmeats are gone. My Hores, aid the other, ran away with my Coach, I have been troubled with the Gout ever ince. When I was a young Fellow, I Sung o long I had well nigh brought my elf into a Conumption. What do ye tell me of Songs, Tales, or Barbers Shops? Who ever came near me but one, only Apelles; and with etting his Hand to his Mouth, Whitled out omewhat, • know not what, which afterwards he wore was Greek. Trimalchio alo when he mimicked the Trumpets, looked on his Minion and • alled him Cr • eus: Yet the Boy was blear-eye'd, and wathing up a little black Bitch with naty Teeth, and overgrown with Fat, in Green Swadling-Clouts, he et half a Loaf on the Table, which he refuing, he cram'd her with it: On which Trimalchio commanded the Guardian of his Houe and Family, Scylax, to be brought; when preently was led in a beautiful Matiff in a Chain, who having a hint given
him by a knock of the Porter's Foot, lay down before the Table: whereupon Trimalchio throwing him a Manchet; There's no one, aid he, in this Houe of mine, loves me better than this Dog. The Boy taking it in dudgeon that Scylax hould be o commended, laid the Bitch on the Floor, and challenged the Dog to have a Rubbers with him. On this Scylax, after the manner of Dogs, et up uch a hideous Barking, that it fill'd the Room; and napping at him, almot rent off a Brooch that hung on Craus's Breat; nor did the Scuffle end here, for the great Candle being overturn • d on the Table, broke all the Chrytal Glaes, and threw the calding Oil on the Guets.

Trimalchio, not to eem concerned at the los, kied the Boy, and commanded him to get on his Back; nor was it long e're he was a Cock-hore, and lapping his Maters Shoulders, and laughing, cry'd out, Fool, fool, and how many of them have • e here?

Trimalchio thus kept under for a while, commanded a Bumper to be fill'd and given round to the Waiters, with this further, That whoever refued it hould have it poured down his Collar.
Thus one while we were Grave, and other while Merry.

After this came Junkets and made Dihes, the very remembrance of which, if I may be believed, will not yet down with me; for there were everal cram'd Hens given about under the notion of Thruhes, and Gooe Eggs with Caps upon them; which Trimalchio, nor without Otentation, pres'd us to Eat; adding withal, that their Bones were taken out.

Nor were the words carce out of his mouth, when a Beadle rapp'd at Door, and one in White, with a company of Roiters following him, came in upon us: For my part I was not a little urprized; and by his Lordlines taking him for the Mayor of a Town, and our elves within his Liberties, was getting upon my Feet. Agamemnon laught to ee me o concerned, and bade me it till; for, aid he, this Habinias is a Captain of Hore, a good Maon, and has a pecial faculty in making Monuments.

Recovered again with his words, I kept my Seat, and wholly fix'd my Eye on Habinias: He came in Drunk, and lolling on his Wife's Shoulders, with
ome Garlands about him, his Face all trickling down with Ointment, he eated himelf at the head of the Table, and incontinently called for Wine and hot Water.
Trimalchio was pleaed with the Humour, and calling for a bigger Glas, asked him what Entertainment he had whence he came?

Every thing, aid the other, but • hy elf; for my inclination was here; tho' (o help me Hercules) it was all well. Scia kept a Nine • days Feat for his Servant Micellus, whom he infranchied after he was dead: It is aid he had a round Sum in the Chequer, for they reckon he died worth 50000 Seterces; yet this was all done in good order, tho' every of us were obliged to pour half his Drink on the Grave.

But, aid Trimalchio, what had ye to Eat? I'll tell ye, quoth Habinas, as near as I can, for my Memory is not o good, but that ometimes I forget my own Name: However, for the firt Dih we had a goodly Porker, with a Garland upon him, and Puddings, Gooe Giblets, Lamb-tones, Sweetbreads, and Gizzards round him; there were alo Bee • s, and Houhold-Bread of his
own baking, for himelf, which I had rather have than White; it makes a Man trong, and I never complain of what I like. The next was a cold Tart, with excellent warm Honey, and that Spanih, running upon it. I • at little of the Tart, but more of the Honey; I tated alo the red Pule, and Lupines, by the advice of Calvus, and everal Apples, of which I took away two in my Handkerchief; for if I bring home nothing to my little he Slave, I hall have Snubs enough: this Dame of mine puts me often in mind of her. We had alo on a Side-Table the Hanch of a Bear, which Scintilla tating ere he was aware, had like to have thrown up her Guts: I on the other hand eat a pound of it or better, for methought it tated like B • ars fleh; and aid I, if a Bear eats a Man, why may not a Man much more eat a Bear? To be hort, we had Cream Cheee, Wine boil'd o • f to a third part, fry'd Snails, Chitterlings, Livers, Eggs, Turneps, Mutard, and a Bowl that held a Gallon. Don't ditu • b me Palamedes; there were alo handed about a Basket of Sugar-Cakes, of which we wantonly • ook ome, and ent away the Gammon of B • con. But • ell me Cai • s, I beeech
you, what's the matter that Fortunata its not among us? How came you to know her? quoth Trimalchio; for till he has gotten her Plate together, and ditributed what we leave among the Servants, not a ip of any thing goes into her mouth.

But unles he • its down, replied Habinas, I'll be gone; and was getting up, but that the word being four times given about for her, he came at lat in a greenih Gown and a Cherry-colour'd Stomacher, beneath which might be een her Petticoat and Embroidered Garters; then wiping her Hands on her Neckcloth, he • ate on that Bed whereon Scintilla the Wife of Habinas was; and having given • er a Kis, told her, it was in Compliment to her that he was there. At length it came to this, that he took o • f her weigh • y Bracelets, and hewed them to Scintilla; which he admiring, he alo unbuckled her Garters and a Net-work Pure, which he aid was of the finet Gold.

Trimalchio oberved it, and commanding all to be laid before him, See, aid he, this Womans Finery, and what Fools our Wives make us; they hould be Six Pound and a half; yet I've another of
Mercury's making, that weighs Ten: And that he might not be thought to tell a Lye, called for his Gold Scales, and commanded them to be weighed: Nor had Scintilla more Wit than t'other, for pulling a Golden Box out of her Boom, which he called Good luck, he took out of it two large Pearl Pendants, giving them in like manner to Fortunata to view: See, quoth he, what 'tis to have a kind Husband, I am ure no Woman has better. What, aid Habinas, hat thou put the Sham on me? thou toldt me thou couldt be contented with Glas Beads; and for this trick, if I had a Daughter I'd cut off her Ears; tho' were there no Women what were the ret worth? This it is to pis warm and drink cold.

Mean time the Women perceiving they were toucht, twitter'd among themelves, and being got Drunk, fell to kiing one another; one commended the Mitres of the Houe, t'other the Mater: when during this chatter, Habinas tealing behind Fortunata, gave her uch a tos on the Bed, that her Heels flew as high as her Head, on which he gave a queak or two, and finding her Thighs bare, ran her Head under Scintilla's Smock.

This held a while, till Trimalchio calling for a econd Service to • ntertain his new Guets, the Servants took away the Tables that were before us, and having brought others, trew'd the Room with Pin-dut, mixt with Vermillion and Sa •• ron; and, what I never aw before, the Dut of a Looking • glas ground to Powder.

When immediately, quoth Trimalchio, I could have been contented with thoe firt Dihes; but ince we have got other Tables, we mut alo have another Service; and if there be any thing worth our having, bring it.

On which, a pr • ce Boy that erved us with warm Water, began to imitate a Nightingale; till Trimalchio giving the word, a Servant that waited on Habinas, et up another Humour, and, as I believe, commanded by his Mater, nois'd out;
Mean time Aeneas had put off to Sea.
Nor was there ever a harher ound yet pierced my Ear; for beides his diordered Country Tone, his pitiful and tarvling way of delivery, he o tufft it with craps of Veres, that even Virgil then firt
direlihed me; till at lat o tyr'd, that he could hold no longer; D'ye think, aid Habinas, this Boy has learn'd nothing? I bred him with Juglers that follow the Fair: Nor has he his fellow, whether he humours a Muliteer or a Jeter. This never-be-good has abundance of Wit; he's a Taylor, a Cook, a Baker, a Jack of all Trades, and but for two faults, were exact to a hair: He's crack-brain'd, and • ores in his leep: For that cat of his Eye I value it not, he looks like Venus, and therefore his Tongue is ever running; and were that Eye out he were worth the Money I gave for him.
On which Scintilla interrupting him, told him he was a naughty Man, for not telling all his Servan • s good qualities: He's a • imp, • id he, if not wore, but I'll take care he be branded for that.

Trimal • hio laught, and aid he knew he was a Cappadocian that never beguiled himelf of any thing, and (o help me Hercules) I commend him • or't: when will you find uch another, but, Scintilla, you mut not be jealous: Believe me, and I know you too; may I o enjoy the health you wih me, as I play'd at Leap-frog o long with our
Boy, that my Mater grew jealous, and ent me to Dig in the Country: But hold thy tongue and I'll give thee a Loaf.

Hereupon the Ra •• al, as if he had been praied all this while, took o • t an Earthen Candletick, and for half an hour or better, counter • eited the Hautboys, Habinas inging the • ae to him, and • labbering his under Lip with his Finger; that done, he went into • he middle of the Room, and clattering o • e Canes together, one while imitated the Bagpipes, and danced a Jigg to it; and o • her while with a ragged Frock and a Whip, humour'd a Fellow driving his M • les; till Habinas having called him, firt ki • 'd him, and then drank to him, which the other pledged; and wihing him better and better, I give you, aid he, a pair of Bus • ins.

Nor had there ever been an end of this Trumpery, had not that lat Service of Blackbirds, baked in good Pie-Crut with Raiins and Chesnuts, been brought up, and after them Quince • Peaches, o tuck with prickles, that they look'd like Hedg • hogs: Yet this might have been born with, if the next • ih had not been uch, that we had rather have tarved than touch'd it: For wh • n it was • et upon the Table, an • as we
thought, a fat Gooe, with Fihes and all kind of Fowl round it, whatever you ee here, aid Trimalchio is all made of the ame ubtance.

I, like a cunning Cur, traight apprehended what it migh • be; and turning to Agamemnon, I marvel, aid I, whether they be all mah'd together or made of Loam; for in a Saturnal at Rome, my elf aw the like imaginary hew of a Supper.

Nor had I carce aid it, when—quoth Trimalc • io, let me o grow in Etate, not Bulk, as my Cook made all this out of one Hog; there is not an excellenter Fellow than himelf; he hall, if ye pleae, make ye a Poll of Ling of a Sows Tripe; a Wood-Culver of fat Bacon; a Turtle of a Spring of Pork; and a Hen of a Collar of Brawn; and therefore of my own fancy, I gave him a Name proper to him, for he is called Daedalus: And becaue he undertands his buines, I had ChoppingKnives of the bet Steel brought him from Rome; and with that, calling for them, he turn'd them over, and admiring them, offered us the liberty of trying their Edge on his Che • k.

On this came in two Servants as quarrelling about their Collars, at which each of them had a large • arthen Pot hanging; and when Trimalchio determined the matter between them, neither of them tood to his Sentence, but fell to Club-Law, and broke each others Pots.

This Drunken Preumption put us out of order; yet cating an eye on the Combatants, we aw Oiters and Scallops running from the Pots, and another Boy receiving them in a Charger, which he carried round the Guets.

Nor was the Cook's Ingenuity hort of the ret, for he brought us a Dih of grill'd Snails on a Silver Gridiron, and with a hrill unpleaant Voice, Sang as he went. I am aham'd of what follow'd; for, what was never heard of till then, the Boys came in with a Baon of liquid Perfumes, and firt binding our Legs, Ancles and Feet, with Garlands, anointed them with it, and put the ret into the Wine Veel and the Lamps.

And now Fortunata began to Dance, and Scintilla's Hands went fater than her Tongue; when, quoth Trimalchio, Sit down Philargyrus, I give ye leave, and you Carrio, becaue you're a Green-Ribbon-Man,
and you Minophilus bid your Comrade do the like; what hall I ay more? The Family o crouded upon us, that we were almot thrut off our Beds; and who hould be eated above me, but the Cook who had made a Gooe of a Hog, all • tinking of Pickle and Kitchen-tuff; nor yet content that he ate amongt us, he fell immediately to Peronate Thepis the Tragedian, and dare his Mater to a Wager which of them two hould win the Prize next Wretling.

Trimalchio abah'd at the Challenge; My Friends, aid he, even Servants are Men; and however oppres'd by ill luck, ucked the ame Milk our elves did; and for mine, it hall not be long e're I make them Free without prejudice to my elf: to be hort, I enfranchie all of them by my lat Will and Tetament.

I give Philargyrus a Country Farm, and his he-Comrade; to Carrio an Iland, with a twentieth part of my Moveables, a Bed and its Furniture; for I make Fortunata my Heires, whom I recommend to all my Friends, and publih what I have done, to the end my Family may o love me now, as if I were dead.

All thanked their Mater for his kindnes; and he, as having forgotten trifles, called for a Copy of his Will, which he read from one end to the other, the Family all the while ighing and obbing; afterwards turning to Habinas, Tell me, my bet of Friends, aid he, do you go on with my Monument as I directed ye? I earnetly entreat ye, that at the Feet of my Statue you Carve me my little Bitch, as alo Garlands and Ointments, and all the Battles I have been in, that by your kindnes I may live when I am dead: Be ure too that it have an hundred Feet as it fronts the High-way, and as it looks towards the Fields two hundred: I will alo, that there be all orts of Fruit and Vines round my Ahes, and that in great abundance: For it is a gros mitake to furnih Houes for the Living, and take no care of th • e we are to abide in for ever: And therefore in the firt place, I will have it Engraven •
LET NO HEIR OF MINE PRETEND TO THIS MONUMENT.

And that I may receive no injury after I am dead, I'll have a Codicil annext to my Will, whereby I'll appoint one of my Freed-men the Keeper of this Monument, that the People make not a Houe-of-Office of it. Make me alo, I beeech you, on this my Monument, Ships under full Sail, and my elf in my Robes itting on the Bench, with five Gold Rings on my Fingers, and cattering Moneys among the common People; for you know I have ordered ye a Funeral Feat, and Twopence a-piece in Money. You hall alo, if you think • it, hape me ome of thee Beds we now it on, and all the People making their Court to me. On my right hand place my Fortunata's Statue, with a Dove in one hand, and leading a little Dog in her Girdle with the other: As alo my Cicero, and large Wine Veels cloe Cork'd that the Wine don't run out, and yet Carve one of them as brok • n, and a Boy weeping over it; as alo a Sun-Dial in the middle, that whoever comes to ee what's a-Clock, may read my Name whether he will or no. And latly, have a pecial conideration whether you think this Epitaph ufficient enough:
HERE RESTS CAIUS POMPEIUS TRIMALCHIO, PATRON OF THE LEARNED. A TROOP OF HORSE WAS DECREED HIM, WITHOUT SUING FOR, AND MIGHT HAVE BEEN A SENATOR WOULD HE HAVE ACCEPTED IT. A PIOUS MAN, HONEST, VALIANT, AND TRUE TO HIS FRIEND. HE RAISED • IMSELF FROM LITTLE OR NOTHING, BUT LEFT BEHIND HIM A PRODIGIOUS ESTATE, YET NEVER HEARD A PHILOSOPHER. FAREWEL TO YOU ALSO.

This aid, Trimal • hio wept plentifully, Fortunata wept, Habinas wept, and the whole Family • t up a cry as it had been his Funeral; nay, I alo whin'd for company: when, quoth Trimalchio, Since you know we mut di • , why don't we live while we may? o l •• me live my elf to ee you happy; as, if we plunge our elves in the ••• h we hall not rep • nt it: At • y <>
• e i • ; I'll lead the way, for thi •
<> is grown as hot as an Ov • n. Sa • you o, quo • h Habi • a • , no •
• m • a •• aid • o make two
days of one; and therewith got up barefoot and follow'd Trimalchio.
I on the other hand turning to A • yltos, asked him what he thought of it, for if I but ee the Bath I hall woon away.
Let's lagg behind then, aid he, and whilt they are getting in, we'll lip off in the Crowd.

The contrivance pleaed us; and o Gito leading the way through the Portico, we came to the lat Gate, where a chained Dog bolted upon us o furiouly, that Acyltos fell into the FihPond. I who had been frighted at the painted Dog, and now gotten as Drunk as Acyltos, while I endeavoured to get hold of him, fell in my elf; at lat the Porter's coming in aved us, for he quieted the Dog and drew us out; but Gito, like a harp Racal, delivered himelf, for whatever had been given him at Supper to carry home with him, he threw it the Dog, and that mollified him.

But, when hivering with cold, we deired the Porter to let us out: You're mitaken, aid he, if ye think to go ou • the ame way ye came in, for no Guet ere yet did; they came in at one Ga •• and are let out by another.

In this ad pickle, what hould we do? we found our elves in a new kind of Labyrinth, and for bathing, we'd enough of it already: However, neceity enforcing us, we pray'd him to hew us the way to the Bath: and Gito having hung out our Cloaths a drying in the Porch, we entred the Bath, which was omewhat narrow, and unk in the Earth, not unlike a Rain-water Citern; in this tood Trimalchio tark-naked: Nor could we avoid his filthy tricks; for he aid, nothing was better than to bathe in a Crowd; and that very place had in times pat been a Grinding-houe. Being weary at length, he ate down, and provok'd by the noiines of the Bath, et up his drunken Throat, and fell a murdering ome Songs of Menecrates, as they that undertood him told us.

Other Guets ran round the Citern with their Arms acros, and made a clamorous lap with their Mouths; others either try'd to take up a Ring from the Pavement, with their Hands bound behind them, or putting one Knee to the ground, to kis their great Toes backward.

While they thus entertained one another, we went into the Hot-houe that had been heated for Trimalchio; and being now recovered of our Drunkennes, were brought into another Room, where Fortunata had et out a freh Entertainment. Above the Lamps I oberved ome Womens Gewgaws. The Tables were may Silver, the Earthen Ware double gilt, and a Conduit running with Win • ; when, quoth Trimalchio, This day, my Friends, a Servant of mine opened a Barber's Shop; he's well to pas, a thri • ty Fellow, and a favourite of mine: Come, let the Floor have a drink as well as our elves; and for our part, we'll it to it till day-light.

While he was yet peaking, a Cock crow'd, at which Trimalchio grew diordered, and commanded the Win • to be thrown under Table, and prinkle the Lamps with it; then changing a Ring to his right Hand, it is not for nothing, aid he, this Trumpeter has given us notice; for either the Houe hould be on • ire, or one of the Neighbourhood will kill himelf: Far from us be it, and therefore whoever brings me this dicoverer, I'll give him a reward.

When immediately a Cock was brought in, and Trimalchio commanding to have him dret, he was torn in pieces by that exquiite Cook, who a little before had made us Fih and Fowl of a Hog, and put in a Stew-pan, and while Daedalus was taking a luty draught, Fortunata ground Pepper.
After which Trimalchio taking ome of the Banquet, bid the Waiters go to Supper, and let others upply their places.
Whereupon came in another rank of Servants, and as the former going cry'd out, Farewel, Cai • s, thoe coming in cry'd out, Sit thou merry, Caius.

And here our Mirth firt began to be diturb'd; for a beautiful Boy coming in among thoe new Servants, Trimalchio plucked the Boy to him, and did nothing but kis him over and over: Whereupon Fortunata to maintain her right, began to Rail at Trimalchio, called him pitiful Fellow, one that could not bridle his Lut, hame and dihonour to an honet Woman, and a very Dog. Trimalchio on the other hand, all confounded and vex'd at her Taunts, threw a Goblet at her Head: She fell a roaring as if he had lot an Eye, and clapt both her Hands before it.
Scintilla alo tood amazed, and covered Fortunata all trembling as he was, in her Boom; the Boy alo put a cold Pitcher to her Cheek, on which he leaned and made a lamentable wailing and blubbing.

But Trimalchio quite contrary; for, aid he, what am I the better for this graceles Buttock? 'Tis well known I took her out of a Bawdy-houe, and made her an honet Woman, but now blown up like a Frog • he bepatters her elf; a very Block, no Woman: But this poor Boy born in a Hovel, never dreams of Palaces. May my good Genius o befriend me, as I'll bring down this eeming Saint, but in her actions a Whore rampant: As inconiderable as he makes me, I might have had a Wife with Two hundred and fifty thouand Pitols; you know I don't Lye; but he was omewhat in years, and Agatho the weet Oil-man, peruaded me not to let my Name run out, when intead of doing good to her, I have put a Thorn in my own Foot; but I'll have a care that • he dig me not out of my Grave with her Nails: And that he may know what I'll do at preent, I will not, Habinas, have you put her Statue in my Monument, that
I have no words with her when I am dead: Nay, that he may know I am able to plague her, he hall not o much as kis me when I die. After this ratling, Habinas entreated him to give over his anger; There's none of us all, aid he, but ome time or other does amis; we are but Men, no Gods. Weeping Scintilla aid the ame, called him Caius, and by his own good nature, be • ought him to be paci • ied.

Trimalchio not able to hold Tears any longer, I beg of you, Habinas, aid he, and as you wih to enjoy what you have got • en, if I have done any thing without caue, pit in my • ace: I kis'd the Boy 'tis true, not for his beauty, but that he's a hopeful thri • ty Lad: He has everal Sentences by heart, can r • ad a Book at firt ight; aves Money ou • of his days Proviion; has a Binn of his own to keep it, and two drinking Cups; and does he not deerve to be in my Eye? but Fortunata, forooth, will not have it o; your bandy Legs won't away with it. Be content with your own, thou heKite, and don't diquiet me, thou Harlotry, or otherwie thou'lt • ind what I am; thou knowet well enough, if I once et on't, 'tis immoveable. But we'll remember the living.

Come my Friends, let's ee how Merry ye can be, for in my time I have been no better than your elves, but by my own indutry I am what I am: 'Tis the Heart makes a Man, all the ret is but tuff. I buy cheap and • ell dear; another Man may • ell ye other things, but I enjoy my elf: And thou Dunghilraker, art thou yet gruntling, I'll make ye hereafter do it for omewhat.

But as I was aying my Frugality brought the fortune I have: I came out of Aia no taller than this Candletick, and daily meaured my elf by it: and that I might get a Beard the ooner, rubb'd my Lips with the Candle-greae; yet I kept Ganymede to my Mater fourteen Years (nor is any thing dihonourable that the Mater commands) and the ame time contented my Mitres: Ye know what I mean, I'll ay no more, for I am no boater. By this means, as the Gods would have it, the governing the Houe was committed to me, and nothing was done but by my guidance: What need many words? He made me Joint-heir with Caear, and I had by it a Senator's Etate; but no Man thinks he has enough, and I had a mighty deire to turn Merchant. Not to detain you longer; I built five
Ships, Freighted them with Wines, which at that time were as dear as Gold, and ent them to Rome; you'll think I deired to have it o: All my Ships Founder'd at Sea; 'tis a great truth, no Story; Neptune wallowed me in one day Three hundred thouand Se • terties. Do ye think I broke upon't, (o help me Hercules) no; the Los was but a Flea-bi • e: For, as if there had been no uch thing, I built others, larger, better, and more fortunate than the former; o that every one called me a Man of Courage. As you know a great Ship carries a great deal of force, I loaded them again with Wine, Bacon, Bea • s, Unguents, Plan • s: And here Fortunata hewed her affection; for he old what he had; nay, her very Cloaths, and put a round Sum in my Pocket; tho' yet it was but a Pig of my own Sow. What the Gods will is quickly done; I got an hundred thouand Seterties by the Voyage, and forthwith redeemed the Lands my Patron had left me, built me a Houe, bought Cattle to ell them again, and whatever I went about gathered like a Snow-ball: But when I grew richer than all the Country beides, I took up, and from a Merchant turn'd Uurer, and bought Servants.

Thus reolved to give over Trading, a certain Atrologer that chanc'd to light on this Village, would have peruaded me to the contrary. He was a Gr • aeian, his Name Saerapa, on • that held Correpondence with the Gods. He told me a deal that I had forgotten, and laid every thing before me from top to bottom: He knew all I had within me, and told me what I had the Night before to Supper; you'd have thought he had liv'd with me all his life.

I beeech you, Habinas, for I think you was there; he told me the Intrigue between my Mitres and me; That I had but ill luck at Friends; that no one ever made me a return of my kindnees: That I had large Po • ions, but nourihed a Viper in my Boom: Why hould I not tell you all? I have by his Account, thirty Years, four Months, and two Days yet to live; and in a hort time hall have another Etate left me.

Thus my Fortune-teller. But if I can join my Lands here to thoe in Apulia, I hall do well enough: in the mean, and while Mercury is my Guardian, I have built this Houe: it was once you know, a pitiful Cabbin, but now as Magnificent as a Temple: it has four Dining Rooms,
twenty Bed-Chambers, two Marble Porticoes, a Gallery above Stairs, my own Apartment, another for this Viper; a very good Porter's Lodge, and the Houe capable of receiving a thouand Guets: To be hort, when ever Scaurus comes this way, he had rather lodge here than at his own Houe, tho' it lie to the Seaward: and many other Conveniencies it has, which I'll hew you by and by. Believe me, He that has a penny in his Pure, is worth a penny: Have and you hall be eteemed. And o your Friend, once no better than a Frog, is now a King.
And now Stichus bring me the Furniture in which I deign to be carried to my Funeral Pile; bring alo the Unguent, and ome of that Pot, which I ordered for the cleaning my Bones.

Stichus lingered not, but brought in a white Coverlet, and Robe of State, and pray'd us to try if they were not fine Wooll, and well Woven. And ee you Stichus, aid Trimalchio miling, that neither Mice nor Moths come at them, for if they do I'll burn you alive. I will be brought out in Pomp, that all the People may peak well of me.

With that opening a Glas Bottle of Spicknard, he caued us all to be Anointed;
and I hope, aid he, it will do as much good when I am dead, as it does while I am living: Then commanding the Wine Veels to be filled again; Fanie, aid he, you are invited to my Funeral Feat. We by this time naueated, were ready to Vomit; Trimalchio alo was gotten confoundedly Drunk, when behold a new Interlude; he called for the Coronets to come in; and, underet with Pillows, and tretching himelf at length on the Bed, uppoe me, aid he, now dead, ay omewhat, I beeech you, in praie of me.

Whereupon the Coronets ounded as it had been at a Funeral; but one above the ret, a Servant of that Freed-man of Trimalchio's, that was the bet condition'd of 'em all, made uch a thundring, that it rais'd the Neighbourhood: On which the Watch thinking the Houe was on fire, broke open the Gate, and making an Uproar after their manner, ran in with Water and Hatchets: When finding o fair an opportunity, we gave Agamemnon the lip, and eamper'd off, as it had been a real Fire.

div.head: That which follows, is Tranlated by Mr. Burnaby, of the Middle-Temple.
div.p:
NOT a Star appear'd to direct us in our way, nor would the dead of the Night give us hopes of meeting a Stranger that could; with thee, the Wine we had drank, and our ignorance of the place, even in the day time, conpir'd to mi-direct us. When we had wander'd almot an hour, with our Feet all bloody, over harp pebbles and broken hills of gravel, Gyto's diligence at lat deliver'd us: for the day before, fearing we might be at a los,
tho' we had the Sun to our help, he had providently mark'd every Pot and Pillar with a Chalk, the greatet darknes was not able to obcure, by whoe hineing whitenes we found our way. But we had as many fears after we got to an Inn; for the Hotes, having drank a little too long with her Guets, had o intirely lot her S • n • s, a burning could not have made her feel; that, perhaps, we had been forc'd to have taken up our Lodging i •
• he Street, if a LetterCarrier that belong'd to Trimalchio, with ten Carriages of his Mater's Revenue, had not come in the mean time; who without much ado beat down the door, and let us in at the ame gap.

After we enter'd the Bed-Chamber, h • ving plentifully • eated; pret by impa
• ient Na • ure, I • ook my Gyto aide; and, w • apt in Pl • aur • s, pent the Night.
div.l: <> can t •• C •• rms of that blet Night declare,
•• w o • t ye • ods! • ur warm Embraces were?

W •
• ugg'd • w •
• ling'd, and thro' each other's Lips,
Our Souls, like meeting Streams, together mixt;
•• rewell the World, and all its Pageantry!
W •• n I, a M • rtal! o begin to Dye.
div.p: 'Tis without Reaon I hug my elf; for Acyltos, the caue of all my Misfortunes, eeing me Drunk, and incapable to hold my Prize, tole the Boy from my Bed, and conveying him to his own, freely injoy'd another's Right: Gyto, not enible of the change, or diembling it, in a Stranger's Arms lept, ecure of our mutual Contract. When I aroe, finding my elf robb'd of all; if there's any Truth in a Lover, I had half an inclination to Murder both, and end them noring into t'other world: But following a ecurer Thought, I rais'd Gyto with blows, and looking as ternly as I cou'd upon Acyltos, thus addres'd my elf: Since you've play'd the Villain by your Treachery, and breaking the common Laws of Friendhip, pack up your Matters quickly, and find another Comrade to abue.

Acyltos conented; and, after we had made an exact diviion of our Booty; now, ays he, let's hare the Boy too: I believ'd it a jet at parting, but, he with a Murderous reolution, drew his Sword, nor hall you, added he, think to ingros this prize, which hould, like the ret, be common to us both. I mut have my hare, or with this Sword will be content
to take it. Upon which, on the other ide, having twited my gown under my arm, I made advances to Ingage.

The unhappy Boy ruh'd between, and, Kiing both our knees, with tears, entreated, that we would not expoe * our elves in a pitiful Alchoue, nor with our blood pollute the Rites of o dear a Friendhip: but, raiing his voice, ays he, if there mut be Murder, behold my naked boom, hither direct your fury: 'Tis I deerve death, who violated the acred Laws of Friendhip.

Upon which we heath'd our Swords; and firt Acyltos, I'll, ays he, end the difference: Let the Boy himelf follow the man he likes, that, in chuing a Friend, at leat, he may have an unquetion'd liberty.

I, that preum'd o long an acquaintance, had made no light impreions on his Nature, was o far from fearing, that with an eager hate I accepted the proffer, and to the Judge committed the dipute: Gyto, that he might not eem to conider, at my conent jump'd up, and Choe Acyltos.

I, like one thundertruck, at the entence, void of defence, fell upon the bed; and had not urviv'd the los, if
envy of my Rival had not topp'd my Sword.
Acyltos, proud of the conquet, goes off with the Prize, leaving me expos'd in a trange place, that a little before he cares'd as a Friend and harer of his Fortune.
div.l: 'Tis in the World, as in a Game at Ches;
We erve our Friends but where our profit is.
When Fortune miles, we're yours, and yours alone;
But when he • rowns, the ervile Herd are gone.
So, in a Play, they Act with mimick Art,
Father, or Son, or griping Mi • rs part:
But when at lat the Comick Scenes are or'e,
They quit the Viards they aum'd before.
div.p:
Nor did I there very long complain, for fearing one Menalaus, an Uher of a School, might, among other Misfortunes, find me alone in the Inn, I made up my Wallet, and, very penive, took me a Lodging in a private place near the Sea: there, after I had been mewd up for three days, reflecting afreh on my depis'd and abject condition, I beat my breat, as • ick as it was; and, when my deep ighs wou'd uffer me, often cry'd out; Why has not the Earth burt open, and wallow'd me?
Why has not the Sea o'rewhelm'd me, that repects not even the Innocent themelves? Have I been a Murderer? when I had violated Lycas's Wife, have I fled jutice? have I ecap'd even when I was condemn'd to Dye, to live in a trange place, to have my Name recorded only among Beggars and Vagabonds? and who condemn'd me to this olitude?—A Boy! One who is a protitute to all manner of Lut; and by his own confeion deerves to dye; whom Sodomy has enobl'd from a Slave; who was publickly contracted with as a Girl, by one that knew he was of the other Sex: and what a wretch is that other, ye Gods! whom, when he might have writ Man, his Mother perwaded even out of his Sex, and putting on Petty-coats, was condemn'd to a Maids Office in a Prion: who, after he had pent what he had, and chang'd the cene of his Lut; having contracted an old Friendhip, baely left it; and, frontles impudence! like a hot Whore, for one night's pleaure, old his Friend. Now the Lovers lye whole nights lockt in each others arms, and who knows but in thoe intervals they recruit their weary'd Strength, may laugh at me: but they han't go off o, for if I'm a man, or a
freeborn one at leat, I'll make their blood compenate the injury.
