Having thus aid, I girt on my Sword; and le • t I hou'd be too weak to maintain the war, encourag'd my elf with a lu • y Meal, and making out of doors, like one poet, earch'd every place: but whilt, with a wild ditracted countenance, I thought of nothing but blood and laughter; and oft with execrations laying my hand on my Sword, a Souldier, perhaps ome Cheat or Padder, oberv'd me, and making up to me, askt to what Regiment or Company I, his Brother Souldier, belong'd? when, with a good aurance, I had cheated him into a belief of the Regiment and Company; well, but Friend, aid he, looking down, do • the Souldiers of your Company walk in uch hoes? I began to look guilty, and by my trembling dicover'd the Lye I had told him: upon which he made me lay down my Arms, and bid me take care of the wort. Thus tript, nay and thus rob'd of my Revenge, I return'd to my Lodging, where by degrees my fears abating, I began in my mind to thank the Robber.

But finding it difficult • to wean my elf from the love of Revenge, I pent half the night very penively; and riing
• by day-break,to eae me of my grief, and thoughts of my injury, I rov'd about every where, till at lat going into a publick Gallery, very wonderful for everal • orts of excellent Painting; I aw ome by Zeuxy's hand, that had not yet yielded to the injures of time: And, not without an awful reverence, behold others by Protogenes, which tho they were firt tryals, yet diputed for exactnes, even with Nature it elf: but on the other ide viewing a Celebrated Piece drawn by Apelles; I even ador'd the Work of o Great a Mater: 'twas o correctly finiht to the life, you'd have worn it an Image of the Soul too. One ide gave the Story of the Eagle Bearing Jupiter to Heaven, the other the fair Hylas repelling the Addrees of the lew'd Naiad: in another part was Apollo, angry at himelf for killing his Boy Hyacinth; and, to hew his love, crown'd his Harp with the Flower that prung form his Blood.

In this Gallery, as in a Viion of living Images, I cry'd out; And are not the Gods themelves ecure from love? Jupiter in his Seraglio above, not finding one that can pleae his appetite, ins upon Earth, yet injures no body: the Nymph wou'd have tifl'd her paion for Hylas,
had he believ'd the luty Hercules wou'd have been his Rival: Apollo turns Hyacinth into a Flower: and every Image enjoy'd its Wihes without a Rival: but I have cares'd, as the dearet Friend, the greatet Villian.

While I was thus talking to my elf, there enter'd the Gallery an old Man, with a Face as pale as age had made his Hair; and eem'd, I know not how, to bring with him the air of a great oul; but viewing his Habit, I was eaily confirm'd in my opinion, ince Fortune eldom deals favourably with Learned Men. In hort, he made up to me, and addreing himelf, told me he was a Poet; and, as he hop'd, above the common herd: if, added he, my merrit don't uffer by Applaue that's promicuouly given, to the good and bad.
Why therefore, interrupted I, are you o meanly Clad? On this account return'd he, becaue Learning never made any man rich.
div.l: The Merchant's profit well rewards his toil:
The Souldier crowns his Labours with the Spoil:
To ervile Flattery we Altars raie:
And the kind Wife her Stallion ever pays:
But tarving Wit in rags takes barren pain:
And, dying, eeks the Mues Aid in vain.
div.p: 'Tis certain, added he, that a Lover of Virtue, on the account of his ingularity, meets with contempt; for who can approve what differs from himelf? And that thoe who admire Riches, wou'd fain poes every body, that nothing is more reaonable than their Opinion; whence they ridicule, as well as they can, the Learned few; that they, like themelves, might eem within the power of Money.
I don't know, how Learning and Poverty become Relations, aid I, and igh'd: You jutly lament, return'd he, the condition of Scholars.

You mitake me, aid I, that's not the occaion of my ighs, there's another, and much greater Caue: And, as all Men are Naturally inclin'd to communicate their grief; I laid open my Cae to him, beginning with Acyltos's Treachery, which I aggravated; and, with repeated ighs, often wiht his Injutice to me might have deerv'd pardon: but that now he was a taunch Villain, and in Lut more ubtle than the Bawds themelves.

p.q: The Old Man, eeing me incere, began to comfort me; and the better to effect it, told me what formerly had happen'd to himelf on the like occaion

div.p: When I was in Aia, began he, I Lodg'd at the Houe of one Pergamus: where the Entertainment did not tempt me to tay o much, as a very beautiful Boy I aw there, Son to the Mater of the houe: my contrivance was to act the Lover, unupected by the Father: and to effect my Wihes, I us'd this method: when ever in their mirth they happen'd to mention the ue of beautiful Boys, I diembl'd uch a horrour of it, and with that evere concern pretended my modety uffer'd by uch dicoure, that the Mother, epecially, lookt upon me as a Philoopher, that was above the little pleaures of the world. Upon this I was deir'd to be Tutor to the Boy, not only to intruct him in a Method of tudy, but imform his Mind with Principles of Honour and Honety, let they hould by accident entertain ome man that might have wicked deigns on his body.

There happen'd a Solemn Fetival, whoe ports entertain'd us o long, that
excus'd my being in the Bed-Chamber with him at M • d-night: when finding him not yet a-leep, in a timorous whiper addreing my elf to Venus, Mitres of our deires, aid I, Could I have the happines to Kis the Boy, and he not know it to morrow, I'll preent him with a pair of Turtles.

Hearing the Reward, he began to nore; upon which, I greedily eiz'd my wihes: atisfi'd with this beginning, early the next morning, the Boy expecting it, I perform'd my promie. The Night after, having the ame opportunity, I advanc'd my deires; and if I cou'd with my hand, aid I, but rub him up, and he not know it, I'll have a pair of GameCocks at his Service: At this, the Boy turn'd to me, and I believe, was half a • raid I hou'd fall a • leep before I had done: I oon undeceiv'd him, and with inexpreible pleaure injoy'd my wihes: the day following, he gladly receiv'd what I promis'd him: The third Night, I had the like acces to him, and proceeding to a bolder liberty, put my Mouth to his Ear, (who was repeating his Dog-leep) and, ye Gods! aid I, could I now eize that wiht for joy entire, that neither dare, nor can be expret
to morrow, I'll preent him with a Turkih-Barb, on this condition that he does not feel me; upon which, he diembled the ecuret Sleep I ever knew: wild to enjoy, I pret his nowy breats, that welling eem'd to meet my hands, and, half mothering him with Kies, haten'd to that lat and greatet joy that bounded all my wihes: The Morning after, he waited as he us'd in the Bed-Chamber, expecting me: You may imagine, the Turtles and Cocks were eaier to be purchat, than o fine a Hore: but beide the Charge, I fear'd o great a Preent, might make my Honourable pretenions for the Boy upected: on this account, I delay'd my Viit ome hours; when going to him, waving the uual Ceremonies, I only Kit him; the Boy, as his Arms were about my neck, looking round; I beeech you, Sir, aid he, where's the Hore?

p.q: The difficulty of getting a Fine one, return'd I, made me defer the Preent, but in a few days I'll be as good as my word: the Boy well knew the meaning of my delay, and his Countenance betray'd a Reentment.

div.p:
This dicoure diverting my grief, I began to quetion the old Gentleman about the Antiquity of ome Pieces, the Stories of others I was not acquainted with, the Reaon why this Age don't come up to the former, and why the mot excellent Arts are lot, of which Painting has not left the leat ign of its being? Our love of Riches, reply'd he, has been the only occaion: for in old time, when Virtue was admir'd for its own ake, all Liberal Arts flouriht, and the only emulation among Men, was to make Dicoveries that might profit the Age. 'Twas in thoe times Democritus, content with Poverty, found out the Vertue of mot Herbs; and le • t there might be any hidden Excellence in Stones and Trees, pent the ret of his Life in Experiments about them: 'Twas then Eudoxu •
abandon'd the World, to live on the top of a high Mountain, to
dicover the motions of the Heavens and Criippus, the better to qualify his mind for invention, went thrice through a coure of Phyick.

But to return to Imagery, Lyippus with that diligence imploy'd himelf about one Statue, that, neglecting his Living, he dyed, for want: and Myron, whoe brazen Images of Men and beats, you might have mitaken for living ones, dy'd very poor: but our Age is o wholly devoted to Drinking and Whoring, we're o far from inventing, that we don't acquaint our elves even with thoe Arts that are found to our hands: But, accuing, Antiquity our Schools become Seminaries of Vice only • what's our Logick? How little do we know of Atronomy? Where's our Philoopher? What Mater of Eloquence could indure to hear it o murdred in a Pulpit? What Wie Man cou'd uffer the noie? Our buines in the Temple is not to inform our minds, or correct our lives; but as oon as we enter the place, one out of love to his Friend, being made his Heir, promies a Sacri • ice to the Gods, if they'd pleae to take him out of this troubleome world; another, if they'd direct him to a Treaure: the like a
third promies if they'd make him happy in a mall Etate of 300. l. per An. or o: The very Senate that hou'd how an Exemplary Conduct, in Occaions of doubtful Events, have devoted mighty ums of Gold to Religious ues: And who wou'd not but admire, that, he is perwaded hath Charms enough to make the Gods themelves comply! You need not wonder why Painting is lot, when Gold appears more beautiful both to Gods and Men, than any thing Apelles or Phidias are now eteem'd madly to have pent their time about: But eeing your Curioity is wholly taken up with that piece, that hews you a contracted Hitory of the Siege of Troy: I'll try to give you the Story more at large in Vere.

lg.l:
Now Troy
• ad •• lt a Si • g • of Ten long Years,
Concern and Sorrow in each Face appears:
The Grecian Prop •• t too, with Terrour fill'd,
What Fate decreed, but doubtfully reveal'd:

div.l: When thus Apollo—

lg.l: From the proud Top of Ida's riing Hill
A lofty Pile of mighty C • dars fell,
Whoe Trunks into a dreadful Fabrick force,
And, let it bear the Figure of a Hore:
The pacious hollows, of whoe Mountain-Womb,
The Choice and Flower of your Troops Entomb.
The Greeks, enrag'd to be o long repell'd,
With their chief Troops the Beats vat Bowels fill'd,
And thus their Arms and all their Hopes conceal'd.
Strange was the Fate that rul'd unhappy Troy,
Who thought them gone, and lating Peace t'enjoy.
So the Incription of the Machine aid,
And Treacherous Synon, for our ruin made.
All from their Arms at once, and troubles run
To view the Hore, and left th'unguarded Town:
So over-joy'd they wept: Thus even fears
When joy urprizes, melt away in Tears.
Enrag'd Laocoon, with Prophetick heat,
Pret thro' the Crowd, that on his Humour wait;
And with a Javelin pierc'd the fatal Hore,
But Fate retards the blow, and topt its force:
The Spear jumpt back upon the Priet, o nigh,
It gave new Credit to the Treachery.
Yet to confirm how weak was the attempt
'Gaint what the Gods will have, his Javelin ent,
Reum'd with double fury, thro' his ide,
And the large Concave of the Machine try'd:
When from within the Captive Grecians roar;
And the Beat trembles with anothers fear.
Yet to the Town the Preent they convey,
Thus a new Stratagem does Troy betray;
While to the Taken, he becomes a Prey.
But other Monters there enform our Eyes,
What mighty Seas from Tenedos arie!
The frighted Neptune eems to e • k the Shore,
With uch a noie, with uch a dreadful roar:
As in a ilent Night, when, from a • ar,
The dim • l ound of Wrecks invades the Ear:
When rolling on the Waves two mighty Sn • kes,
Unhappy Troy decry'd; whoe circling Stroaks,
Had drov • the welling urges on the Rocks.
Like lofty Ships they on the Billows ride,
And with rais'd Breats the foaming Flood divide:
Their Crets they brandih and red • ye-balls raie •
That all ar •• nd dipence a Sulp • u • ous Bla •• .
To Shore advancing, now the W •• es appear
All Fire; unwonted ra • lings •• ll th • Air.
The Ocean trembles at their dr • ad •• l H •• s;
And holy Wreaths their acred Temples bind,
Laocoon's Sons were by the Snakes entwi • 'd:
Now t'ward • Heaven their Little Hands are thrown
Each for his Brother, not him • lf does moan,
And prays to ave his ruin by his own.
Both dye at lat, thro' fear each other hou'd;
And to give Death a greater Pomp, the Good Ground
Laocoon to their recue vainly run,
Now gorg'd with Death, they drag him on the
Up to the Altar, where devoted lies
The Priet himelf, a panting Sacri • ice.
Thus with his Blood the Temple they prophane;
Loing their Gods, Troy's ruin thus began:
Now the bright Taper of the Night appears
Gayly attended with a train of Stars:
When midt the Trojans, dead in Sleep and Win • ,
The Grecians Execute their dire Deign:
W • en from the open'd C • verns of the Hore,
And now deliver'd, leave their Hore and f • ar,
With the ame wanton motions Colts appear:
When from the Plow, and •• avy Collar freed,
They hake their riing Cre • s, and try their peed.
Their Swords they Brandih, and their Shi • lds they r • ar,
And • ix their Helme • s, then begin the War:
A Party • here o'th' Drunk • n Trojans light,
Another there now make their Altars moke,
And againt Troy, Troy's Guardian Gods invoke.

div.p: When Eumolpus had gone thus far in his Story, the People that were walking there, began to • ling Stones at him: But he, concious of his Merit, cover'd his Head, and took up his Heels: I, fearing they wou'd have taken me for a Poet too, made after him: When we were out of Stone hot of the Enemy, I beeech you, Sir, aid I, what will you do with this Dieae of yours? I don't wonder at the Peoples humour, ince I have hardly been acquainted with you two hours, and your Entertainment has been more Poetry, than the Converation of a Man. I think I mut • ill my Pocket with Stones, that when I perceive you going into a Fit • I may bleed you in the Head for it, with one of 'em.

He turn'd to me, and, Dear Child, aid he, I roe to day without conulting my Fortune; tho' 'tis confet I eldom appear even on the Stage, but uch a Mobb as this are Laughing at me: But that I may not be at difference with you too, I'll tye my elf up from this humour of Poetry: Well, well, aid I, on that condition I Sup with you; upon which, going into the poor Cottage I lodg'd at, we order'd the Mater of it to get us a Supper, and in the mean time
we went to the Bagnio, where I aw Gito tanding againt the Wall, with Towels and Rubbing-Bruhes in his hand; his troubled Countenance eaily perwaded me he erv'd on Compulion: As oon as he aw me, with joy Addreing himelf, he told me, that ince I was not in that Martial poture that once frighted him to belye his Affections, he cou'd freely peak t • me, upon which he entreated me to pity his Circumtances; and, if I cou'd but deliver him from o Barbarous a Mater, ince he was now orry he was forc'd to be my judge, I might take my atisfaction in any Punihment I'de pleae to inflict; for, added he, i • I mut dye, 'twill be comfort enough to o unhappy a Wretch to think that you are pleas'd in't.

I deir'd him wave his Complaints, le • t our Deign hou'd be dicover'd, and leaving Eumolpus (for in the Bath he was ver •• ying) we made off thro' a dirty Back-Entry, as privately as we could to my Lodgings: Where, hutting the Door, I threw my Arms about his neck, and, tho' he was all in tears, half mother'd him with Kies: Thus we continu'd without a word from either ide: Gito's repeated Sobs o diturb'd him, he could
not peak: When after a long time pent in that poture, how unaccountable is it, began I, to Love him that once forook me! and that in this Breat I hou'd feel o great a Wound, yet have no ign of its being there! what's your pretence for chuing Acyltos? Have I deerv'd uch uage?

After he found I till had Love for him, he began to look les concern'd: When, added I, I'm o far from deireing an Umpire to judge of th' ingratitude of your Choice, that I neither complain of, or deign to remember it; if I find you incere.

I cou'd not tell him this without a Tear: When, wiping his face, ays he, Eucolpius, I appeal to your Memory, whether I le •• you, or you betray'd me. I mut confes, and hope you can't blame me; when I aw two at Daggers-Drawing, that I ran to the tronget.
I cou'd not but admire his Wit, and to convince him of a perfect Reconciliation, eal'd it with repeated Kies.

'Twas now quite dark, and our Supper was Dihing up; when Eumolpus knock'd at the Door: I ask'd how many there was of 'em: And took an opportunity through a Chink, to ee whether
Acyltos was with him: But finding him alone, I oon open'd the Door: He had hardly fixt himelf on his Couch, when eeing Gito in waiting, on my word, aid he, a very Ganymed; ure Eucolpius, you'll have no reaon to complain to day.

I did not like o oberving an entry; and was afraid I had entertain'd another Acyltos. Eumolpus puruing his Humour, when the Boy fill'd him a Glas, I had rather, aid he, be in poeion of thee, than the whole Bagnio; and greedily drinking it off, the heat I've been in, added he, made this the pleaantet Draught I ever took: For to deal freely with ye, I narrowly cap'd a beating, for attempting, when I was in the Bath, to deliver my Thoughts of it in Vere: And after I was turn'd out of the Bagnio, as I us'd to be out of the Theatre; I earch'd every place, crying as loud as I cou'd, Eucolpius, Eucolpius: A Naked Youth that had lot his Cloaths, as trongly Echo'd back to me, Gito, • ito: The Boys, believing me Mad, ridicul'd me with their Mimikry: But the other was attended with a great Concoure of People, that with an awful Admiration prais'd the Youth: For Nature had o largely qualify'd him for a Lover, his
Body eem'd but as the Skirt of the mighty Member it bore: A luty Rogue! I'll warrant, he'd maintain the Field four and twenty hours! He therefore oon found relief; for ome Debauch'd Spark, a Roman Knight, as was reported, flung his Cloak over him, and took him home, with hopes I preume to engros o great a prize: But I was o far from meeting uch Civility, that even my own Cloaths were kept from me, till I brought one that knew me, to atisfie 'em in my Character: So much more profitable 'tis to improve the Body, than the Mind.

Whilt Eumolpus was telling his Story, I often chang'd Countenance: Looking glad at the ill Fortune of my Rival, but troubled at his good: Yet did not interrupt him, le • t he hou'd dicover my Concern; and when he had done, I told him what we had for Supper.

I had hardly given him an account, e're our Entertainment came in: 'Twas common homely Food, but very nourihing: Our half tarv'd Doctor attacqu'd it very briskly, but when he had well fill'd himelf, began to tell us, Philoophers were above the World; and to ridicule thoe that condemn every
thing, becaue 'tis common, and only admire thoe things that are difficult to be had: Thee Vicious Appetites • added he, that depie what they can cheaply come by, never tate any thing pure, but, like ick Men, love only thoe things that are hurtful to 'em.
div.l: What's oon obtain'd, we naueouly receive,
All hate the Victory that's got with leave:
We corn the Goods our happy Ile brings forth,
But love whatever is of foreign growth:
Not that the Fih that ditant Waters feed,
Do thoe excel that in our Climate breed;
But thee are Cheaply taken, thoe came far,
With difficulty got, and cot us dear:
Thus the kind She, abroad, we admire above
Th' inipid Lump, at Home, of Lawful Love •
Yet once enjoy'd, we trait a new deire,
And abent Pleaures only do admire.
div.p:
Is this, aid I, interrupting him, what you promis'd, that you wou'd not verifie to day agen? I beeech you, Sir, at leat pare us that never pelted you: For if any of the Inn hou'd find we have a Poet in our Company, the whole • eighbourhood wou'd be rais'd, and we hou'd dye Martyrs for a wrong Opinion:
If nothing ele will make you pity us, think of the Galery and Bath you c • me from: when I had treated him after this rate, the good Natur'd Gito, correcting me, aid, I did very ill to rail at a Man o much my Elder; and that having offer'd a Gentleman the Curteie of my Table, I hou'd not o far forget good breeding, to affront him when he came: With many the like Expreions, attended with a bluh at their delivery, that extreamly became him.

Happy the Woman, aid Eumolpus, that's blet with uch a Son! Heaven encreae your Virtue; o much ence, and o much beauty we eldom meet with in any one Peron: But, le • t you hou'd think your Civility thrown away, you have found a Lover for it: I'll give th • World your Praies in Vere: I'll be your Servant, your Gardian, and will follow you every where: Nor can Eucolpius think himelf injur'd, he Loves another.

Eumolpus was oblig'd to the Souldier that robb'd me of my Sword, ele I had turn'd the fury upon him I meant for Acyltos: Gito reading it in my Countenance, under pretence of fetching Water, prudently withdrew: And allay'd
my heat, by removing one caue of it: But my rage reviving, Eumolpus, aid I, I had rather have heard even your Veres, than you propoe to your elf uch hopes: I am very Paionate, and you are very Lutful: Conider how improbable 'tis we hou'd agree; believe therefore • I am mad, and humour the Phrenzy; that is, be gone immediately.

At this Eumolpus was in great Confuion, and, without asking the occaion of my Paion, preently made out: But drawing the Door after him, what I did not in the leat upect, he lock'd me in, and tealing the Key out of the Door, ran in pur • uit of Gito.

The Rage I was in to be o abus'd, put me upon Hanging my elf; and having ty'd an Apron, I found in the Room, to the Bed-tead, committed my Neck to the Nooe I had made with its Strings: When Eumolpus and Gito came to the Door, and entering, prevented my Deign: Gito, his Grief growing to a Rage, made a great out-cry, and forcing me on the Bed, you're mitaken, aid he, Eucolpius, if you fancy it poible for you to dye before me: I was firt in t • e D • ign, and had not urviv'd my choice of Acyltos; if I had met with
an Intrument of Death: But had not you come to my Relief in the Bath, I had reolv'd to throw my elf out of the Window: And that you may know how ready Death is to wait thoe that deire it; ee—I've got that you o lately endeavour'd.

Upon which, having natch'd a Raor from Eumolpus's Servant, he truck three or four times at his Throat, and fell down before us; frightned at the Accident, I cry'd out, and falling upon him e're he had reach'd the Ground, with the ame Weapon endeavour'd to follow him: But neither had Gito any appearance of a Wound, nor did I feel my elf hurt: For it happen'd to be a dull Raior, deign'dly made o, to prepare Learners of the Art to handle a harper: Which was the reaon Eumolpus did not offer to prevent our Mimick Deaths, nor his Man look concern'd when the Raior was natch'd from him.

While this Scene was Acting, the InnKeeper came in upon us, with the other part of our Supper; and viewing the obcene poture we were in, I beeech you, Sirs, aid he, are ye Drunk, or have fled Jutice, and are Acting it on your elves, or both? ho! who was going to make a
Gibet of the Bed? What private deigns are here on foot? What—was your going out but now with intent to Bilk me? But you hall feel for't: I'll oon make ye know who rules here.

What, you Racal, Crys Eumolpus, do you threat too? And without more ado flung his Fit in his face: The Inn-Keeper took up an Earthen Pitcher we o oft had empty'd, and ending it at Eumolpus, broke his Forehead, and immediately ran down Stairs: Eumolpus, impatient of Revenge, natching up a great Wooden Candletick, made after him; and pouring his blows very thick on the InnKeeper, repair'd the injury with Interet: This alarm'd the whole Houe, and whilt the ret of his Gues, that by this time were mot of 'em Drunk; ran to ee what was the matter, taking an opportunity to revenge the injury Eumolpus had offer'd me, I lock'd him out; and turning thus his trick upon himelf, at once, enjoy'd the Bed and Board without a Rival.

In the mean time, the Ilanders (that came in at the butle) and Cooks with all their Kitchin Artillery et upon Eumolpus: One throws at his head a hot Spit with the Meat on't; another with
a Pitchfork puts himelf in a Martial poture againt him; but epecially a BlearEy'd Old Woman, who tucking up the dirty Apron he had about her, with one Shoe on, and another off, hall'd a great Matiff and et him at Eumolpus: But with the wooden Candletick he defended himelf againt all his Enemies.

We aw all through a Hole they had made by wrenching the Latch from the Door: I wih'd him well you may imagine; but Gito had Compaion, and wou'd have uccour'd the Ditret Eumolpus; upon which, my Rage continuing, I gave his pitying Head two or three blows with my Fit; he ate down on the Bed and cry'd: But I o eagerly ply'd the Hole, I made my Eyes relieve each other; and, encouraging the People againt him, with great atisfaction beheld the conlict: when the Bailiff of the Iland, one Bargates, whom the Scuffle had rais'd from Supper; was brought into the Room, upported by others Legs, for he was o troubl'd with the Gout, he cou'd not ue his own: And having in his Clownih manner, with a great deal of heat, made a long Harangue againt Drunkards and Vagabonds, looking on Eumolpus, ha! what is it you, ays he,
the Excellent Poet? What—has thee Rogues been abuing you all this while?

At what time he goes up to Eumolpus, and in a whiper, I have a Maid, ays he, that flouts at me when I ask her the Quetion; Prithee, if you have any Love for me, abue her in a Copy of Veres till he's aham'd of her elf.

While Eumolpus was thus ingag'd with Bargates, the Cryer of the Town, and ome other Officer, attended with a great Concoure of People, entred the Inn; and, haking a moaky rather than lighted Torch he carried, mouths out this; viz.
Not long ago run away from the Bath, a very pretty Boy, with curl'd Hair, by Name, Gito.
If any Man, or Woman, in City, or Country, can tell Tale or Tidings of him, hall have for his Reward 1000 Seterces.
Not far from the Cryer, tood Acyltos, Clad with a Coat of many Colours; who, to incourage any Dicoverer, held the Reward in a Silver Charger before him.
Upon this, I order'd Gito to teal under the Bed, and thrut his F •• t and Hands through the Cords; that, as Vl • es formerly hid in a S • eeps Hide, o extended he might cheat the Searchers.

Gito immediately obey'd the motion, and fixing himelf, as I directed, ou • -did vlyes in his Native Art: But, that I might leave no room for Supicion, I o dipos'd the Bed-Cloaths, that none could believe more than my elf had lain there.

We had jut done, when Acyltos, with a Beadle, having earch'd the other Chambers, came to ours, which gave him greater hopes, becaue he found the Door o barr'd: But the Petty Officer he brought, with an Iron Crow, for • 'd it open.

Upon Acyltos's Entry, I threw my elf at his feet, and beeech'd him, if he had any memory of our pat Friendhip; or any repect for one that • ad ha • 'd Misfortunes with him, he wou'd at leat let me ee the till dear Gi • o: A • d to give my ham-intreaties a better colour, I ee, ays I, Acyltos, you are come with Deigns on my Life; for to what other end could you bring thoe Miniters of Jutice? Therefore atisfi • your Rage,
behold my naked Boom, let out that Blood, which, under pretence of a earch, you come to eek.

Acyltos, now laying aide his old grudg • to me; profes'd he came in puruit of nothing but Gito, that had run from him; nor deir'd the Death of any Man, much more of one that falls before him; and whom, after a fatal Quarrel with him, he held mot dear.

The Petty Officer was not o eaie to me, for taking a Stick out of the InnKeeper' • hand, he felt under the Bed with it, and run it into every Hole he • ound in the Wall: Gito drew his Body • ut of the Stick's way, and, breathing as •• ntly as •• ar cou'd make him, held his • outh cloe to the Cords.

They were hardly gone, e're Eumolpus boun •• d in upon us, for the broken • oor cou'd • op no body; and, in a g •• at h • at, cry'd out •
• 'll earn the Reward: I'll make a • t • r the Cryer, and let him know how oon Gito may be in his Cutody.

Eumolpus puruing his deign, I kit his Knees, and intreated him not to anticipate the • nd of dying Men; you wou'd be jutly angry, added I, if you hou'd dicover to 'em how you are deceiv'd:
The Boy run into the Crowd undicover'd, and where he is gone, my elf can't upect. I b • eech you, Eumolpus, bring back the Boy, or at leat retore him even to Acyltos.

Jut as I had work'd him to a belief, Gito, with retraining his breath, nees'd thrice o throughly, that he hook the Bed; at which Eumolphus, turning about, aluted him with, God bles you, Sir; and, taking the Bedding aide, aw the little Vlyes, who might have rais'd Compaion, even in a Blood-thirty Cyclops; then looking u • on me, Thou Villain, ays he, how have you hamm'd me? Durt you not tell truth, even when you was catch'd in a Roguery? If ome God, that has the • are of Humane Affairs, had not forc'd the Boy to dicover himelf, I had wander'd in earch of him to a ine purpoe. But Gito, that cou'd • awn much better than I, took a Cobweb dipt in Oyl, and apply'd to the Wound in his Forehead: And, changing his torn Coat for his own Mantle, imbrac'd the now reconcil'd Eumolpus, and • uck to his Lips; at lat he • pok • , and, Our Lives, aid he, mot indulgent Father, our Lives are in your power; if you love your Gito, convince him that you do, by preerving
him: O! could I now meet a Grave in flames or waves, that I, the only caue of all, might end your Quarrels with my life.

p.q: Eumolpus, concern'd at our grief, and particularly mindful of Gito's tendernes to him; urely, ays he, y' are the greatet of Fools, who have Souls enrich'd with Virtues, that may make ye happy, yet live a continu'd Ma • tyrdom, raiing to your elves every day new Occaions of grief; I, wherever I am, make my Life as pleaant and free from trouble, as if I expected no more of it: If you'll imitate me, never let Cares diturb your Quiet. And to avoid Acyltos that haunts ye in thee parts, I am taking a Voyage to a Foreign Country, and hou'd be glad of your Company: I believe to morrow Night I hall go on board the Veel: I am very well known there, and you need not doubt of a Civil Entertainment.

His advice appear'd to me both wie, and profitable; for at once it deliver'd me from Acyltos, and gave me hopes of living more happy: Thus oblig'd by Eumolpus's good nature, I was orry for the late injury I had done him, and began
to repent I appear'd his Rival, ince it had occaion'd o many Diaters.

div.p: At lat, with Tears, I beeech'd him to be Friends with me too, for that it was not in a Rival's power to bound his Rage; yet, that I wou'd try neither to ay, or do any thing that may offend him: And hop'd o wie and good a Man as he, wou'd leave in his Mind no ign of a former Quarrel: for 'twas with Men as with Countrys, on rude and neglected Grounds Snows lay very long, but where the fruitful Earth was improv'd by Culture, they preently melt off, and hardly leave a Print behind: Thus unfahion'd Minds can't dicharge their Paions uddenly, but where Souls are inrich'd with intruction, they but appear, and vanih.

And to confirm the Truth of what you ay, return'd Eumolpus, all my heat expires in this Kis; but, to prevent the deigns of your Enemies, haten with your Wallets, and either follow me, or, if ye like it, act the Leaders.

He had not done peaking, when, hearing the Door move, we turn'd about, and aw a Seaman, with a Beard that made him appear terribly Grim: who aluted Eumolpus with a Why dy'e tay, as if
you did not kn • w how near the time 'twas?
All immediately prepare for the March, Eumolpus Loads his Servant, who had been all this while aleep; I, and Gito, pack'd our Things together, and, thanking our Stars, enter'd the Veel.

We fixt our elves, as much out of the way as we could, under Deck; and it being not yet day, Eumolpus fell a-leep: I, and Gito, cou'd not take a wink: When reflecting afr • h, that I had harbour'd in my Acquaintance, a Rival more powerful than Acyltos; I began to be much troubled: But wiely allaying my Grief, I thus reaon'd with my elf. Is it o troubleom to hare what we love? when the bet of Nature's works are in common? The Sun throws his Rays on all. The Moon, with her infinite train of Stars, erves to light even Beats to their Fodder: What below can boat an Excellence of Nature above the Waters? Yet they • low in publick for the ue of all: Only Love e • ms weeter tol'n, than when it's given us: So it is, we e • eem nothing, unles 'tis • nvy'd by others; but what have I to • ear in a Rival, that Age and Impotence conpire to
render diagreeable? Who, when he has an inclination, his Body jades under him before he can reach the Goal.

When I had cheated my elf with this aurance, I muffled my Head in my Coat, and feign'd my elf aleep: But on a udden, as if Fortune had reolv'd to ruin my Quiet; I heard one above Deck groaning out: And has he corn'd me • This truck me with a trembling, for it was a Man's voice, and one I was afraid I knew: But at a greater ditance, with the ame heat, I heard a Woman Lamenting: O that ome God • aid he, wou'd bring my Gito to my Arms; tho' he banih'd himelf thence; how kindly wou'd I receive him!

So unexpected a thing drove the colour from our Cheeks: I epecially, as in a Trance, was a long time peechles; when, trembling with fear, I pull'd Eumolpus by the Coat, who was now aleep; and I beeech you Father, aid I, do you know the owner of this V •
• l, or who the Pa • engers are? He was very angry to be diturb'd: And was it for this Reaon, aid he, that we choe the mot private place in the Ship; that none but your elf might diturb us: Or what will it igni • ie if I tell you, that
one Lycas a Tarentine owns her, and is carrying one Tryph • ena to Tarentum?

For a while I tood like one Thunder-truck, when opening my Boom, I trembling, cry'd out; At lat, Fortune, you have ruin'd every part of me: For Gito, my better half, lean'd on my Breat, as if he'd breath'd his lat: When our weating through fear, had a little recover'd our Spirits; I fell at Eumolpus feet, and in • reated him to have Compaion of two dying Wretches: That is, to ai • t us in the Means of ecaping the impending Michief: Tho' Death, I added, wou'd be more grateful to us, if the Happines of enjoying you, did not make us deire Life.

Eumolpus was glad to erve us, and wore by all that's acred, he was privy to no Deign againt us; and that he had very innocently brought us hither, for no other end, than for our Company, having hir'd the Ve • el before he was acquainted with us: But what deigns on your Lives are here? added he, O • , have we a Pyrat •
Hannibal on board? Lycas, continu'd he, a very Honourable Man, is not only Mater and owner of this Veel, but of a good Etate; and having inclinations to Tra •• ick, freights his Ve • el
himelf: Is this the terrible Cyclops? Is this the dreadful Cut-throat, we mut pay our Carriage to? And beides him, is the Beautiful Tryphoena that other Emblem of Terrour, who for her pleaure only goes with Lycas.
Thee are the very two, reply'd Gito, we trove to avoid: And, in a low voice, made Eumolpus, that trembled at the Story, at once undertand the Occaions of their Malice to us, and our preent danger.

Eumolpus was o ditracted in his thoughts, he cou'd not advie, but bid each of us give him his Opinion; and preume, ays he, we had jut enter'd the Cyclops Den, where Jove's Thunder-bolts are made. We mut eek a means of delivery, except we deign to free us from all Danger, by inking the Veel.

No, no, began Gito, rather offer the Pilot a Reward, to direct the Veel to ome Port: And affirm the Sea o diagrees with your Friend, that if he is not • o Kind, you fear he'll dye: You may colour the pretence with Tears, and appear much concern'd, that, mov'd with Compaion, the Pilot may befriend you.

Eumolpus reply'd, that could not be effected; for not only the difficulty of guiding o great a Ship to a Port, but a Supicion he wou'd necearily have, that his Friend cou'd not be o uddenly very ill, conpir'd againt it: Then next, perhaps •
Lycas wou'd have a Curioity to viit his ick Paenger: Can you propoe to ecape by a means that will dicover ye to him ye'd avoid? But preuming the Ship cou'd be topt in her rapid Coure, and that Lycas hou'd not viit his ick on Board: How can we get out, but all mut ee us? With our Heads muffled, or bare? if cover'd, we move every one to lend a hand to ick Perons; if bare, we dicover our elves.

A deperate Dieae, aid I, mut have a deperate Cure; I know no better Expedient of our delivery, than to lide into a long Boat, and cutting the Cord, leave the ret to Fortune: Nor do I deire Eumolpus to hare the Danger: For what wou'd it ignifie to involve an innocent Peron in other Mens deerv'd Misfortunes? We hall think our elves happy, if Fortune be kind.

'Twas not ill advied, aid Eumolpus, if it cou'd be done; for do you think to
tir in the Ship unoberv'd, when the ditant motion of the Stars themelves can't ecape the Pilot's diligence? You mut pas the only guarded part of the Ship, near which place the Rope that holds the Boat is tyed: Beides, Eucolpius, I wonder you did not remember that one Seaman was upon contant duty night and day in the Boat it elf; nor will be mov'd from his Pot, without you cut his Throat, or fling him over-board; which conider whether you can dare attempt; for my part, to go with you I would refue no danger that could give me the leat hopes of getting off; but to put o low a value on life, to throw it away as an ueles thing • I believe even your elves are unwilling: Hear whether you like my Propoal, I'll put ye into two Mantles I have here, and making Holes to breathe and eat through, will place you amongt my other Goods for Baggage; next morning I allarm the whole Ship, crying out, my ervants, fearing a greater punihment, in the night jumpt into the Sea; that when the Ship made to land, I might carry you off for Baggage.

Very well, aid I, but do you deign to tye us as Stocks, within which Nature does not labour to be freed; or as thoe
that ue to neeze and nore? Or, becaue I once ucceeded in a like deceit? But uppoe we cou'd hold out a day o ty'd up, what hall we do if we're put to't longer? Will the thoughts of a quiet life without cares, or of our advere fortune entertain us mot? our very Cloaths long bound up will rot upon our backs: Can we, d'ye think, that are young, and not inur'd to labour, endure to be clad like Statues, and wear our cords as inenibly? Since we are yet to eek a way of ecape, for no Propoal has been made without an objection; ee what I have thought on: The tudious Eumolpus, I preume, never goes unfurniht with • nk; is there a better Expedient, than wahing our hands, face, and hair, with that, to appear like Aethiopian Slaves? when without wringing our Limbs, we can't but be merry, to act a Cheat, that o neatly impoes on our enemies?

And why wou'd not you have us Circumcis'd too, interrupted Gito, that we ma • appear like Jews; and have our Ears bor'd, to perwade them we came from Arabia? and why did not you advie our Faces to be Chalk'd as well as Ink'd, that we might pas for Frenchmen, as if our Colour would make uch a mighty Alteration?
Has a Foreigner but one mark of ditinction? Can you think any body o ignorant to mitake you for one, by that ign only? Grant our dawb'd faces wou'd keep their Colour: Suppoe it wou'd not wah off, nor our Cloaths tick to the Ink, how can we imitate their black wollen Lips? the hort curl of their hair? the eams on their foreheads? their circular way of treading? their play feet? or the mode of their Beards? an artificial Colour rather tains than alters the body; but, if you'll be rul'd by a madman, let's cover our heads, and jump into the Sea.

Nor Heaven nor Man, cry'd Eumolpu • , cou'd uffer ye make o ill an end; rather purue this advice: My Slave, as you may imagin by the Razor, is a piece of a Barber; let him have not only your Heads, but, as a mark of greater punihment, your Eye-brows too, and I'll finih your diguie with an Incription on your Foreheads, that you may appear as Slaves branded for ome extraordinary Villany: Thus the ame Letters will at once divert their upicion, and conceal your Countenances under the mask of punihment.

We lik'd the advice, and haten'd the execution, when tealing to the ide of
the Veel, we committed our Heads and Eye-brows to the Barber: Eumolpus in the mean time fill'd our Fore-heads with great Letters, and very liberally dipenc'd the known marks of Fugitives through the other parts of our Faces; one of the Paengers, eaing his o'recharg'd tomach o're the ide of the Ship, by the Moon perceiving the reflection of a Barber buie at o uneaonable a time, and, curing the Omen that he thought preag'd a Shipwrack, ran to his Hammock; upon which we diembled the ame, but indeed had an equal though different concern; and the noie over, we pent the ret of the night without reting much.

p.q: The next day Eumolpus, when he found Tryph • ena was tirring, went to viit Lycas; and after he had talk'd with him about the happy Voyage he hop'd from the clearnes of the Heavens, Lycas, turning to Tryph • ena, Methoughts,
p.U:
aid he, about midnight the Viion of Priapus appear'd to me, and told me, he had lately brought into my Ship Eucolpius that I ought for: Tryph • ena was tartl'd, And you'd wear we lept together, r •
ply'd he, for methoughts the Image of
Neptune having truck his Trident thrice againt the Baj • e, told me that in Lycas's Ship I hou'd meet my Gito.

div.p: Hence proceeds, aid Eumolpus, interrupting 'em, that Veneration I pay the Divine Epicurus, who o wittily has dicovered uch illuions.
div.l: W • en in a Dream preented to our view,
Thoe airy Forms appear o like the true;
Nor Heaven nor H • ll the fancy'd Viions ends,
But every breat its own deluion lends:
For when oft leep the body wraps in eae,
And from th' unactive mas our fancy frees,
Whatever 'tis in which we take delight,
And think of mot by day, we dream at night.
Thus he, the now ackt City jutly fear'd,
Who all around had • eath and ruin har'd.
From fancy'd <…> a darkned sky,
And Troops <…> in confuion fly:
There the <…> pomp of Kings; here
Concious <…> drown'd in blood, appear.
He that by <…> nois'd it at the Bar,

Of Knaves <>
• ools now ees the great reort,
And to meet <> vainly •• ars in Court.
Miers amid •• their heaps are raiing new,
And think they oft their old • id treaure view.

And Huntmen the imagin'd Chace p ••
•• .
The Merchant dreams of Wrecks, the Ship wou'd ave,
Or now, by inking it, himelf preerve.
The Mitres to her ditant lover writes;
And, as awake, with flames and darts indites:
The Goodwife dreaming of her Stallion's charms,
Oft eeks the pleaure in her Cuckold's arms.
Dogs on full cry, in leep, the Hare purue,
And haples wretches their old griefs renew.
div.p: But Lycas, when he had thank'd his Stars for their care of him, That we may not eem, aid he, to condemn the Divine Powers, what hinders but we earch the Veel?

Upon which one Aeius, the Pa • enger that had dicover'd us by our reflection in the water, cry'd out, thee are the men that were hav'd by Moon-hine to night. Heaven avert the Omen! I thought the Ceremony of cutting the Nails and Hair, was never perform'd but as a olemn Sacrifice to appeae a Storm.

Is't o, ays Lycas, in a great heat, did any in the Ship of • er to have themelves, and at midnight too? bring 'em quickly hither, that I may know who they are
that deerve to die a acrifice for our afety.

'Twas I, quoth Eumolpus, commanded it, not wihing ill to the Ship, but eae to my elf; for they are my Slaves, and having long taring hairs, I order'd the uncomely • ight to be taken away; not only that I might not eem to make a Prion of the Ship • but that the mark of their Villany might more plainly appear; and to let you know how richly they deerve the punihment; among other Rogueries, they rob'd me of a coniderable um of Money, and pent it with all the luxury of rich Debauches, on a Trull that was at both their ervices, whom I catcht them with lat night. In hort, they yet mell of the Wine they profuely gave themelves with my Money.

Lycas, that the offenders might attone for their crime, order'd each of them forty tripes; we were immediately brought to the place of Execution; where the enrag'd Seamen et upon us with Ropesends, and try'd to offer our blood a acrifice for their afety. I bore three tripes very Heroically. Gito, who had not o much paive valour at the firt blow, et up uch an out-cry that the known ound of his voice reach'd Tryph • ena's ear; who
in great diorder attended with her Maids, that were all like her elf urpriz'd at the voice, run to the ufferer.

Gito's admirable beauty had often'd their rage, and eem'd without peaking to intreat their favour; when the Maids unanimouly cry'd out, 'tis Gito, 'tis Gito; hold your barbarous hands, help Madam, 'tis Gito!
Tryph • ena to their cry inclin'd her Ears, that already had anticipated her belief, and with eager hat flew to the Boy.

Upon which Lycas that knew me very well, as much atisfied as he had heard my voice, ran to me, and taking my other parts on content, with a lacivious diligence directed his eyes and hands to my Codpiece, where atisfy'd by good tokens, your ervant Eucolpus, ays he, 'twill be no wonder how Euryclea that nurs'd Ulyes, at his return after twenty years abence, hou'd know him by a car in his forehead, when 'tis conider'd, the mot dicreet Lycas, not beholden to the marks of any een part of the body, o judiciouly dicover'd me by the mot hid: Tryph • ena, having cheated her elf into a belief that thoe marks of lavery we wore on our foreheads were real, wept; and began in a low voice, to inquire what Prion
cou'd top us in our Rambles; or whoe o cruel hands cou'd finih uch a punihment without reluctancy. I confes, added he, they deerve ome punihment with whom their Maters are o ju •• ly angry.

Lycas was in a great heat at Tryph • ena's tendernes. And thou foolih Woman, aid he, can you believe, thoe marks were cut before the Ink was laid? We hould be too happy were thoe tains not to be rub'd off, and had jutly been, as they deign'd us, the ubject of their laughter, if we had uffer'd our elves to be o groly impos'd on in a ham Incription.

Tryph • ena, who was not yet unmindful of our former amours, wou'd have pity'd us. When Lycas, till reenting the abue he received in his vitiated Wife, and the affronts at the Porch of Hercules's Temple, with greater rage cry'd out, I thought you had been convinc'd Tryph • ena, that Heaven has the care of humane affairs, when it not only brought our Enemies into our power, which they trove to avoid, but reveal'd it in a viion to us both; ee what you'l get by pardoning them, whom Heaven it elf has brought to punihment, for my part, I am not naturally o cruel, but am afraid the judgment
I hou'd prevent from jutly falling upon, others, may light on my own head.

This upertitious Harangue, turn'd Tryphaena from hindring our punihment to haten its execution. When he began afreh as highly to reent the former affronts that was offer'd her • as Lycas did the repute of his modety that he had lot in the peoples eteem.

p.q: When Lycas found Tryphaena was with himelf eagerly inclin'd to revenge, he order'd to increae our punihments, which when Eumolpus perceiv'd, he endeavour'd to mitigate after this manner.

div.p:
I pity the wretches, aid he, that lie at your mercy.—Lycas, they implore your compaion, and chooing me as a man not altogether unknown to 'em to perform the office, deire to be reconcil'd to them they once held mot dear. Can you believe, 'twas by accident they fell into your hands, when all Paengers make it their chief buines to enquire to whoe care they are to trut themelves? When you are atisfied of their intentions, can you be o barbarous to continue your revenge, but uffer free born men to go uninjur'd where they have deign'd. Even barbarous and implacable Maters allay their cruelty when their Slaves repent;
and all give quarter to the Enemy that urrenders himelf. What can you, or will you deire more? you have at your feet repenting Supplicants; they're Gentlemen, and men of worth; and what's more prevailing than both, were once cares'd as your dearet Friends. Had they rob'd you of your Money, or betray'd your trut, by Hercules the punihment they've inflicted on themelves might have atisfied your rage; don't you ee the marks of Slaves on their Faces; who, though free, to attone their injuries to you, precrib'd themelves.

To avoid confuion, interrupted Lycas, give me a reaon for all particulars as I hall ask you; and firt, if they came with deign to urrender themelves, why did they cut off their hair? for all Diguies are aum'd rather to deceive than atisfie the injur'd.

Next, if they expected to ingratiate themelves by their Embaadour, why have you endeavoured in every thing, to conceal them you were to peak for? whence it plainly appears, 'twas by accident the offenders were brought to punihment, and that you have us'd this Artifice to divert our upicion.

Sure you thought to raie our envy, by ringing in our ears, that they were Gentlemen, and Men of Worth; but have a care their caue don't uffer by your impudence; what hou'd the injur'd do when the guilty come to • em to be puniht? and if they were my friends, they deerve to be more everely treated; for he that wrongs a tranger is call'd a Rogue, but he that erves a Friend o, is little les than a Parricide.

I am encible, aid Eumolpus, anwering this dreadful Harangue, that nothing cou'd happen to thee unhappy Young men more unfortunate, than the cutting their hair off at midnight, which is the only argument that may perwade you to mitake their voluntary coming here, for accidental; but I hall as candidly endeavour to undeceive you, as it was innocently acted: before they imbarkt they had deigns to eae their heads of that, as trouble • ome as ueles weight, but the unexpected wind that haten'd us on board, made 'em de • er it; nor did they upect it to be of any moment where 'twas done, being equally ignorant of the ill Omen, and Cutoms of Mariners.

What advantage, reply'd Lycas, cou'd they propoe to themelves by the los of their hair? unles they thought baldnes might ooner raie our compaion: Or can you believe I wou'd be atisfy'd in your relation? when addreing himelf to me, What Poyon, aid he, thou Villain has eat your hair off? To what God have your Sacrilegious hands offer'd it?

The fear of punihment truck me peechles; nor cou'd I find any thing to urge in my defence againt o plain an accuation. Then the confuion I was in, my disfigur'd face, with the equal baldnes of my Head and Eye • brows, gave a ridiculous air to every thing I aid or did; but when they wip'd us with a wet Spunge, the Letters melting into one, pread o're our Faces uch a ooty cloud that turn'd Lycas's rage to a perfect loathing. Eumolpus cou'd not endure to ee free-born men againt all Law and Jutice o abus'd, and returning their threats with blows, not only was our advocate but Champion too. He was econded by his Man and two or three ick Paengers appear'd our Friends, that erv'd • ather to encourage us, than encreae our force.

Upon which I was o far from begging pardon, that without any repect I held my Fits at Tryphaena, and plainly told her he hou'd feel me, if her lecherous Ladihip, who only in the Ship deerv'd to be puniht, was not content to decline her pretentions to Gito.
The Angry Lycas was all rage at my impudence; and very impatient of revenge when he found, without any concern for my own caue, I only tood up for anothers.
Nor was Tryphaena les diturb'd at my contempt of her; at what time every one in the Veel chooe his ide, and put himelf in a poture of defence.

On our ide Eumolpus's Slave ditributed the Intruments of his Trade, and reerv'd a Razor to defend his own peron; on the other, Tryphaena and her Attendance advanc'd, arm'd with nothing but their Nails and Tongues; which lat upply'd the want of Drums in their Army; when the Pilot, crying out, threaten'd he wou'd leave the Ship to the mercy of the waves if they continu'd the butle rais'd about the lut of two or three Vagabonds.

This did not in the leat retard the ight; they preing for revenge, we for
our lives: In hort, many fell half dead on both ides; others withdrew, as from greater Armies, to be dret of their Wounds; yet this damps not the rage of either ide.

Then the bold Gito drawing out that part of him, Tryphaena mot admird, clapt a bloody Razor to't, and threaten'd to cut away the caue of all our Misfortunes. But Tryphaena did not aintly end to prevent o cruel an act: I often of • er'd at my Throat too, but with as little deign to kill my elf as Gito to do what he threatned: He the more boldly handl'd his becaue he knew it to be the ame blunt Razor he had us'd before; which made Tryphaena very appr • henive of his Tragick intentions.

Upon this, both ides drew up their ranks, when the Pilot perceiving how Commical a War it was, with much ado was perwaded to let Tryphaena dipatch an Herauld to capitulate: Articles immediately according to the Cutom of Countries being mutually agreed off on both ides; Tryphaena natcht an Olivebranch, the Enign of Peace, that tuck to the Image of Properity pictur'd in the Ship, and holding it in the midt of us, thus addret her elf.
div.l: What fury did thee udden broils engage,
How have thee guiltles hands deerv'd the rage?
No Paris a toln Dame to Troy conveys,
No Witch Medea here her Brother • ays:
But ighted love mut needs reenting be:
And midt the waves who is the raging he
Now rob'd of Arms that can attempt my fate?
By whom is imple death o little thought?
Let not your murderous rage out torm the Seas,
And dangers of the angry waves increae.
div.p: When in a great heat Tryphaena had thus aid, both Armies tood till a while, and reviving the Treaty of Peace, put a top to the War. Our Captain Eumolpus prudently us'd the occaion of her repentance, and having firt everely chatiz'd Lycas, ign'd the Articles: Which were as follow.

Tryphaena, You do from the b • ttom of your heart, as you are in perf • ct mind, promie never to complain of any i • jury you have receiv'd from Gito; nor men • ion, upbraid him with, or tudy to revenge directly or indirectly any action of his before this day; and to prevent your forcing him to an unwilling compliance, be it further agreed, that you never kis, coll, or bring him to a cloer
hug, without the forfeiture of 100 Denarii: And for better ecurity, that you always pay your Mon • , before you have your Ware.

Item, You Lycas, from the bottom of your heart, as you are in perfect mind; do promie never to reproach, or inultingly treat Eucolpius, either in Words, or Getures: And that you never offer at his Breeches, but, on the forfeiture of 200 Denarij for each time you abue him, behind his back.
Conditions thus agreed on, we laid down our Arms: And, leat my grudge might till remain, wipe off the memory of all things pat, in repeated Kies.

All Quarrels expir'd in univeral houts, and a umptuous Banquet that follow'd, pread equal Mirth through the whole Company: The Veel rung with Songs, the Enigns of their Joy: And the occaion of a udden Calm, gave other diverions: Here a little Artit bob'd for Fih, that riing, eem'd with hate to meet their ruin: There another draws the unwilling Prey, that he had betray'd on the Hook, with an inviting Bait: When looking up, we aw Sea-Birds itting on the Sail-Yard, about which, one skill'd in that Art, having plac'd LimeTwigs,
made 'em his booty. Their downy Feathers, the Air whirl'd about: The other, the Sea vainly tot too and fro.

Now Lycas began to be friends with me: And Tryphaena, as a Mark of her Love, threw the bottom of her Wine upon Gito: At what time, Eumolpus, quite Drunk, aim'd at Rallery on thoe that were Bald and Branded; till having pent his life-les Stock, he return'd to his Veres; and deigning an Elegy on the los of Hair, thus began.
div.l: Natures chief Ornament, the Hair is lot,
Thoe vernal Locks, feel Winters blat:
Now the Bald Temples mourn their Banih'd hade,
And Britles hine o'th' Sun-burnt Head.
The Joys, dec • itful Nature does fir • t pay
Our Age, it natches firt away.
Unhappy Mortal, that but now
The lovely grace of Hair, did't know:
Bright as the Sun's, or Cynthia's Beam • ,
Now wore than Bras, and only eems
Like th' Muhroons, that in Gardens prings.
From porting Girls, you'll frighted run,
And that Death will the ooner come:
Know that part of your Head is gone.
div.p: He wou'd have condemn'd us to hear more, and I believe wore than the former; if an Attendant of Tryphaena, had not diturb'd him: Who taking Gito aide, dres'd him up in her Mitrees Tower; and to retore him perfectly to his former Figure • drawing fale Eyebrows out of her Patch-Box, plac'd 'em o exactly, Nature might have mitaken 'em for her own work.
At the fight of the true Gito, Tryphaena wept for joy: Who, not before, cou'd hug him with o real a atisfaction.

I was glad to ee his los o well repair'd: Yet, often hid my Head, as enible I appear'd with no common deformity, whom even Lycas thought not worth peaking to: But 'twas not long e're the ame Maid came to my relief, and calling me aide, dres'd me in a Peruke no les agreeable: For being of Golden Locks, it rather improv'd my Complexion.

But, Eumolpus, our Advocate, and Reconciler, to Entertain the Company, and keep up the Mirth; began to be pleaant on the incontancy of Women: How forward they were to Love, how oon ye forgot their Sparks: And that no woman was o Chat, but her untry'd
Lut • might be rais'd to a Fury: Nor wou'd he bring intances from ancient Tragedies, or Peronages celebrated to Antiquity: But Entertain us, if we wou'd pleae to hear, with a Story within the Circle of his own Memory: upon which the Eyes and Ears of all were devoted to him: Who thus began.

There was at Epheus a Lady, of o Celebrated virtue • that the Women of Neighbouring Nations came to join their admiration with that of her own Country: This Lady at the death of her Husband not content with tearing her Hair, or beating her Breat, thoe common expreions of grief; but following him into the Vault, where the Body plac'd in a Monument, he, after the Grecian Cutom, watch'd the Corps, and whole Nights and Days continu'd weeping; the perwaions of Parents nor Relations cou'd divert her grief, or make her take any thing to preerve life: The publick Officers at lat, he guarding the Body for 'em, left the Vault; and lamented by all for o ingular an example of grief, liv'd thus five days without Eating.

All left her but a faithful Maid, who with tears upply'd her afflicted Lady, and as often as the Lamp they had by,
began to expire, renew'd the light; by this time he became the talk of the whole Town; and all degrees of Men confet, he was the only true example of Love and Chatity.

In the mean time there happening a Trial of Criminals, the Condemn'd were order'd to be Crucify'd near the Vault in which the Lady was weeping o're the Corps of her late Husband. The Soldier that guarded the Bodies let any might be taken from the Cros and bury'd, the night after oberv'd a light in the Vault, and hearing the Groans of ome affl • cted peron, pret with a curioity common to Mankind, he deired to know, who, or what it was? Upon which he enter'd the Vault, and eeing a very beautiful Woman, amaz'd at firt, he fancy'd 'twas a pirit, but viewing the dead Body, and conidering her t • ars and torn face, he oon guet, as it was, that the Lady cou'd not bear the lo • s of her Husband: he brings his Supper with him into the Vault, and began to perwade the mournful Lady not to continue her unneceary grief, nor with vain complaints conume her health: That death was common to all M • n; and many other things he told her, that ue to retore afflicted perons
to that calmnes they before enjoy'd: But • he mov'd anew at the comfort a tranger offer'd, redoubl'd her grief, and tearing her Hair, cat it on the Body that lay before her.

The Soldier however did not withdraw, but with the like invitations o •• er'd her omewhat to eat, till her Maid o'recome, I preume, by the pleaing cent of the Wine, no longer cou'd reit the Soldier's Courteie. When refreht with the Entertainment, he began to join her perwaions to win her Lady; and what advantage, began he, wou'd you reap in t • rving your elf? in burying your elf alive? What wou'd it ignifie to anticipate your fate?
div.l: D'ye think departed Souls will value it?
div.p: Will you, Madam, in pite of Fate, revive your Husband? Or will you hake off thee vain complaints, the marks of our Sex's weaknes, and enjoy the World while you may? The very Body that lyes there might make you envy life.

We don't unwillingly obey when we're commanded to eat or live. The Lady now dry with o long fating, uffer'd her elf to be o'recome; nor was les pleas'd with her Entertainment, than her Maid that firt urrender'd. You know with what
thoughts encouraging meats inpire young perons. With the ame Charms our Souldier had won her to be in love with life, he addret himelf as a Lover; nor did his peron appear les agreeable to the chate Lady, than his converation; and the Maid, to raie her opinion of him, thus apply'd her elf:
div.l: And arm'd with pleaing love dare you ingage,
E're you conider in whoe Tents you are?
div.p: To make hort: nor even in this cou'd the Lady deny him any thing: Thus our victorious Souldier ucceeded in both; he receiv'd his Imbraces; not only that night they truck up the bargain, but the next and third day: Having hut the door of the Vault, that if any of her acquaintance or trangers had come out of curioity to ee her, they might have believ'd the mot chat of all Women, had expir'd on the body of her Husband. Our Souldier was o taken with his beautiful Mitres, and the privacy of injoying her, that the little Money he was Mater of, he laid out for her Entertainment, and, as oon as 'twas night, convey'd it into the Vault.

In the mean time the Relations of one of the Malefactors, finding the Body unguarded, drew it from the Cros and bury'd it. The Souldier thus rob'd while he was in the Vault, the next day, when he perceiv'd one of the Bodies gone, dreading the punihment, he told the Lady what had happen'd; and, added that with his Sword he wou'd prevent the Judges Sentence; if o be he wou'd pleae to give him Burial, and make that place at once the fatal Monument of a Lover and a Husband.

The Lady, not les merciful than chat; Nor wou'd Heaven allow, aid he, that I hou'd at once feel the los of the only two in the world I held mot dear; I'd rather hang up the dead Body of the one, than be the wicked intrument of the other's death. Upon which he order'd her Husband's Body to be taken out of the Co •• in, and fixt to the Cros, in the room of that which was wanting: Our Souldier purued the directions of the dicreet Lady, and the next day the people wonder'd for what reaon that Body was hung on the Cros.

The Seamen were pleas'd with the Story. Tryph • ena not a little aham'd, lovingly apply'd her Cheek to Gito's, and
hid her bluhes; but Lycas wore an air of dipleaure, and knitting his brows, aid he, If the Governour had been a j • t man, he ought to have retor'd the Husbands Body to his Monument, and hung the Womans on the Cros. I don't doubt it made him reflect on his own Wife, and the whole Scene of our Lut when we rob'd his Veel. But the Articles he agreed to, oblig'd him not to complain; and the mirth that ingag'd us gave him no opportunity to vent his Rage.
Tryph • ena entertain'd her elf in Gito's Arms, preing oft his Neck with eager Kies, and o • t dipoing his new Ornament, to make it appear more agreeable to his Face.

At this I was not a little out of humour • and impatient of our new League, cou'd neither eat nor drink any thing; but with ide-looks wiht a thouand Cures on them both; every kis and every look he gave him, wounded me. Nor did I yet know whether I had more reaon to repent the los of my Mitres • or my Comrade; he having rob'd me of her; and he deluded him from my arm • : Both were wore than death to me. And to compleat my miery, neither Tryph • ena poke to me as her acquaintance, and
once grateful Lover; nor did Gito think me worth drinking to; or what's the leat he cou'd, common dicoure with him: I believe he was tender of the new return of her favours, and afraid to give her another occaion to fall out with him: Grief forc'd a flood of Tears from my Eyes, and I tifl'd my Complaints, till I was ready to expire.

When Lycas perceiv'd how well, tho' in this trouble, my yellow Ornament became me, he was inflam'd afreh; and viewing me with Lovers eyes, addreed himelf as uch, when laying aide the haughty brow of a Mater, he put on the tender complacency of a Friend: but his endeavours were fruitles. At lat meeting with an intire repule, his love turning to a fury, he endeavour'd to ravih the favours he cou'd not win by intreaty; at what time Tryph • ena unexpectedly came in, and oberving his wantonnes; in the greatet confuion he hid his head, and ran from h • r.

Upon which the more lutful Tryph • ena askt, and made me tell her, what thoe wanton Carees meant; he was inpired with new heat at the relation; and mindful of our old Amours, offer'd to revive our former Commerce; but worn
off my legs with thoe Employments, I gave her invitations, but an ill return; yet he with all the deires of a woman tranported by her paion, threw her arms about me, and o cloely lockt me in her Imbraces, I was forc'd to cry out; one of her Maids came in at the noie, and eaily believing I wou'd force from her the favours I had deny'd her Mitres, ruht between, and loos'd the Bands: Tryph • ena meeting with uch a repule, and even raging with deire, took it more grievous at my hands, and with threats at her going off, • lew to Lycas; not only to raie his reentments againt me, but join with him in puruit of revenge.

By the way oberve, I had formerly been well receiv'd by this Attendant of Tryph • ena, when I maintain'd a Commerce with her Mitres, upon that core he reented my convere with Tryph • ena, and deeply ighing, made me eager to know the occaion; when he, tepping back, thus began, If you had any parks of the Gentleman in you, you'd value her no more than a common Protitute; if you were a man you wou'd not decend to uch a Jakes; thee thoughts not a little diturb'd her; but I was aham'd of nothing more, than that Eumolpus, upecting
the occaion, hou'd in his next Veres make our uppos'd quarrel the ubject of his Drollery; and let my care to avoid it hou'd prove one means of dicovering it.

When I was contriving how to prevent his upicion, Eumolpus himelf came in, already acquainted with what was done; for Tryph • ena had communicated her grief to Gito, and endeavour'd at his co • t to compenate the injury I had offer'd her. Upon which Eumolpus was on ire, and the more, b • caue her wantonnes was an open breach of the Articles he had ign'd.

When the old Doctor aw me, pitying my misfortune, he deir'd to know the whole Scene from my elf; I freely told him of the Gameomenes of the lewd Lycas, and Tryph • ena's lut • ul a • ult, that he was already well inform'd of; upon which, in a olemn Oath, he wore to vindicate our caue, and that Heaven was too jut to uff • r o many Crimes to go unpuniht.

While we were thus ingag'd, a Storm aroe; now thick Clouds, and th' inrag'd ••• od eclyp •• the day, the Seamen fly to their Pots as fat as fear cou'd make 'em: and, pulling down the Sails, leave the V • el to the mercy of the Tempet;
for the uncertain winds made them hopeles of any direct coure; nor did the Pilot know which way to teer; ometimes the unguided Ship was for • 'd on the Coat of Sicily, o • ten by contrary Winds 'twas tot near Italy; and what was more dangerous than all, on a udden the gathering Clouds pread uch horrid darknes all around, that the Pilot cou'd not ee over the Fore-catle; upon which all depair'd of afety; when Lycas threw himelf before me, and lifting up his trembling hands, I beeech you Encolpius, began he, ait the ditres'd, that is retore the Sacred Vet and Timbrel you took from the Image of the Goddes Iis; be merciful as you are wont. At what time a Whirl-wind natcht him up, and threw him howling midt the flood, and oon a piteful wave jut hew'd him us, and drew him back again.
Tryph • ena, hatily taken up by her faithful Attendants, and plac'd with her chief Goods in the Skiff, avoided a mot certain death.

I, lockt in Gito's Arms, not without tears, cry'd out, And this we have merited of Heaven, that only Death hould joyn us; but even now I fear Fortune will be againt it; for ee the Waves
threaten to o'return the Veel; and now the Tempet comes to burt the lov'd bands that unite us; therefore if you really love Encolpius, let's kis while we may, and natch this lat joy even in pite of our approaching Fate.

When I had thus aid, Gito threw off his Mantle, and getting under mine, thrut his Head out at top to reach my Lips; but that the mot malicious Wave might not ravih us aunder, he girt himelf to me with the Thong that bound his Wallet; and 'tis ome comfort, aid he, to think that by this the Sea will bear us the longer e're it can divorce us from each others Arms. Or, if in compaion it hou'd throw us on the ame Shore, either the next that paes by wou'd give us a Monument of Stones, that by the common Laws of Humanity he wou'd cat upon us; or at leat the angry Waves, that eem to conpire our eparation, wou'd unwittingly bury us in one grave, with the and their rage wou'd vomit up. I was atisfy'd with my Chain, and, as on my Death-bed, did now contentedly expect the coming hour.

In the mean time the Tempet, acting the D • crees of Fate, had rent all the Rigging from the Veel; no Mat, no Rudder
left, not a Rope or Plank, but an awkard hapeles body of a Ship tot up and down the flood.

The Fiher-men that inhabited the Seaide, expecting a Booty, in all hate put out with their Boats; but when they aw thoe in the Veel that cou'd defend their own; they chang'd their deign of pillaging to uccouring.

After a alute on both ides, unwonted Murmurs, like that of ome Beat, labouring to get out, proceeded from beneath the Maters Cabin; upon which, following the ound, we found Eumolpus itting alone, and in his hand a large Scroll of Paper that he was filling, even to the Margent, with Veres; we all were amaz'd to ee a man amue himelf with Poetry, at a time when he had reaon to think each minute wou'd be his lat, and having drawn him, making a great noie, from his hole, we endeavour'd to recover him from his Frenzy; but he was in uch a heat to be diturb'd, that, 'S death, aid he, let me make an end of this Couplet, it finihes the Poem; on which I took hold of the Mad man, and order'd the till murmuring Poet to be hall'd on Shore.

When with ome trouble we had got him on Shore, we very penively enter'd
one of the Fihermen's Huts, and howe're we feated on our Meats the Sea had corrupted, we had no comfortable night of 't.

The next day, as we were propoing how to betow our elves, we dicover'd an Human Body floating on a little Wave that made to Shore: I tood till concern'd, and began with more diligence to ee, if what was preented to our view were real.

When finding it to be a mans; and who knows, I cry'd out, but this Wretch's Wi • e, in ome part of the World, ecure at home, may expect his coming; or perhaps a Son, ignorant of the fatal Storm, may wait the wiht arrival of his Father; who with o many Ki • es eal'd his unwilling parting: Thee are our great deigns! va • n Mortals well with promiing hopes, yet there's the iue of them all • ee the mighty Nothing how it's tot!

When I had thus bemoan'd the Wretch, as one unknown, the Sea cat cat him on Land with his face, not much dis • i
• igur'd, toward Heaven; upon which I made up to it, and eaily knew that the but now terrible and implacable Lycas was lying at my feet.

I could not retrain my Tears; but, beating my Breat, Now where's, aid I, your Rage? where your unruly Paions? now you're expos'd a prey to Fih and Beats; and the poor Shipwrackt wretch, with all his boated power, now has not one Plank of the great Ship he proudly call'd his own. After this, let Mortals flatter themelves with Golden Dreams; let the weary Mier heap up ill-got Wealth for many years; 'twas but yeterday this lifeles thing was priding in its Riches, and had fixt the very day he thought to return. How hort, alas! lyes the poor wretch of his deign! but 'tis not the Sea only we hould fear: one the Wars deceive; another by ome accidental ruin, even at the Altar, meets a Grave; a third by a fall in running anticipates his arrival to the Goal; eating oft kills the Greedy; and Abtinence the Temperate. If we rightly conider it, in this Sea of Life we may be Shipwrackt every where; but we vainly lament the want of Burial to a wretch that's drown'd; as if it concern'd the perihing Carcas, whether Flames, Worms, or Fihes were its Canibals. Whatever way you are conum'd, the end of all's the ame. But Fih, they object, will tear their Bodies; as if their
Teeth were les gentle than the Flames; a punihment that we believe is the highet we can in • lict on Slaves that have provok'd us; therefore what madnes is't to trouble our lives with the cares of our Burial after we're dead; when the bet of us may meet the Fate he vainly trives with o much diligence to avoid?

After thee Reflections, we perform'd the lat office for the dead, and, tho' his Enemies, honour'd him with a Funeral Pile; but while Eumolpus was making an Epitaph, his Eyes roam'd here and there, to find an Image that might raie his Fancy.

When we had willingly acquitted our elves of this piece of Humanity to Lycas, we puru'd our deign'd Journey, and all in a weat oon reacht the head of a neighbouring Hill, from whence we dicovered a Town eated on the top of a high Mountain; we did not know it, till a Shepherd inform'd us 'twas Crotona; the mot ancient and once mot flourihing City of Italy; when we enquir'd of him what ort of People inhabited this renown'd place, and what kinds of Commerce they chiefly maintain'd, ince they were impoverih'd by o many Wars?

Gentlemen, aid he, if you have deigns of Trading, you mut go another way; but if you're of the admir'd ort of Men, that have the thriving qualifications of Lying and Cheating, you're in the direct path to buines; for in this City no Learning flouriheth; Eloquence has not a room here; Temperance, Good Manners, nor any Virtue can meet a reward; aure your elves of finding but two orts of Men, and they are the Cheated, and thoe that Cheat. A Father takes no care of his Children, becaue the having of Heirs is uch a mark of Infamy, that he who is known in that Circumtance, dares not appear at any publick Game or Show, is deny'd all publick Priviledges, and only herds among thoe that all Men pis upon. But ingle Men, who have no tyes of Nature that oblige the dipoal of their Wealth, are carres'd by all, and have the greatet Honours confer'd on 'em; they're the only Valorous, the only Brave; nay, and only innocent too. You're going to a City, added he, like a Field in a Plague-time, where you can oberve nothing but one Man devouring another, as Crows dead Carcaes.

The prudent Eumolpus, at a thing o urprizingly new, began to be thoughtful, and confet that way to riches did not dipleae him. I believ'd it the effect of a Poetick Gaiety, that had not le • t his years: When, I wih, continu'd he, I cou'd maintain a greater figure, as well in Habit as Attendants, 'twou'd give a better colour to my pretences: By Hercules, I'd throw by the Wallet, and oon advance all our Fortunes.

Promiing therefore to upply his wants, we have with us, aid I, the Sacred Vet of Iis, and all the Booty we made at Lycurgus's Village; and you have given me uch hopes, Eumolpus, added I, that were the Goddes her elf in my power, I'd pawn her for Money to carry on the deign.
Upon which, aid Eumolpus, why delay we the bringing of our hands in ue? and if you like the Propoal let me be call'd your Mater.

None e're cond • mn'd a project that was no charge to him; therefore to be true to his interet, we engag'd in an Oath before we wou'd dicover the Cheat to uffer ten thouand Racks; and thus like free-born Gladiators elling our Liberty, we Religiouly devoted both Soul and Body to our new Mater.

After the Solemn Ceremonies of our Oath were ended; like Slaves, at a ditance, we alute the Mater of our own making. When beginning to exercie his Authority, he commanded us to report that our ancient Lord (meaning him) griev'd at the los of a Son, who was a great Orator and comfort to his age, was unhappily forc'd to quit the place of his Abode, let the daily alutes of thoe that expected Preferment under him, or Viits of his Companions, might be the continual occaions of Tears; and the late Shipwrack had added to his grief, having lot to the value of twenty thouand Crowns; tho' he was not o much concern'd at the los of his Money, as of his large Retinue; that, he fear'd, would make them not proportion their thoughts to his greatnes; and to add, that our Lord had Mortgages almot on half the Etates in Afric ••
and mighty Sums at ue on Peronal Security; and cou'd raie of his own Gladiators, dipert about Numidia, a Force able to Plunder Carthage.

After this, that his Actions might aagree with his condition, 'twas concluded neceary to wear a • air of dicontent; that he hould with a tately tiffnes,
like Quality, often Cough, and pit about the Room; that his words might come the more faintly from him; that in the eye of the world he hou'd refue to eat or drink; ever talking of Riches, and ometimes, to confirm their belief, hou'd break into thee words; Strange that uch or uch a Seat hou'd diappoint my expectation, that us'd to be blet with o large an increae! And that nothing might be wanting to compleat the humour, as often as he had occaion to call any of us, he hou'd ue one name for another; that it might • aily appear how mindful the Lord was even of thoe Servants he had left in Africk.

Matters thus order'd, having, as all that wou'd thrive in the world, implor'd the aitance of Heaven, we began our march, but both Gito did not like his new lavery, and Eumolpus's hir'd Servant, bearing mot of our Baggage, in a little time beginning to be uneaie in his ervice, wou'd often ret his burden; and with ten thouand wry looks, and as many cures for our going o fat, at lat wore he would either leave his charge, or go quite away with't. 'S death, aid he, d'ye think I'm a Pack-hore, or a Dray, that you load me thus? I was hir'd for a Man, not a
Hore; nor am I les a Gentleman by birth, than any of you all • tho' my Father left me in a mean condition • Nor content with reproaches, but getting before us, he lift up one Leg, and, venting his Choler at the wrong end, • ill'd our Notrils with a beatly cent.
Gito mockt his humour, and for every crack he gave, return'd the like, that one ill-cent might tiffle another.
