But even here Eumolpus returning to his old humour: Young men, began he, this Poetry deceives many; for not only every one that is able to give a Vere its numbers, and pin out his feeble ence in a long train of words, has the vanity to think himelf inpir'd; but Pleaders at the Bar, when they wou'd give themelves a looe from buines, apply themelves to Poetry, as an Entertainment without trouble; believing it eaier to compile a Poem than maintain a Controverie, adorn'd with a few florid Sentences • But neither will a generous Spirit affect the empty ound of words; nor can a mind, unles enricht with Learning, be deliver'd of a birth of Poetry; there mut be the purity of Language, no Porterly expreion, or meannes, as I may call it, of words is to be admitted; but a tile perfectly
above the common, and with Horace,—
Scorn the Unletter'd Herd,
And drive 'em from you.

Beides, you mut be trictly diligent • that your Expreions appear of a piece with the Body of the Dicoure, and your Colours o laid, that each may contribute to the beauty of the whole. Greece has given us a Homer and the Lyricks for Examples; Rome a Virgil and an Horace; the purity of whoe Language is o happily correct, others either never aw the path that leads to Poetry, or eeing, were afraid to tread it. To decribe the Civil Wars of Rome wou'd be a Mater-piece, the unletter'd head that offers at it, will ink beneath the weight of o great a work; for to relate pat Actions, is not o much the buines of a Poet, as an Hitorian; the boundles Genius of a Poet trikes through all Mazes, introduces Gods, and puts the invention on the rack for Poetick Ornaments; that it may rather eem a Prophetick • ury, than a trict relation, with witnees of meer truth. As for example, this rapture, tho' I have not given it the lat hand.
div.l: Now Rome reign'd Empres o're the Vanquih'd Ball,
As far as Earth and Seas, obey'd by all:
Uneaie yet, with more deires he's curt,
And boundles, as her Empire, is her thirt.
In Burden'd Veels now they travell'd o're
The furrow'd deep to Seas unknown before:
And any hidden part of Land or Sea,
T • at Gold afforded, was an Enemy.
Thus Fate the Seeds of Civil fury rais'd,
When great in wealth no common pleaure pleas'd.
Delights more out of fahion by the Town:
Th' Souldier's Scarlet now from Spain mut come;
The Purple of the Sea contemn'd is grown.
India with Silks, Africk with Precious Stone,
Arabia with its Spices hither come,
And with their Ruin raie the pride of Rome.
But other Spoils, detructive to her Peace,
Rome's ruin bode, and future ills encreae:
Through Lybian Dearts are wild Monters chac'd,
And the remotet parts of Africk trac'd:
W • ere the Unweildy El • phant that's ta'en,
For fatal value of his Tooth is lain.
Uncommon Tygers are imported here,
And led Triumphant in the Theatre;
Where, while devouring Jaws on Men they try,
The People Clap to ee their Fellows die.
But Oh! who can without a bluh relate
Th • horrid c • ne of their approaching Fate?
W • en Perian Culoms, fahionable grown,
Made Nature tart, and her bet work diown,
Male Infants are divor • 'd from all that can,
By timely progres ripen into Man.
T • us Circling Nature dampt, a while retrains
H • r ha • y Coure, and in a Paue remains;
Till working a return t'h • r wonted Pot,
She eeks her elf, and to her elf is lot.
T •• Herd of Fops the frantick Humour take,
<> k •• ps a Capon, loves its mincing Gate,
I • s • lowing • air, and triving all it can,

<>
••• nging Mode and Dres, t' appear a Man.
<> the Wilder Luxu • y of Rome,

<>
Afri • k Furniture, Slaves, Tables come,
A •• Purple Carpets made in Africk Loom.

Thus their •
• ates run out, while all around
The Sot-companions in their Wine are drown'd;
T • e Souldier loads, neglected is his Sword,
With all his Spoils the dearly noble Board:
Rome's Appe • ite grows wi •• y, and what's caught
In Si • ily, to their Boards are living brought:
B • t S • oma • hs go • g'd, (a dearer Luxury)
Mut with • x •• niv • S • w •• n • w hunger buy.
The Phaian Banks, the Birds all eaten, gone,
With their fo • aken Trees in ilence moan,
And have no Muick but the Winds alone.
In Mars's Field no les a Frenzie reigns,
Where Brib'd Aemblies make a Prey of Gains.
Their ervile Votes ob • y the Chink of Gold,
A People and a Senate to be old!
The Senate's elf, which hould our Rights maintain,
From their free pirits, toop to ordid Gain,
The power of right by Gold corrupted dies,
And trampled Majety beneath it lies:
Cato's pretence the Giddy Rout neglect,
Yet did not him, but him they rais'd, d • ject:
Who, tho he won, with concious bluhes • ands,
Aham'd o'th' Power he took from worthier hands.
O Manners, Ruin, and the People's hame!
He uffer'd not alone, the Roman Name,
Virtue and Honour to their Period came.
Thus wretched Rome does her own ruin hare,
At once the Merchant, and at once the War • ,
All Lands are Mortgag'd, and all Perons bound,
And in the Ue the Principal is drown'd.
Thus D • bt's a • eaver, and like that dieae,
Bred in our Bowels, by u ••• lt degrees

Will throug •
• ur thi •
• y <>
• v' • y M • mb • r eize.
Wild Tumults now to Arms for uccour call •
(For want may dare and never fear a fall.)
Wated by Riot, Wealth's a putrid Sore,
That only Wounds can its lot trength retore.
What rules of Reaon, or oft gentle ways,
Rome from this Lethargy of Vice can raie?
Where uch mild Arts can no impreion make,
War, Tumult, Noie and Fury mut awake.
Fortune one Age with three great Chiefs upply'd,
Craus's Blood, Aia; Africk, Pompey's hed;
In Thankles Rome, the Murder'd Caear bled.
Thus as one Soil alone too narrow were,
Their Glorious Dut, and great Remains to bear,
O're all the Earth their catter'd ruin lyes;
Such Honours to the Mighty dead arie.
'Twixt Naples and Puteoli there is,
Deep in the Gaping Earth, a dark A • ys,
Where runs the raging Black Cocytus Stream,
That from its Waters ends a Sulphurous team,
Which preads its ury round the Bla • ed Green,
O're all the fatal compas of its breath
No Verdant Autumn Crowns the fruitful Earth;
No blooming Woods with Vernal Songs reound,
Nothing but Black Confuion all around,
Where lonely Rocks in dimal quiet mourn,
Which aged Cypres dreadfully adorn.
Here Pluto rais'd his head, and through a Cloud
Of Fire and moke, in this Prophetick Mood,
To Giddy Fortune poke,—
All ruling Power,
You love all Change, and quit it oon for more;
You never like what too ecurely tands;
Does Rome not tire your faint upporting hands?
How can you longer bear the inking Frame,
The Roman Youth now hate the Roman Name.
See all around Luxuriant Trophies lye,
And their encreaing Wealth new ills upply.
Golden apiring Piles here Heav'n invade,
There on the Sea encroaching Bounds are made.
Where Field • contriving as from Waters prung,
Inverted Nature's injur'd L • ws they wrong.
So deep the Caverns in the Earth ome make,
They threat my Empire, and my Regions hake;
While to low Quarries others ink for Stone;
And Hollow Rocks beneath their fury groan.
Proud with the hopes to ee another day,
M' infernal Subjects 'gin to diobey:
Fortune be kind, till • le their fury dare,
Turn all your Smiles, and • ir up Rome to war,
And a new Colony of Souls prepare.
Our ooty Lips this Age no blood have tate,
With thirt Tiiphone's dry Throat does wat.
Since Sylla's Sword let out the Purple flood,
And guilty Earth grew fruitful from the blood.
The black grim God did thus to Fortune ay,
Reaching her hand, the yielding Earth gave way;
The fickle Goddes, thus returning, aid,
Father, by all beneath this Earth obey'd,
If dangerous Truths may be with afety told,
My thoughts with yours a jut proportion hold:
No les a rage this willing breat inpires,
I hate the Bleings that to Rome I lent,
And of my Bounty, now abus'd, repent:
Thus the proud height of Rome's apiring Wall,
By the ame dreadful God'twas ra • s'd, hall fall.
Their Blood I'll offer as a Sacrifice,
T' appeae the Ghot of their departed Vice.
I already ee Phar • alian Armies lain,
T •• Funeral Piles of Th • aly and Spain:
Aegypt and Libya's Groans methinks I hear,
T • e dimal • ound of arms now trikes my ear,
An Actian Sea-fight, and retreating fear.
Ma •• wide the entrance of your thirty Soil,
N • w •• irits mu •• i'th' mighty Harvet toil;
Charon's too narrow Boat can ne're convey,
Scarce a whole Fleet will waft the Souls away;
Pale Furies be with the vat ruin Crown'd,
And fill'd with Blood, remangle every Wound.
The • niveral Fabrick of the World,
Rent and divided, to your Empire's hurl'd.
She carce had poke; e're from a Cloud there flyes
A blating flame, that burting hake the Skyes;
At Jove's avenging Thunder, to his Hell,
From the clos'd Earth, affrighted Pluto fell.
When oon the angry Gods their Omens how,
That bode detruction and approaching woe:
Atonihment urpriz'd the darkned Sun,
As if the War already were begun;
Approaching Ills the concious Cynthia knew,
And bluhing, from impiety withdrew.
With hideous noie the falling Mountains cleave;
And treams repult their uual coures leave.
Ingaging Armies in the Clouds appear,
And Trumpets raiing Mars himelf to War.
Now Aetna's flames with an uual roar
Vomit huge Bolts of Thunder in the Air,
Amidt the Tombs and Bones without their Urns,
Portending Spirits end up dimal groans:
A Comet's een with Stars unknown before,
And Jove decending in a Bloody how'r:
The God thee Wonders did in hort unfold,
Caear their Ills no longer hou'd with-hold.
Impatient of revenge, quit Gallick Jars,
And draw his conquering Sword for Civil Wars.
In Cloudy Alps, where the divided Rock
To cunning Grecians did its Nerves unlock,
Altars devoted to Alcides moke.
The Temple with eternal Ice is Crown'd,
Whoe milky top o far in Clouds is drown'd;
You'd think its Shoulders in the Heavens bound.
Not the warm rays of a Meridian Sun,
Or the hot Southern Winds can melt it down.
So fixt with Ice and Snows it did appear,
That its apiring top the Globe might bear.
Here Conquering Caear leads his joyful Bands,
And on the proudet Cliff conid'ring tands.
The ditant Plains of Italy urveys,
And, Hands and Voice to Heaven directed, ays,
Almighty Jove and you, Saturnia, found,
Safe by my arms, oft with my Triumphs Crown'd,
Witnes thee Arms unwillingly I wear,
Unwillingly I come to wage this War,
Compell'd by injuries too great to bear.
Baniht my Country, while I make the Flood,
That laves the Rhine, run Purple all with blood.
While the Gauls, ripe our Rome to re-invade,
I force to skulk behind their Alps, afraid:
By Conquering my Banihment's ecur'd.
Are ixty Triumphs not to be • ndur'd?
A German Conquet reckon'd uch a fault?
By whom is Glory uch a Monter thought?
Or who the vile upporters of this War?
A foreign Spawn, a Mobb in Arms appear,
At once Rome's candal, and at once her care.
No lavih Soul hall bind this Arm with Chains,
And unreveng'd triumph it o're the Plains.
Bold with ucces till to new Conquets lead,
Come, my Companions, thus my Caue I'le plead,
The Sword hall plead our caue, for to us all
D • es equal guilt, and equal danger, call:
Oblig'd by you I conquer'd, not alone.
Since to be puniht is the Victor's Crown,
Fortune invokt begin the offer'd War,
My Caue is pleaded when you bravely dare,
With uch an Army, who ucces can fear.
Thus Caear poke: from the propitious sky
Decending Eagles, boding Victory,
Drive the • low winds before 'em as they Fly.
From the left ide of a dark Wood proceed
Unwonted crys, which dying, flames ucc • ed.
The Sun-beams with unuual brightnes rie,
And pread new Glories round the gilded Skies.
New fir'd with Omens of the promis'd day,
Caear o're untrod Mountains leads the way;
Where th' Fr • zen Earth o're-clad with Ice and Snows,
At firt not yielding to their Hores blows,
A dreadful quiet in dull tiffnes hows.
But when their trembling Hoofs had burt the Chain,
And often'd milky Clouds of hardned rain;
So quick the melted Snows to Rivers run,
That oon a deluge from the Mountains prung.
But thus you'd think 'twere done by Fates decrees,
For the Flood topt, and Billows riing Freeze,
And yielding Waves but now are Rocks of Ice.
The lippery paage now their fe • t betray,
VVhen oon in mierable heaps o'th' way,
Men, Hores, Arms, in wild confuion lay.
Now pregnant Clouds with whirling blats are torn,
And, burting, are deliver'd of a Storm:
Large tones of Hail the troubl'd Heavens hoot,
That by tempetuous winds are whirl'd about;
So thick it pours, whole Clouds of Snow and Hail,
Like Frozen Billows, on their Armour fall:
The Earth lay vanquiht under mighty Snow,
An Icy damp the vanquiht Heavens know,
And vanquiht Waters now no longer flow.
Thus all but Caear yield; on his • uge Lance
The Hero leaning, did ecure advance.
Alcmena's Son did les ecurely ruh,
From the proud height of riing Caucaus;
Or Jove himelf, when down the teep he pret
Thoe Sons of Earth, that durt his Heaven molet.
While raging Caear cales th' apiring height,
Big with the news, Fame takes before her flight;
And from Mount Palatine approaching ills,
To frighted Rome, thus dreadfully he tells:
A numerous Fleet is riding o're the Main,
The melted Alps are hid with Caear's Train.
That reeking from a German Conquet come,
And with a like detruction threaten Rome.
Now Arms, Blood, Death, and dimal Scenes of War,
Are to their Eyes preented by their fear;
With dreadful thoughts of coming VVar poet,
A wilder tumult raigns in every breat.
This flys by Land, and that the Sea prefers,
And thinks his native oil les afe appears,
The Souldier truts the Fortune of the VVars.
Pret by their Fate, thus as they fear they run.
'Midt thee diorders, through th' abandon'd Town:
A moving ight, wild tumuls here and there,
Follow the blind impules of their fear.
Vanquiht by rumour all, prepar'd for flight,
Their much lamented Habitations quit:
Trembling, this takes his Children in his Arms,
And that protects his Guardian Gods from harms.
Scar'd from their homes, unwillingly they go,
And in their wihes tab the abent Foe.
Some bear their Wives, amidt ten thouand fears,
In ad imbrace; and ome their aged Sires:
The tender Youth, unus'd to Burdens, bear
Only that with 'em for which mot they fear:
Some les dicreet, trive to bear all away,
And only for the Foes prepare the Prey.
So in a Storm when no Sea-arts avail
To guide the Ship with any certain ail;
Some bind the hatter'd Mat, with thoughts ecure
Others are wiming t'ward the peaceful hore;
While with full ails kind Fortune thee implore.
But why do we of uch mall fears complain,
With both the Conuls greater Pompey ran,
That Aia aw'd, in dire Hydapes grown
The only Rock, its Pyrates plit upon;
W • oe third Triumph o're Earth made Jove afraid,
Proud with ucces he'd next his Heaven invade:
To whom the Ocean yielding honours gave,
And • ougher Bopherus humbly till'd his wave.
Yet he, of Empires and of Men the hame,
Quitting the honour of a Ruler's name,
Meanly at once abandon'd Rome and Fame.
Now this to Heaven it elf does fears impart,
And the mild train of quiet Gods depart;
Frighted with Wars they quit the impious World,
And leave Mankind in wild confuion hurl'd.
Fair Peace, as leader of the Goodly Train,
Beating her Sno • y Arms, did firt complain:
A wreath of Olives bound her drooping head,
And to Hell's dark inatiate Realms he •• ed.
Jutice and Faith on her attending went,
And mournul Concord with her Garment rent.
On th' other ide from Hell's wide gaping Jaws,
A Train of dire Inhabitants aroe:
Dreadful Erinnys, ierce Bellona there,
Fraud, and Megaera arm'd with brands of fire,
And th' Gatly Image of pale death appear:
Diorder'd Rage from all her Fetters freed,
Proudly 'midt thee lifts her ditracted head,
And her hackt face with bloody Helmet hid.
On her left arm a Target old and worn,
Pierc'd with innumerable Darts was born,
And brands of fire upported in her right,
The impious World with • lames and ruin threat.
The Gods decending, leave their till abode,
For all the Inhabitants of Heaven come,
Chooing their ides, with factious fury down.
For Caear firt Dione does appear,
Pallas and Mars with his huge brandiht Spear;
Phaebe and Phaebus too for Caear came,
And with Cyllenius, to fill the Train,
Alcides went, in all his acts the ame.
The Trumpets ound, when from the Stygian hade
Wild Dicord raies her diorder'd head;
From whoe woln Eyes there ran a briny flood,
And Blood congeal'd o're all her Viage tood;
Her hideous rows of Brazen Teeth were furr'd,
A filthy Gore there iu'd from her tongue,
Rent and divided did her Garb betray
The Image of the Breat on which it lay;
And brandiht Flames her trembling hand obey.
Thus from Hell's deeps he pat with dire deign,
Vp to the top of Noble Appennine,
From whoe proud height he all the World decri'd.
Earth, Seas, and Armies march on every ide,
And burting out at length, with fury cry'd,
Let murderous rage the World to Arms inpire,
That every Nation may appear a fire:
No age or ex hall from the War be free,
Nor ubtle Fear be a • curity.
The Earth it elf hall tremble, and the hock
Make Mountains cl • ft againt each others knock.
M • rcellus guide the Laws, Curio the Crowd,
Let Lentulus inpire the Warlike God.
But why is't Caear uch low meaures takes?
Not cale the Walls? Nor force th' apiring Gates,
Nor to the Town, nor to the Treaure makes?
At Rome, if Pompey ears th' approaching Foe,
Let him to fatal Epidamnum go:
Fill all its Plains with blood. Thus dicord aid,
And impious earth her black D • crces obey'd.
div.p:
When Eumolpus •
with his uual freedom, had deliver'd himelf of th • s, we arrived at Crotona; where having refreht our elves in a little Inn we took up at, the
next day, deigning an Enlargement of our Houe and Fortune, we fell into the company of ome Paraitical Corbacchio's; who immediately enquir'd what we were, and whence we came? When, according to our contrivance, prudently advancing our Characters, we told the credulous Paraites whence we came, and who we were. Upon which, immediately all their Fortunes were at Eumolpus's Feet; and each, to ingratiate himelf into his favour, trove to exceed the ret in preenting him.

While this Flood of Fortune was for a long time flowing on us, Eumolpus, 'midt his happines, having lot the memory of his former condition, o boated his Interet, that he affirm'd, none in Crotona cou'd reit his deires; and that what e're Crime any of us hou'd act, he had Friends enough to wipe off the Guilt.

But, tho' our daily increaing Riches, left my pamper'd body no deire unatisfy'd; and tho' I latter'd my elf into an opinion that ill Fortune had taken her lat leave of me, yet not only the thoughts of my preent condition, but the •• ans of getting to't, wou'd oft • r • ak in upon my Joys, and bitt • r all
the weet. And what, aid I to my elf, if ome one, wier than the ret, hou'd dipatch a Meenger for Africk; hou'd not we oon be dicover'd? What if the Slave Eumolpus, pickt up, glutted with his preent happines, hou'd betray us to his Companions, and maliciouly dicover the whole Cheat? we hould then be put upon the trole again, and be oblig'd with hame to renew our former beggery. Heavens, how ill it fares with wicked lives! they ever expect the punihment they deerve.

p.q: Going out full of thee thoughts to divert my concern, I reolv'd on a Walk, but I had carce got into a publick one, e're a pretty Girl made up to me, and calling me Polyaenus, told me her Lady wou'd be proud of an opportunity to peak with me.
You're mitaken, Sweet heart, return'd I, in a little heat, I'm but a Servant, of another Country too, and not worthy of o great a favour.

div.p:
No Sir, aid he, I have commands to you; but becaue you know what you can do, you're proud; and if a Lady wou'd receive a favour from you, I ee he mut buy it: For to what end are all thoe allurements, • orooth? the Curl'd
Hair, the Complexion advanc'd by a Wah, and the wanton roll of your Eyes, the tudy'd Air of your Gate? unles by howing your Parts, to invite a Purchaer? For my part I am neither a Witch, nor a Conjurer, yet can gues at a Man by his Phyiognomy. And when I find a Spark walking, I know his Contemplation. To be hort, Sir, if o be you are one of them that • ell their Ware, I'll procure you a Merchant; but if you're a Courteous Lender, confer the benefit. As for your being a Servant, and below, as you ay, uch a favour, it increa • es the flames of her that's dying for you • 'Tis the wild Extravagance of ome Women to be in love with Filth, nor can be rais'd to an appetite, but by the Charms forooth of ome Slave or La • quy; ome can be pleas'd with nothing but the trutting of a Prize-fighter with a Hack • -face, and a Red Ribbon in his Shir • : Or an Actor betray'd to protitute him •• lf on th' Stage, by the vanity of howing his pretty Shapes th • re; of this ort is my Lady; who indeed, ad •• d he, prefers the paultry Lover of the Upper G • ll • ry, with his dirty Face, and Oaken <> to all th •
• ine Gentlemen of the Boxes, with their Patches, Gunpowder-po • s, and Toothpickers.
When pleas'd with the humour of her Talk, I beeech you, Child, aid I, are you the the that's o in love with my peron? Upon which the Maid fell into a fit of Laughing. I wou'd not return'd he, have you o extr • amly • latter your elf, I never yet truckl'd to a Waiter, nor will Venus allow I hou'd imbrace a Gibbet. You mut addres your elf to Ladies that kis the Enigns of Slavery; be aur'd that I, though a Servant, have too fine a tat to convere with any below a Knight. I was amaz'd at the relation of uch unequal paions, and thought it miraculous to find a Servant, with the cornful pride of a Lady, and a Lady with the humility of a Servant.

Our pleaant Dicoure continuing, I deir'd her to bring her Lady: he readily conented, and taking hold of her Petticoats, tript it into a Lawrel Labyrinth, that border'd on the Walk; 'twas not long e're he uher'd her Lady to me; a Beauty excelling even the • lattery of Painters; words can't expres o perfect a Creature; whatever I hou'd ay of her wou'd fall hort of what he was. Her Hair pread all o're her Shoulders, and eem'd in eaie Curls to wanton in
the Air. Her Forehead oval, and that naturally inclin'd the Hair to its advantage. The proportion of her Eye-brows was mot correct. Her Eyes eclypt the Glory of the brightet Star. Her Noe had an eaie turn, and Mouth was uch Praxiletes believ'd Venus had. Then her Chin, her Neck, her Arms, and Feet, gently girt with Embroider'd Sandals, to whoe whitenes the Parian Marble wou'd • rve but as a • oil. 'Twas then I began to depie my old Mitres Doris. And thus broke out:
div.l: Sure amorous Jove's a holy tale above;
With fancy'd arts that wait upon his love,
When we are bl • t with uch a charm as this,
And he no Rival of our happines:
How well the Bu • l wou'd now the God become:
Or his Grey- • airs to be transform'd to Down?

Here's Dana •
's •• lf, a touch from her wou'd fire,
And make the God in Liquid joys expire.
div.p:
She was pleas'd, and mil'd with uch an air, that, • he eem'd like the Moon in • ll her Glories breaking through a Cloud; • hen addreing her elf, her pretty Fingers humouring the turn of her Voice, If
a fine Woman • and that but this year, has been acquainted with a Man, aid he, may deerve your love, let me commend a Mitres to you. I am enible you have a Comrade already, nor have I thought it below me to inquire it: But why not a Mitres too? I enter the Lit on the ame bottom with your Comrade; nor do I deire to engros all the Carees; only think me deerving, and confer them as you pleae.

Let me beeech you, Madam, return'd I, by all thoe Cupids in your Face and Meen, not to corn to admit a tranger into the number of your Admir • rs. You'l find him mot Religious, if you accept his Devotions, and that you hou'd not upect I believe the way to this Heaven, unlike all others, may be trod Gratis, I preent you with my Comrade.

What? aid he, do you give him without whom you cou'd not live? On whoe lips your very Being hangs? Whom you o love, as I cou'd you. Her words were attended with • uce a Grace at their delivery, and the weet • ound o charm'd the yielding air, you wou'd have worn ome Syren had been breathing Melodies. Thus rapt with every thing o amazing, and fancying a Glory
hin'd in every part, I ventur'd to enquire what name the Goddes own'd? My Maid, I • perceive, aid he, has not inform'd you, I am call'd Circe; I would not have you believe, tho' I bear that name, that I derive my original from Apollo; nor that my Mother, while he lay in the God's Imbraces, held the fiery Steeds: Yet I hall know enough of Heaven, if Fate will give you to my Arms. And who knows the dark Decrees? Therefore come, my Dear, and Crown my Wihes. Nor need you fear any Malicious diturber of our Joys. Your Comrade is far enough from hence.
Upon which, he threw her Downy Arms about me, and led me to a Plat of Ground, the Pride of Nature, deckt with a gay variety of every pleaing object.
div.l: On Ida's top, when Jove his Nymph caret,
And Lawles heat in open view expret:
His Mother Earth in all her Charms was een.
The Roe, the Violet, the weet Jeamin,
And the fair Lilly miling on the Green.
Such was the Plat on which my Venus lay,
But ecret our love, more Glorious the Day,
When all around was bright, and as the Nymph as Gay.
div.p: Here we prepar'd for Battel, and through ten thouand Kies pret to a cloer engagement; but a udden weaknes rob'd me of my arms. Thus cheated in her expectation, he highly reenting it, askt whether her Lips, her Breath, or ome ill cent of any part of her, offended me? Or if none of thoe, whether I fear'd Gito?

I was o aham'd of my elf, that if there was any park of the Man left in me, I lot it. And finding every part of me feeble, and as it were lifeles: I beeech you, Madam, aid I, don't triumph o're my miery: I'm urely bewitcht.

p.q: So light an excue cou'd not allay her reentment, but giving me a didainful glance,
p.U: he turn'd to her Maid, and, I prithee Cryis, aid he, be free with me, don't flatter your Mitres, Is there any thing misbecoming or ungentile about me? Or have I us'd Art to hide any natural deformity? I don't know how you've dret me to day.

div.p:
Upon which, e're Chryis cou'd make a return, he natcht a Pocket-glas from her, and after he had practis'd all her Looks, to try if any appear'd les charming than before, he took hold of her
Petticoats that were a little rumpl'd with lying on, and immediately ran to a Neighbouring Temple dedicated to Venus.
I could not tell what to ay or do, but as if I had een a Viion, at lat began with horror to conider whether I had been rob'd of any real joy.
div.l: So when a Dream our wandring Eyes betrays,
And to our ide ome hidden Gold conveys;
Our buie hands th' inviting Treaure eize,
And hide in guilty folds the fancy'd prize.
Sweating we fear le • t any concious py,
Might earch our boom, and the thet decry.
But with our leep when all our joys are o're,
And minds retor'd to what they were before,
Concern'd, we wih the fancy'd Los regain'd,
And with the Image till are entertain'd.

p.q:
This misfortune might make me jutly think it not only a true Viion, but real Witchcraft; for I had o long lot my trength I cou'd not rie: my mind at lat, a little freed, began by degrees to recover its vigour, upon which I went to my Lodging, and diembling a faintnes, lay down on the bed. A little after Gito, being inform'd I was ill, came to me
much troubl'd; but to allay his concern, I told him I was only a little weary, and had a mind for a Nap. Several things I talkt to him of, but not a word of my lat adventure, for I was afraid becaue I knew he envy'd every one that had a Charm for me, and to prevent his upicion, throwing my Arms about him, I endeavour'd to give a proof of my love; but diappointed of the expectation I had rais'd him to, he roe very angry from my ide, and accuing my weaknes, and trange behaviour to him, told me that of late he had found my chief favours were betow'd in anothers Arms.
My Love to you, Gito, aid I, has ever been the ame, but now my Dancing days ubmit to reaon.

div.p: Therefore, aid he, Laughing at me, in the name of Socrates, I thank you, becaue like him, you propoe to love me: Alcibiades, Encolpius, did not rie a Virgin from that Philoopher's ide.
Then added I, believe me, Gito, I hardly know I've any thing of Man about me, now ueles lyes the terrible part, where once I was Achilles.

When he found how unfit I was to confer the Favours he wanted, and to prevent a upicion of his privacy with
me, he jumpt up and ran to another part of the Houe.
He was hardly gone, e're Chryis enter'd my Chamber, and gave me a Billet from her Mitres, in which I found this written:

HAD I rais'd my expectation, I might deceiv'd, complain; now I'm oblig'd to your impotence, that has made me enible how much too long I have trifl'd with mitaken hopes of pleaure. Tell me, Sir, how you deign to betow your elf, and whether you dare rahly venture home on your own Legs? for no Phyician ever allow'd it cou'd be done without trength. Let me advie your tender years to beware of a Palie: I never aw any body in uch danger before. On my Concience you are jut going! and hou'd the ame rude Chillnes eize your other parts. I might be oon, alas! put upon the evere trial of weeping at your Funeral. But if you would not upect me of being incere, tho' my reentment can't equal the injury, yet I hall not envy the Cure of a weak unhappy Wretch. If you wou'd recover your trength, ask Gito, or rather not ask him for't.—I can aure a return of
your vigour if you cou'd leep three nights alone: As to my elf I am not in the leat apprehenive of appearing to another les Charming than I have to you. I am told neither my Glas nor report does flatter me. Farewell, if you can.

When Chryis
• ound I had read the reproach, this is the cutom, Sir, aid he, and chiefly of this City, where the Women are skill'd in Magick-charms, enough to make the Moon confes their power; therefore the recovery of any ueful Intrument of Love becomes their care; 'tis only writing ome oft tender things to my Lady, and you make her happy in a kind return. For 'tis confet, ince her Diappointment, he has not been her elf; I readily conented, and calling for Paper, thus addret my elf:

'TIS confet, Madam, I have often inned, for I'm not only a Man, but a very young one, yet never left the Field o dihon ••• ably before. You have at your Fe • t <> con • eing Criminal, that deerves whatever you <> I have cut a Throat, betray'd m • Country, committed Sacril • ge; if a p •• ihment for any of thee will erve, I am ready • o
receive entence. If you fancy my death, I wait you with my Sword; but if a beating will content you, I fly naked to your Arms. Only remember, that 'twas not the Workman, but his Intruments that fail'd: I was ready to engage, but wanted Arms. Who rob'd me of them, I know not; perhaps my eager mind outrun my body; or while with an unhappy hate I aim'd at all; I was cheated with abortive joys. I only know I don't know what I've done: You bid me fear a Palie, as if the Dieae cou'd do greater that has already rob'd me of that, by which I hou'd have purchas'd you. All I have to ay for my elf, is this, that I will certainly pay with interet the Arrears of Love, if you allow me time to repair my misfortune.

Having ent back Chryis with this Anwer, to encourage my jaded Body, a • ter the Bath and • trengthning Oyles, had a little rais'd me, I apply'd my elf to provocation-meats, uch as trong Broths and Eggs, uing Wine very moderately; upon which to ettle my elf, I took a little Walk, and returning to my Chamber, lept tha • night without Gito; o great was my care to acquit my elf honourably
with my Mitres, that I was afraid he might have tempted my contancy, by tickling my ide.

The next day riing without prejudice, either to my body or pirits, I went, tho' I fear'd the place was ominous, to the ame Walk, and expected Chryis to conduct me to her Mitres; I had not been long there, e're he came to me, and with her a little Old Woman. After he had aluted me, What, my nice Sir Courtly, aid he, does your Stomach begin to come to you?
At what time, the Old Woman, drawing from her boome, a wreath of many colours, bound my Neck; and having mixt pittle and dut, he dipt her finger in't, and markt my Fore head, whether I wou'd or not.

When this part of the Charm was over, he made me pit thrice, and as often pret to my boome Enchanted Stones, that he had wrapt in purple; after which, he began to exam • n my Breeches, when quick as thought, the welling Inhabitant obey'd her power, and gave her above two hands-full: She, was all joy; and d'ye ee, my Chryis, aid he, d'ye ee what a Hare I have tarted, for another to have the pleaure of the Chace.
div.l: Never depair; Priapus I invoke
To help the parts that make his Altars moke.

p.q: After this, the Old Woman preented me to Chryis; who was very glad he had recover'd her Mitres's Treaure; and therefore hatning to her, he conducted me to a mot pleaant retreat, deckt with all that Nature cou'd produce to pleae the ight.

div.l: Where lofty Plains o • re-pread a Summer hade,
And well trimm'd Pines their haking tops diplay'd,
Where Daphne 'midt the Cyprus crown'd her Head.
Near thee, a circling River gently flows,
And rolls the P • bbles as it murmuring goes.
A place deign'd for Love, the Nightingale
And other wing'd Inhabitants can tell.
That on each Buh alute the coming day,
And in their Orgyes ing its hours away.
div.p:
She was in an undres, reclining on a flowry bank, and diverting her elf with a Myrtle Branch; as oon as I appear'd, he bluht, as mindful of her diappointment:
Chryis, very prudently withdrew, and when we were left together, I approacht the Temptation; at what time, he skreen'd my face with the Myrtle, and as if there had been a wall between us, becoming more bold; what, my chill'd Spark, began he, have you brought all your elf to day?

Do you ask, Madam, I return'd, rather than try? and throwing my elf to her, that with open Arms was eager to receive me, we kit a little Age away; when giving the ignal to prepare for other Joys, he drew me to a more cloe Imbrace; and now, our murmuring Kies their weet fury tell; now, our twining Limbs, try'd every fold of Love; now, lockt in each others Arms, our Bodies and our Souls are join'd: But even here, alas! even amidt thee weet beginnings, a uddain chillnes pret upon my Joys, and made me leave 'em not compleat.

Circe, enrag'd to be o affronted, had recoure to Revenge, and calling the Grooms that belong'd to the Houe, made them give me a warming; nor was he atisfi'd with this, but calling all the Servant-Wenches, and meanet of the Houe, he made 'em pit upon me. I hid my
Head as well as I cou'd, and, without b • gging pardon, for I knew what I had deerv'd, am turn'd out of doors, with a large Retinue of kicks and pittle: Proelenos, the Old Woman was turn'd out too, and Chryis beaten; and the whole Family wondering with themelves, enquir'd the Caue of their Lady's diorder.

I hid my bruizes as well as I cou'd, let my Rival Eumolpus might port with my hame, or Gito be concern'd at it; therefore, as the only way to diguie my Misfortune, I began to diemble Sicknes, and having got in Bed, to revenge my elf of that part of me, that had been the Caue of all my Misfortunes; when taking hold of it,
div.l: With dreadful St • el, the part I wou'd have lopt,
T • rice from my trembling Hand the Razor dropt.
N • w, what I might be • ore, I cou'd not do,
For cold as Ice the fearful Thing withdrew;
And hrunk behind a wrinckled Canopy,
Hiding his Head from my Rev • nge and me.
Thus, by his fear, I'm baulkt of my deign,
When I in words more killing vent my pleen.
div.p: At what time, raiing my elf on the Bed, in this or the like manner, I reproacht the • ullen impotent: With what face can you look up, thou hame of Heaven and Man? that can't not be eriouly mention'd Have I deerv'd from you, when rais'd within ight of Heavens of Joys, to be truck down to the lowet Hell? To have a candal fixt on the very prime and vigour of my Years, and to be reduc'd to the weaknes of an Old Man? I beeech you, Sir, give me an Epitaph on my departed vigour; tho' in a great heat I had thus aid,
div.l: He till continu'd looking on the ground,
Nor more, at this had rais'd his guilty Head,
Than th' drooping Poppy on its tender talk.
div.p:
Nor when I had done, did I les repent of my ridiculous Paion, and with a concious bluh, began to think, how unaccountable it was, that forgetting all hame, I hou'd contend with that part of me, that all Men of Sence, reckon not worth their thoughts. A little after, relaping to my former humour: But what's the Crime, began I, if by a Natural complaint I was eas'd of my grief?
or how is it, that we blame our Stomachs or Bellies, when 'tis our Heads that are ditemper'd? Did not
• lyes beat his breat • as if that had diturb'd him? And don't we ee the Actors punih their Eyes, as if they heard the Tragick Scene? Thoe that have the Gout in their Legs, Swear at them: Thoe that have it in their Fingers, do o by them: Thoe that have • ore Eyes, are angry with their Eyes.
div.l: Why do ye trickt-liv'd Cato's of the Age,
At my familiar lines o gravely rage?
In meaures looly plain, blunt Satyr flows,
Which all the People o incerely hows.
For whoe a Stranger to the Joys of Love?
Who, can't the thoughts of uch oft Pleaures move?
Such Epicurus own'd the chiefet blis,
And uch Lives the Gods themelves poes.
div.p:
There's nothing more deceitful than a ridiculous Opinion, nor more ridiculous, than an affected Gravity. After this, I call'd Gito to me; and tell me, aid I, but incerely, whether Acyltos, when he took you from me, puru'd the injury that Night, or was Chatly content
to lye alone? The Boy with his • inger at his E • es, took a olemn Oath, that • e had no incivility offer'd him by Acyltos.

This drove me to my Wits end, nor did I well know what to • ay: For why, I conider'd, hou'd I think of the twice michievous accident that lately be • ell me? At lat, I did what I cou'd to recover my vigour; and willing to invoke the aitance of the Gods, I went out to pay my Devotions to Priapus, and as wretched as I was, did not depair, but kneeling at the entry of the Chamber, thus beeecht the God:
div.l: Bacchus and Nymphs delight, O mighty God!
Whom Cynthia gave to Rule the blooming wood.
Lesbos and verdant Tha • os thee adore,
And Lydians, in looe • lowing Dres implore,
And raie devoted Temples to thy Power.
Thou D • yard's Joy, and Bacchus's Guardian, be • r
My concious Prayer, with an attentive Ear.
My Hands with guiltles Blood I never tain'd,
Or Sacrilegiouly the Gods Prophan'd.
To feeble me, retoring B • eings end,
I did not th • e, with my whole elf o ••• nd.
Who Sins thro' weaknes is les guilty thought,
Be pacify'd, and pare a Venial Fault.
On me, when Fate hall miling Gifts betow,
I'll not ungrateful to thy Godhead go.
A detin'd Goat hall on thy Altar lye,
And the • orn'd Parent of my F • ock hall dye.
A ucking Pig appeae thy injur'd Shrine,
And ballow'd Bowls o're-low with generous Win • .
Then thrice thy frantick Votaries hall round
Thy Temple Dance, with Youth and Garlands crown'd,
In Holy Drunkennes thy Orgies ound.
div.p: While I was thus at Prayers, an Old Woman, with her hair about her Eyes, and difigur'd with a mournful Habit, coming in, diturb'd my Devotions; when taking hold of me, he drew me all fear out of the entry; and what Hag, aid he, has devour'd your M • nhood? Or what Ominous Carcas have you • umbl'd over in your Nightly walks? You have not acquitted your elf above a Boy; but • aint, weak, and like a Hore o're-charg'd in a teep, tyr'd, have lo • t your toyl and weat; nor content to in alone, but you have unreveng'd againt me, provokt the off • nded Gods.

When leading me, obedient to all her Commands, a econd time to the Cell of a Neighbouring Prie • es of Priapus; he threw me upon the Bed, and taking up a tick that fatned the door, reveng'd her elf on me, that very patiently receiv'd her • ury: and at the firt troak, if the breaking of the tick had not lened its • orce, he might have broke my Head and Arm.

I groan'd, and hiding with my Arm my Head, in a flood of • ears lean'd on the Pillow: Nor did he then, les troubled, • it on the Bed, and began in a hrill voice to blame her Age, till the Prietes came in upon us; and what, aid he, do you do in my Chappel, as if ome Funeral had lately been, rather than a Holy-day, in which, even the mournful are merry.

Alas, my Enothea! aid he, this Youth was born under an ill Star; for neither Boy nor Maid can raie him to a perfect Appetite; you ne're beheld a more unhappy Man: In his Garden, the weak Willow, not the luty Cedar grows; in hort, you may gues what he is, that co • 'd rie Unblet from Circe's Bed.
div.l: All Natures Works my Magick Powers obey,
The blooming Earth hall wither and d • cay,
And when I pleae, agen be freh and gay.
From rugged Rocks, I make weet waters flow,
And raging Billows to me humbly bow.
With Rivers, Winds, when I command, obey,
And at my fe • t, their Fans contracted lay,
Tygers and Dragons too, my Will obey.
But thee are mall, when of my Magick Vere,
Decending Cynthia does the power confes.
When my Commands, make trembling Phaebus Reign,
His fiery Steeds, their Journ • y back again.
Such power have Charms, by whoe prevailing aid
The fury of the raging Bulls was laid.
The Heaven-born Circe, with her Magick Song,
Ulyes's Men, did into Monters turn.
Proteus, with this aum'd, what hape he wou'd.
I, who this Art o long have undertood,
Can end proud Ida's top into the Main,
And make the billows bear it up again.
div.p: I hook with fear at uch a Romantick Promie, and began more intentively to view the Old Woman: Upon which, he cry'd out, O Enothea, be as good as your word; when, carefully wiping her Hands, he lay down on the Bed, and half mother'd me with Kies.

Enothea, in the middle of the Altar, plac'd a Turf-Table, which he heapt with burning coals, and her old crackt Cup (for Sacrifice) repair'd with temper'd pitch; when he had fixt it to the moaky-wall from which he took it; putting on her Habit, he plac'd a Kettle by the Fire, and took down a Bag that hung near her, in which, a Bean was kept for that ue, and a very aged piece of a Hog's Forehead, with the print of a hundred cuts out; when opening the bag, he threw me a part of the Bean, and bid me carefully trip it. I obey her Command, and try, without daubing my • ingers, to deliver the grain from its naty coverings; but he, blaming my dullnes, natcht it from me, and skilfully tearing its shells with her Teeth, pit the black morels from her, that lay like dead Flies on the ground. How ingenious is Poverty, and what trange Arts will Hunger teach? The Prietes eem'd o great a
Lover of this ort of Life, that her Humour appear'd in every thing about her, and her Hut might be truly term'd, Sacred to Poverty.
div.l: Here hines no glittering Ivory et with Gold,
No Marble covers the deluded Mold,
By its own Wealth deluded; but the Shrine
With imple Natural Ornaments does hine.
Round Cere's Bow • r, but homely Willows gro • ,
Earthen are all the Sacred Bowls they know.
O • ier the Dih, Sacred to ue Div • ne:
Both coure and tain'd, the Jug that holds the Wine.
Mud mixt with traw, make a defending Fort,
The Temple's brazen tuds, are knobs of dirt.
With Ruh and Reed, is thatcht the Hut it elf,
Where, beides what is on a moaky helf,
Ripe Service-Berries into Garlands bound,
And avory-bunches with dry'd Grapes are found.

Such a low Cottage Hecal •
confin'd,
Low was her Cottage, but ublime her Mind.
Her bounteous Heart, a grateful Praie hall crown,
And Mues ma • e Immortal her Renown.
div.p:
After which, he tated of the fleh, and hanging the ret, old as her elf, on the hook again; the rotten Stool on which
he was mounted breaking, threw her on the fire, her fall plit the Kettle, and what it held put out the fire; he burnt her Elbow, and all her face was hid with the ahes that her fall had rais'd.

Thus diturb'd, I aroe, and Laughing, took her up; immediately, le • t any thing hou'd hinder • he offering, he ran for new fire to the Neighbourhood, and had hardly got to the door, e're I was et upon by three Sacred Geee, that daily, I believe, about that time were fed by the Old Woman; they made an hideous noie, and, urrounding me, one tears my Coat, another my Shooes, while their furious Captain made nothing of doing o by my Legs; till eeing my elf in danger, I began to be in earnet, and natching up one of the • eet of our little Table, made the valiant Animal feel my arm'd hand; nor content with a light blow or two, but reveng'd my elf with its death.
div.l: Such were the Birds Alcides did ubdue,
That from his Conquering Arm t'ward Heaven Flew:
Such ure the Harpyes were which Poyon trow'd,
On Cheated Phineus's fale deluding food.
Loud Lamentations hake the trembling Air,
The Powers above the wild confuion hare,
Horrours diturb the Order of the Sky,
And frighted Stars beyond their Cour • s fly.
div.p: By this time the other two had eat up the pieces of the Bean that lay catter'd on the Floor, and having lot their Leader, return'd to the Temple. When glad of the Booty, and my revenge, I hea • 'd the light Wound in my Leg with Vinegar. But fearing the Old Womans an • er, I deign'd to make off; and taking up my Cloaths, began my march; nor had I reacht the door, e're I aw Enothea bringing in her hand an Earthen Pot fill'd with Fire; upon which I retreated, and throwing down my Cloaths, • ixt my elf in the Entry, as if I were impatiently expecting her coming.

Enothea, entring, plac'd the Fire, that with broken Sticks he had got together, and having heapt more Wood upon thoe, began to excue her tay, that her Friend wou'd not let her go before he had, againt the Laws of Drinking, taken off three Healths together. When looking about her, What, aid he, have you been doing in my abence? Where's the Bean?

I, who thought I had behav'd my elf very honourably, told her the whole fight; and to end her grief, for the los of the Bean, preented the Gooe: when I hew'd the Gooe, the Old Woman et up uch an out • cry, that you wou'd have thought the Geee were re-entring the place.
In confuion and amaz'd, at o trange a humour, I askt the meaning of her paion? or why he pity'd the Gooe rather than me.

But wringing her hands, you wicked Wretch, aid he, d'ye peak too? D'ye know what you've done? You've kill'd the Gods delight, a Gooe the pleaure of all Matrons: And, let you shou'd think your elf innocent, if a Magitrate shou'd hear of it, you'd be hang'd. You have defil'd with blood my Cell, that to this day had been inviolate. You have done that, for which, if any's o malicious, he may expel me my Office.
div.l: She aid, and trembling, rends her aged Hairs,
And both her Cheeks with wilder fury tears:
Sad murmurs from her troubl'd breat arie,
A Shower of tears there iu'd from her eyes.
And down her face a rapid deluge run,
Such as is een, when a Hills froty Crown,
By warm Favonius is melted down.
div.p: Upon which, I beeech you • aid I, don't grieve, I'll recompence the los of your Gooe with an Otrich.

While amaz'd I poke, he at down on the Bed, lamented her los; at what time Proelenas came in with the Sacrifice, and viewing the murder'd Gooe, and enquiring the caue, began very earnetly to cry and pity me, as it had been a Father, not a Gooe I had lain. But tired with this tuff, I beeech ye, aid I, tell me, tho' it had been a Man I kill'd, won't Gold wipe off the Guilt? See here are two Pieces of Gold: with thee you may purchae Gods as well as Geee.

Which, when Enothea beheld, Pardon me, Young Man, aid she, I am only concern'd for your afety, which is an argument of Love, not Hatred; therefore we'll take what care we can to prevent a dicovery: You have nothing to do, but intreat the Gods to forgive the Sin.
div.l: Who e're has Money may ecurely ail,
On all things with all-mighty Gold prevail.

May Dana •
wed, or Rival amo'rous Jove,
And make her Father Pandar to his Love.
May be a Poet, Preacher, Lawyer too:
And bawling win the caue he does not know:
And up to Cato's Fame for widom grow.
Wealth without Law will gain at Bar renown,
How e're the cae appears, the caue is won,
Every rich Lawyer is a Littleton.
In hort of all you wih you are poet,
All things prevent the Wealthy man's requet,
For Jove himelf's the Treaure of his Chet.
div.p: While my thoughts were thus engag'd, he plac'd a Cup of Wine under my hands, and having cleans'd my prophane extended fingers with acred Leeks and Parley, threw into the Wine, with ome Ejaculation, Hazel-Nuts, and as they unk or wam gave her judgment; but I well knew the empty rotten ones wou'd wim, and thoe of entire Kernels go to the bottom.

When applying her elf to the Gooe, from its open'd Breat, he drew a luty Liver, and then told me my future Fortune. But that no mark of the Murder might be left, he • ixt the rent Gooe to a Spit, which, as he aid, she had fatten'd
a little before, as enible it was to die.

In the mean time the Wine went bri • kly • ound, and now the Old Women gladly devour the Gooe, they o lately lamented; when they had pickt its Bones, Enothea half drunk, turn'd to me; and now, aid she, I'll finish the Charm that recovers your trength: When drawing out a Leathern Enign of Priapus, She dipt it in a medley of Oyl, mall Pepper, and the bruis'd eed of Nettles, and began by degrees to direct its paage through my hinder parts; with this mixture h • barbarouly prinkl'd my Manhood; and with the juice of Crees and Suthernwood wahing the Plat around it, began with a bunch of Green Nettle, to trike gently all the Vale below my Navel. Upon which jumping from her, to avoid the ting, I m • de off. The Old Women in a great rage puru'd me, and, tho' drunk with Wine, and their more hot deires, took the right way; and follow'd me through two or three Villages, crying top Thief; but with my hands all bloody, in the haty flight, I got off.

When I got home, to eae my wearied Limbs, I went to Bed, but the thoughts
my misfortunes would not let me leep; when conidering how unparallel'd a Wretch I was, I cry'd out, Did my ever cruel Fortune want the afflictions of love to make me more mierable? O unhappines! Fortune and Love conpire my ruin. Severer love pares me no way, or loving, or belov'd, a Wretch: Chryis adores me, and is ever giving me occaions to addres: She, that when she brought me to her Mitres, depis'd me for my mean habit as one beneath her deires; that very Chryis that o corn'd my former fortune, purues this even with the hazard of her own; and wore, when he firt dicover'd to me the violence of her love, that he wou'd be ever true to me. But Circe's in poeion of my heart, I value none but her; and indeed who wears uch Charms? Compar'd to her • what was Ariadne or Lyda? what Helen, or even Venus? Paris himelf the Umpire of the wanton Nymphs, if with thee eyes he had een her contending for the Golden Apple, wou'd have given both his Helen, and the Goddees for her. If I might be admitted to kis her weet lips again, or once more pres her divinely riing Breats, perhaps my vigour wou'd revive, which now I believe lyes
oppret by Witchcraft. I hou'd dipence with m • reproaches, hou'd for ••• that I was beat; eteem my b • ing <> out of doors, • port; o I might b • again happy in her favour.

Thee thoughts an •
• he im • ge of the b • autiful C • rces o •• is'd my mind, that I oft, as if my love was in my a • ms, with a great deal of frui • les ardor hug'd the Bed-cloaths, till out of patienc • with the lating a •• l • ction I began to reproach my impotence; yet recovering my preence of mind, I l • w for comfort to the misfortunes of ancient Hero's and thus broke out:
div.l: Not only me th' <> Go • s <> ,
Oft th • y th • ir <> on • heir Hero's threw;

By Juno's rage <>
•• aven b • re,

And P • lia's injur'd
• un •
<> b • fore.
<> re • ntments felt,

<>
Tel • phus's <…>
• is guilt.

Cra •• y <>
• ou'd <>
• hun.
• as l • ft his <…> .
div.p:
Full of anxious car • s I pent the night: and Gito, inform'd tha •
• lay at hom •• enter'd
my Chamber by day-break, when having paionately complain'd of my looe life, h •
• old m • the Family took much notice of my behaviour, that I was eldom in waiting, and • hat perhaps the Company I kept wou'd be my ruin.

By this I undertood he was inform'd of my Affairs; and that ome one had been in puruit of me; upon which I askt my Gito whether any body was to enquire for me? Not this day, aid he, but yeterday there came a very pretty Woman, who, when he had tir'd me with a long i • tting-Dicoure; at lat told me you deerv'd to be puniht, and hou'd as a Slave, if you longer complain'd.

This o enibly touch'd me, that I began afreh to reproach Fortune: Nor had I done, e're Chryis came in, and wildly throwing her Arms about me: Now, aid he, I'll hold my wih, you're my Love, my Joy; nor may you think to quench this lame, but by a more cloe embrace.

I was much diturb'd at Chryi's Wantonnes, and gave her • air Language, to
get rid of her; for I was very apprehenive of the danger of Eumolpus's hearing it, ince his Good Fortune had made him o proud. I did therefore what I could to appeae her rage; I diembl'd love, whiper'd oft things, and in hort manag'd it o like a Lover, that he believ'd me one. I made her undertand in what danger we both were, if he hou'd be found with me in that place, and that our Lord Eumolpus puniht the leat offence. Upon which he immediately made out, and the more hatily, becaue he aw Gito returning, who had left me a little before he came.

She was carce out, when on a udden one of the Slaves came to me, and told me that our Lord o highly reented my two days abence, that unles, as he advied me, I invented a good excue to allay his heat, I hou'd certainly be punih'd.

Gito perceiving how concern'd I was, poke not a word of the Woman, but advis'd me to behave my elf merrily to Eumolpus, rather than erious. I puru'd the counel, and put on o pleaant
a face that he receiv'd me in Drollery, without the grave tiffnes of a Mater: He was plea • ant on the ucces of my Amours: Prais'd my Meen and Wit that was o agreeable to the Ladies: and I'm no tranger, aid he, to your love of a very beautiful Lady. But now, Encolpius, that rightly manag'd, may turn to our advantage; therefore do you P • ronate the Lover, I'll continue the Character I've begun.

He was yet peaking, when there enter'd the Room a very Venerable Matron, her Name Philumene, who by the well manag'd Virtues of her S • x had often got great Boo • ies, and now grown old, and pat her blooming years, he'd thrut her Son and Daughter upon childles Old-men, and thus continue her device. She therefore comes to Eumolpus, and addreing, commends her Children to his Conduct, that her elf, and all her hopes he committed to his widom: that he was the only one in this world that with ueful Precepts cou'd daily inform the minds of young people. In hort, that he wou'd leave her Children there, to hear his Widom, which was
the only portion he cou'd give them: Nor was he wore than her word; and leaving a very beautiful Girl, with her little Brother, went out with pretence to pay Heaven publick thanks in the Temple for what he had receiv'd. Eumolpus to whom my elf eem'd but a Boy, immediately invi • ed the Girl to acri • ice to Priapus; but having publickly reported him • elf to be Gouty and feeble, it might endanger his fortune to alter his Character. Ther • fore to maint • in his pretence, he intr •• ted the Girl to • avour his weaknes by •• tting uppermot; the • oy he order'd to get under the Bed, • hat placing his hands on the Ground, with his Body he might move him up and down. He unwillingly obey'd; and now in a jut motion keeps time with his Siter above. • ut when the buines was coming to an iue, Eumolpus loudly call'd to the Boy to quicken his trokes; and thus plac'd between his Mitres, and the Boy, unconcern'd enjoy'd an • ai • luxury at others toil and in. Eumolpus pleas'd with the conc • it, often rep • ated his humour. And I • oo, • earing my Virtues might rut by di • ue, wh •• e the Boy was admiring his Siters
moving Engine, advanc'd to try whether he would be a Patient in Love. The dicreet Youth did not reject the invitation, but my advere fortune till attended me.

I was not o concern'd at this as the former; for a little after my trength return'd, and finding my elf more vigorous, I cry'd ou • , the courteous Gods are greater that have made me whole again. For Mercury, that conveys and reconveys our ouls, by his • avour • has retor'd. wh • t his a • ger had •• iz'd: now I hall be in as great e • e • m as Proteilaus or any of the A • tient • . Upon which taking up my Cloaths, I hew'd my whole elf to Eumolpus, he tartl'd at firt • but oon, to confirm his •• lief • with both hands cha'd the mighty favour of the Gods.

This great bleing making us merry, we laugh'd at
•• ilumen •
's cu • ning, and her Childrens experience in the art, which wou'd profit 'em little with us; for to no other end were they le • t, but to b •
<> to what we had. When re • lecting on thi •
• ordid manner of deceiving childles ag • , I took occaion to conider the condi • ion
of our preent fortune, and told Eumolpus that the deceivers might be deceiv'd, that therefore all our actions hou'd be of a piece with the Character we bore. That Socrates, the wiet of Men, us'd to boat he never aw a Tavern, nor ever had been in the common company that frequents uch places. That nothing was more convenient than a dicreet behaviour. All thee are truths; nor hou'd any • ort of Men, added I, more expect the udden aaults of ill fortune, than thoe that covet what's other Mens. But how hould Pick-Pockets live, unles, by ome well order'd trick, to draw Fools together, they get imployment? As Fih are taken with what they really eat; o Men are to be cheated with omething that's olid, not empty hopes; thus the People of this Country have hitherto receiv'd us very nobly: but when they find the arrival of no Ship from Africk, laden, as you told 'em, with Riches, and your Retinue; the impatient deceivers will leen their bounty; therefore, or I'm mitaken, or Fortune begins to rep • nt her Favours.

I have thought of a means, aid Eumolpus, to make our deceivers continue
their care of us. And drawing his Will out of his Pure, thus read the lat lines of it.

All that have Legacies in this my lat Will and Tetament, my freed Men excepted, receives 'em on thee conditions, that they divide my Body, and ea • it before the People. And that they may not think it an unjut demand, let them know, that to this day 'tis the cutom of many Countries, that the Relations of the Dead devour the Carcas; and for that reaon they often quarrel with their • ick Kindred, becaue they poil their fleh by lingring in a Dieae. I only intance this to my Friends, that they may not refue to perform my Will; but with the ame incerity they wiht well to my Soul, they might devour my Body.

When he had read the chief Articles, ome that were more intimately acquainted with him, enter'd the Chamber, and viewing the Will, earnetly intreated him to impart the contents of it; he readily conented and read the whole. But when they heard the neceity of eating his Carcas, they eem'd much concern'd
at the trange Propoal; but their in • atiate love of the Money made 'em ti • le their paion, and his Peron was o awful to 'em, they durt not complain. But one of ' • m, Gorgias by name, briskly told him he was willing to accept the conditions, o he might not wait for the Body.

To thi •
Eumolpus, I'm not in the leat apprehenive of your performance, nor that your tomach wou'd refue the task, when to recompence one ditateful minute you promie ages of Luxury. 'Tis but hutting your Eyes, and uppoing intead of Man's • leh you were eating an hundred Seterces. Some Sawce may be added to vary the tat; for no • leh pleaes alone, but is prepar'd by art to commend it to the Stomach. If you deire intances of this kind to make ye approve my advice; the Saguntines when they were beieg'd by Hannibal, eat Humane Bodies, without the hopes of an Etate for doing it. The Petav • i reduc'd to the lat extremity did the like; nor had they further hopes in this Banquet than to atisfie Nature. When Scipio took Numantia, Mothers were found with th • ir
Children half eaten in their Arms. But ince the thoughts only of eating Man's fleh create the loathing; 'tis but reolving, and you gain the Mighty Legacies I leave you.

Eumolpus recounted thee hameles inhumanities with o much confuion, that his Paraites began to upect him, and more nearly conidering our words and actions, their jealouie encreas'd with their obervation, and they believ'd us perfect Cheats. Upon which thoe who had receiv'd us mo • t nobly, reolv'd to eize us, and jutly take their revenge; but Chryis, privy to all Stratagems, gave me notice of their deigns; the frightful news o truck me, that I made off with Gito immediately, and le • t Eumolpus to the mercy of his Enemies; and in a few days we heard the Crotonians raging, that that old Racal hou'd live o long at uch a umptuous rate on the publick charge, acrifi • 'd him the Mailian way. Whenever the Mailians were viited with a Plague, ome one of the pooret of the people, for the ake of being well fed a whole year at the publick charge, wou'd offer himelf a Sacrifice to appeae the Gods: He after his year was up, dret in Holy
Wreath and Sacred Garment, was led about the City with Invocations on the Gods, that all the ins of the Nation might be puniht in him; and o was thrown from a Precipice.
